Consumer complaint narrative:
I have encountered several unethical interactions with Bank of America. Their ongoing deceptive practices aim to defraud customers by falsely reporting late payments. This tactic appears designed to sabotage customers ' credit lines, increase interest rates, and reduce credit limits. 

I possess supporting documents for these fraudulent actions. 

Bank of America employs deceptive practices to create financial instruments that defraud their customers, akin to similar actions by other banks in the past. Despite having already paid fines for such conduct, the continued lack of government oversight perpetuates the erosion of trust. The deception and fraud persist unabated. 

Additionally, the XXXX representative assigned to my recent cases has been completely inaccessible. I received a voicemail at XXXX XXXX  XXXX, but all my callbacks and emails have gone unanswered. 

I have reached out to my senator and congressman for assistance in navigating this matter, as I find the governing agency 's role in these proceedings to be duplicitous.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Bank of America allegedly engaged in deceptive practices, falsely reporting late payments to sabotage customers' credit lines, increase interest rates, and reduce credit limits. The complainant has supporting documents and claims to have experienced unresponsiveness from their assigned representative.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I was charged {$210.00} from the merchant XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXI have never purchased anything from this company, nor have I been to XXXX XXXX, Florida. Once I noticed the charge, I opened a dispute ( XX/XX/XXXX ) with Citi. Before Citi would proceed with the dispute, they asked me to contact the merchant and seek a refund. 

I tried to contact the merchant both by telephone ( ( XXXX ) XXXX ) and email. I never received a response. 

After contacting Citi again, they agreed to open a dispute ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 

I sent over all the information Citi requested, and after several weeks, they resolved my dispute in favor of the merchant ( XX/XX/XXXX ). 

I have never seen a clearer case of fraud. If you XXXX " XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX  '' you will inundated with numerous testimonies from other victims of this fraudulent company. 

This is the email I sent to Citi : " Here is the required documentation for the aforementioned dispute. 

I have tried to contact the merchant multiple times. I have yet to get a response. 

A quick XXXX search clearly shows that XXXX is a scam company. It is impossible to contact them. All reviews of the " company '' are simply other people complaining about their credit card information being stolen. '' I'm not sure what else I can do. Hence, why I am opening this case with the CFPB.

Narrative Summary: A consumer was charged $210 by a merchant they'd never purchased from. Despite disputing the charge with Citi and providing documentation, the dispute was resolved in favor of the merchant. The consumer claims the merchant is a scam and unreachable, with numerous online complaints of credit card theft.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Company closed your account
Consumer complaint narrative: At one point in time I filed for an apple credit card via Goldman Sachs and then closed the account. This was around 2022 when it closed and they still are showing up on my credit report and I do not know why? It says via XXXX that dings like this fall off after 3 months and few years later is still there. Its been eating away at my credit score ever since. I need it to be fixed and to show up as a technical error. Its also saying my oldest credit card account was from nine years ago but is also saying I closed that and still have XXXX  XXXX from 9 years ago. I should be getting rewarded credit for this and havent been. Changing to a new XXXX  XXXX card doesnt mean that I sold off my credit history from the previous XXXX years for the new card. Its still capital one and shouldnt change. Only the interest rate and fees should be charged if they ever do accrue! Its ruined my credit history because of this. My longest account by date should have me at 9 years still not 3 years. Apple credit card ding should be removed entirely
Narrative Summary: The consumer is complaining that a closed Apple credit card account (via Goldman Sachs) from 2022 still appears on their credit report, negatively affecting their score. They claim it should have been removed after 3 months, and also dispute the reported age of their oldest credit account.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Can't use card to make purchases
Consumer complaint narrative: I made a {$200.00} payment with my XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/2024. The Available credit was not reflected immediately as I was instructed it would be in the past. I called Capital One and they told me that Capital One is in the process of removing XXXX XXXX payments as an option for making payments. I find that to be very suspicious, because I received no communication that this would be happening. The XXXX on the phone advised me that the Available Credit doesn't update right away because their system doesn't allow it to update right away, which is not normal given the pattern of payments I've made. I make substantially large payments that would cover at least XXXXXXXX XXXX  of the XXXX XXXX every few days or so because my intent was to use this card as an everyday card for purchases. Capital One is treating it very differently. I also questioned the security of my information given that it is being accessed outside of my country. The XXXX expressed that they can not bring bags, cell phones, paper, pens, etc into their offices ( which I find hard to believe ). So I began to question how I know my information is secure, especially when being accessed from a mainframe in a different country from the headquartered location where no law enforcement can hold criminals accountable for stealing information belonging to people not residing within that country.
Narrative Summary: A consumer made a $200 payment to Capital One using XXXX XXXX, but the available credit wasn't reflected immediately. The company claimed they're phasing out this payment method, which the consumer wasn't notified about, raising concerns about payment processing and data security.

At around XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX  XX/XX/year>, I received an alert from XXXX 's " TruIdentity '' program stating that someone ( via Chase XXXX XXXX XXXX asked for access to my XXXX credit report. 

I DID NOT recently apply for ANY type of credit from Chase, so I do not know WHO would do this. 

AN INITIAL FRAUD ALERT has now been placed at EACH of the three CRAs via XXXX.
Narrative Summary: A consumer received an alert that someone via Chase requested access to their credit report, despite not applying for credit with Chase, leading to the placement of initial fraud alerts at the three credit reporting agencies (CRAs).

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card

Consumer complaint narrative:
I reported credit card fraudulent charges on my Truist credit card in XX/XX/XXXX XXXX stopped that card and issued me a new card with a different account number. 
Fraudulent charges from the same company ( XXXX ) kept showing up on the old account which were transferred to my new card. These were new charges. 
I made several attempts to correct this situation and was told these were late posted charges and I wouldnt need to pay. 
In XXXX I noticed another fraudulent charge on my old, inactive card again transferred to my new card, this time with a recent posting date. I inadvertently paid the bill before recognizing this new problem. It happened again in XX/XX/XXXX. Same vendor, same amount same recent posting date. I reported this again for the fourth or fifth time and still have no resolution or explanation of why they are continuing to allow charges to continue being registered to an account closed since XX/XX/XXXX. I have received no satisfaction regarding this issue.

Narrative Summary: A consumer reported fraudulent charges on their Truist credit card, and a new card was issued. However, new charges from the same company continued to appear on the old, inactive account and were transferred to the new card, despite multiple reports and assurances the issue would be resolved.

Sub-issue: Problem during payment process
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was XXXX  for most of 2023, beginning the end of XXXX. When I came home all my bills were overdue, so my sister contact the companies to advise them of my situation and to see what she could do. Hardship payment arrangements were made and auto payments were set up in XX/XX/year>, with the exception of Lowes/Synchrony Bank . The rep refused to assist in providing help with making payments. He said that the account was being turned over to dispute, so he could not offer any assistance.However, that same day, J.C. Penny's/Synchrony account, also turning over to dispute was handled that same day. 

XXXX of the accounts, XXXX XXXX XXXX, initiated a hardship repayment plan; took out the initial funds, but did not credit the rest. When inquiring as to why the auto payments were not being taken out as authorized, the rep claims that auto payments are not allowed for hardship payments, so we turned the account over to collections. When providing the transaction confirmation number, the rep wanted to speak to his supervisor first, so we asked if we could just speak with her directly. He said he asked her, but she fussed to talk to us. 

Both account, XXXX and Lowes/Synchrony Bank have been turned over to collections ; not because I was not willing to make arrangements or payments, but because the reps refused to assist.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer's complaint is about two Synchrony Bank accounts (Lowes and J.C. Penny's) being turned over to collections despite attempts to make hardship payment arrangements. Reps allegedly refused assistance or made false claims about auto payments, leading to accounts being sent to collections.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/24 I booked and paid for a hotel reservation through a supposed hotel-booking website called " XXXX ''. Once I arrived at the hotel ( a XXXX XXXX location ) to check-in, I was told they had found my reservation but no payment had been made. I was then made to pay for the entire reservation again, and I have attached a receipt showing this entire separate payment directly to the hotel. 

At this point, I realized I had been defrauded by the " merchant '' in question, and explained this to the Apple Card Support team. They opened a dispute on XX/XX/24. I followed up with the Apple Card Support team every few weeks after this date, because this seemed like an obvious case of merchant fraud and I was confused why it had yet to be resolved. Ultimately, on XX/XX/24, I received an email stating that the 'dispute had been resolved in the merchant 's favor '. It seems the standard Apple Card Support team is ill-equipped to deal with this obvious case of merchant fraud, and as a loyal Apple customer I am disappointed that this is the case. I would like this to be resolved immediately, and for the Apple Card Executive team to share what steps they will take in the future to prevent having to escalate such a simple case through the CFPB.
Narrative Summary: A consumer booked a hotel through "XXXX" but upon arrival, the hotel claimed no payment was made. The consumer paid again and filed a dispute with Apple Card Support, but it was resolved in the merchant's favor, prompting the consumer to seek further action.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Credit card company won't work with you while you're going through financial hardship
Consumer complaint narrative:
I requested lower monthly payments on one of my credit cards due to financial hardship. I have been a customer with Chase for over twenty five years with a mortgage I have with them. I also have a business checking account.

Today in requesting lower monthly payments after being transferred to six different customer agents I received no help. The last customer support agent, XXXX was rude and hung up on me. 
Chase in the past has always treated me egregiously disrespectful. When people were applying for forbearance due to the Cares Act that was precipitated by the pandemic, Chase didnt want to give me my forbearance until I spent an enormous amount of time insisting on it.

Chase denied me a loan modification as I am an XXXX  person. 
I have a fixed rate mortgage but Chase raised my monthly payments claiming I have an escrow account and the New York tax bureau sent them a letter claiming my taxes were overdue. Chase never produced the letter but still hasnt reduced my monthly payment to what my fixed rate mortgage payment should be as stated on my note. And when I took the mortgage out I did not consent to an escrow account.
Narrative Summary: A long-time Chase customer requested lower credit card payments due to financial hardship but was transferred to six agents and received no help. The last agent was rude and hung up. The customer also claims Chase has a history of disrespect, including issues with their mortgage and loan modification.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Charged too much interest
Consumer complaint narrative: I received a call from the XXXX offices of Barclays Bank. The conversation started off with this call is being recorded with out my permission which is a violation of Texas state and Federal wiretapping laws Texas is considered a " one-party consent '' state. This means that unless at least one of the parties to a conversation consents, both Texas and federal wiretapping laws make it a crime to record an audio conversation, either in person or over the phone, if the parties have a " reasonable expectation of privacy. I requested that the call not be recorded and the Executive said that he would not do that. I requested a copy of the recording and he said that I would have to go to court to get a copy. THIS IS ILLEGAL what this company does. I spoke with the Executive about the fraudulent fees and the fact that they sent out fraudulent documents stating I was late on a payment/missed a payment ( see attached below ) and I spoke about the exorbitant interest rate of XXXX  % this evil greedy organization is charging. The company received by payment via their app on XX/XX/year> and then decided to record it as it was received on XX/XX/year> which is a LIE!! Just so they could charge a {$29.00} late fee. THIS IS FRAUD! When I call in and hear the recording about my account it states that the payment was received on XX/XX/year>. ( I have this recorded ) THIS IS FRAUD! This XXXX stated that my case is under review but eluded to the fact that percentage rates are set and that they may decrease under promotions but he eluded to he didnt know if it would. I mentioned that if I filed bankruptcy his organization would not receive a dime as this is unsecured credit. I discussed how this organization lowered my credit limit when I previously mentioned bankruptcy making my credit utilization extremely high again and I would bet that they will do it again. They play this bait and switch, luring consumers in with low introductory interests and high credit limit betting on the consumer will forget or an adverse event in life happens ( such as in my case ) causing the consumer not to be able to pay off the balance and then watch interest fees jump from {$38.00} to {$300.00} a month. This is wrong and predatory lending ( loan sharks or in Barclays case XXXX just like they have been doing since the XXXX and it must stop. THIS CORPORATE GREED must be reigned in. THE CFPB must not allow such companies to get away with this immoral, unethical behavior. The fact that the company is charging a late fee on the actual DUE DATE is WRONG! HOW MANY other consumers have they done this to? They defamed my character by stating that I was late and sending out emails stating this fact. If they reduce my credit limit thus increasing my credit utilization then my credit score will be negatively affected, thus lowering my chances of getting a personal loan at a lower interest rate to pay off these thieves keeping me in-slaved to this evil corporation. The audacity and arrogance of BARCLAYS attitude towards humanity is insane and the fact that they think they are untouchable is wrong. Its time to hold Barclays accountable for their corporate greed and illegal and deceptive business practices!
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer alleges Barclays Bank recorded a phone call without permission, violating Texas state and federal wiretapping laws. They also claim the bank charged a $29 late fee by misdating a payment, and engaged in predatory lending practices with high interest rates and reduced credit limits.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
I purchased an automated kitty litter, which was faulty and immediately proceeded to return this item. XXXX gave me a choice, refund my original credit card purchase and credit my Discover card, or they offered to provide me an XXXX e-gift card, which would be a faster, almost immediate refund to my XXXX account. I chose the latter. 
I returned the item on XX/XX/XXXX or XXXX, and almost XXXX weeks had gone by and I had received no e-gift card from XXXX. As such, I advised XXXX I was going to dispute the charge with Discover and Discover provided a temporary credit pending their " investigation. '' Discover performed an " investigation '' which was reduced to asking XXXX what they had done about my refund. XXXX told Discover that they had provided an e-gift card, but they FAILED to tell Discover that they took the e-gift card back and provided me a XXXX ( XXXX ) REFUND, because XXXX was told Discover had provided a refund. So, BOTH DISCOVER AND XXXX LEFT ME WITHOUT A REFUND. 

I provided evidence to Discover that XXXX did not provide an XXXX card, or rather, they took back their XXXX certificate once they learned Discover had provided a refund. Now, as stated, neither Discover nor XXXX have provided my credit for {$380.00}. I uploaded evidence that XXXX took the e-gift card balance back and to this date, NEITHER DISCOVER NOR XXXX HAVE CREDITED MY ACCOUNT. 

I demand that Discover credit my account accordingly as I have returned the item for {$380.00} for XXXX month ago now, and to this day, they have FAILED to credit my Discover account, and neither has XXXX provided an e-gift card for {$380.00} for the returned item. 

This is clear evidence of a multibillion-dollar company, or XXXX, which do NOT listen to their customer, fail to perform a proper investigation, simply take the word of a behemoth, multibillion dollar company against that of their customer, and leave the customer against a rock and a hard place, with NO refund to date, for an item returned XXXX month ago. 

I WANT MY {$380.00}!
Narrative Summary: A consumer purchased a faulty automated kitty litter and returned it. They chose an e-gift card refund option but never received it. Discover provided a temporary credit, but both Discover and the company claimed the other had issued a refund, leaving the consumer without the $380 refund.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Credit card company won't increase or decrease your credit limit
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have 3 credit cards with Citi bank. Cosco/AAdvantage/XXXX I have NEVER had a late payment and have always paid at least the minimum plus. My husband died in XXXX, and my income decreased. I had to use my credit cards. I did not use all of my credit limit, but my balances did go up significantly in a short time period. 

On XX/XX/XXXX my credit limit was reduced on ALL 3 of my cards, to just over what I owed. This significantly increased my credit usage, resulting in a major drop in my credit score. Now today, XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email informing me that my credit limit was being decreased again due to my credit score. Citibank, dropped my credit limit, which caused my credit score to go down, then dropped my credit limit again due to my score going down. I believe this is wrong and if not illegal, it is definitely poor business practices. I have credit cards from several banks and they have not ever decreased my credit limit, even after my score dropping. I have NEVER missed or had a late payment!!!! 

I pay my bills on time, as my credit reports show 100 % on time payments. 

I have recently received more income. I am trying to pay down all of my credit cards, to improve my usage percentage. Now, my usage will again go back up, resulting in another lowering of my credit score, which will then cause another decrease in credit limit. This is a vicious circle and is an incredibly cruel practice. 

I called customer service today to dispute this and was told that I could NOT dispute this decision. I can not even call the department that makes these decisions, so they obviously know what they are doing is wrong. 

They are making it impossible to dig out of a financial hole. 

Once again, this is the ONLY company that has done this. I have XXXX XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, etc. No problems with these companies.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Citi Bank reduced the credit limits on three cards to just above the owed balance, significantly increasing credit utilization and lowering the consumer's credit score. A subsequent limit decrease was made due to the lower credit score, creating a "vicious circle" despite the consumer's on-time payment history.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Advertising and marketing, including promotional offers
Sub-issue: Didn't receive advertised or promotional terms
Consumer complaint narrative: I had an agreement with avant to make a payment of {$40.00} by the due date and to make a payment of the full balance In order for the account to remain open. However, Once the payment for the full balance was received by Avant on XX/XX/year> for {$760.00}, rather than abide by the agreement, avant closed the account on XX/XX/year>, which was the opposite of what was agreed on and after Avant assured me that the account would remain open and that I would be able to use the card once the available balance updated within 10 days after the payment was received. I have contacted Avant multiple times concerning this issue, and Avant has stated that the concern has been escalated, however, the issue remains unresolved.
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims Avant closed their account despite an agreement to keep it open after a full balance payment of $760. Avant had assured the account would remain open, but instead closed it, and the issue remains unresolved despite multiple contact attempts.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Other problem
Consumer complaint narrative: From XXXX XXXX, 2024 to XXXX XXXX, 2024 I rented a car from XXXX XXXX. The initial cost was {$540.00} which included {$200.00} deposit for XXXX XXXX, 2024 to XXXX XXXX, 2024. I extended the car rental at weekly rates from XXXX XXXX, 2024 to XXXX XXXX, 2024. Each extension required a pending charge on my American Express card ( see image XXXX for example ) at the point of extension. This meant that the available balance on my Amex account included these pending charges. Thus at the end of the rental, I was not expecting another charge on my credit card for the full amount of the car rental for the month for {$940.00}. On XX/XX/XXXX, I rented a car from a different company, XXXX which authorized a weekly rate and deposit of {$300.00} for a total of {$640.00} on the same Amex account. However that charge isnt posted on my account as pending despite it being XXXX days since that transaction occurred. There was enough funds ( {$770.00} which should have reflected the pending charges for the XXXX car rental from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX plus {$130.00} pending charge for returning it on XX/XX/XXXX ) in my account to cover the XXXX transaction on XX/XX/XXXX, however my current available balance is XXXX. Its been very difficult to get a true account of my balance and spending limit. The major purchases on my card are for the car rentals. Its concerning that the business practices of charging pending transactions that fall off before the full payment has been ongoing for the over the past XXXX years. This practice makes it difficult to accurately calculate the balance on my credit card account and how much of my monthly payments in addition to biweekly payments are going towards keeping the balances manageable. Ive sent complaints about similar issues to Amex in the past and it continues.
Narrative Summary: A consumer rented a car from XXXX XXXX, extending the rental at weekly rates with pending charges on their Amex card. However, a final charge of $940 for the full rental period was made, despite the pending charges, causing account balance confusion and difficulties in tracking spending.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Card was charged for something you did not purchase with the card
Consumer complaint narrative:
STILL NO ANSWER!! Amazon Synchrony has no fraud protection in place. This virtual card was used without my consent and I was not informed for months until they sent a paper statement. They removed one bad charge but refused to remove the other. For 2 years they continue to add fees and interest onto this frauduent charge. The issue is, they let a virtual card be used without a 2 step authentication, and without having a user input a 3 digit security code that would be on the back of a credit card. I have been asking for over a month via email ( to " OfficeofthePresident ( Synchrony Financial ) '' XXXX, and XXXX, ) To give me a reply on at what point does their company do a " charge off ''? Their customer service department mentioned this to me but did not have the answer. I want to know when they will Charge Off the balance they made on my account? And also, when can I expect this to be fixed? 

Once again, I want to know when they will Charge Off the balance they made on my account? And also, when can I expect this to be fixed?
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A consumer's Amazon Synchrony virtual card was used without consent, resulting in unauthorized charges. Despite removing one charge, the company refused to remove the other, adding fees and interest for 2 years. The issue stems from the lack of 2-step authentication and 3-digit security code verification.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
Two Dispute issues : 1. I ordered a book from a book retailer called XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  ). The XXXX XXXX *cancelled* the book and ALL ORDERS from book retailers were ALSO cancelled. I provided a statement from XXXX XXXX XXXX  that was available to the public stating that all orders were cancelled. I also provided an e-mail from a 2nd book retailer supporting my point that when the PUBLISHER cancels all orders the RETAILERS *must* follow suit ( they cancelled a separate order I put in ). However, ONE YEAR LATER, the publisher RE-SOLICITED the same book. Every other retailer had to take and enter NEW orders for this solicitation. But THIS one book retailer took it upon themselves to use my previously-but-now-cancelled charge approval and went ahead and applied to a NEW charge on the NEW solicitation of the book. The bookseller charged me and sent the book... even tho " the charge was meant to ONLY be applied to a now-cancelled product. I tried to return it ; the retailer wouldn't accept it ( the book was unopened, as was the box it came in ). Discover Card sided w/the book seller, even though I sent demonstrable proof that my approval can not and should not have been applied to a wholly new order, no matter that it was for the same item at the same price. Simply put, I gave NO approval for this charge, only for the PREVIOUSLY ( cancelled ) charge. 
********* XXXX. My web hosting company, a group called XXXX, was hosting my websites for several years. Recently, I cancelled all of the hosting. There was a {$21.00} charge put on my Discover card in advance of the renewal ( a standard practice at web hosts so that users like me don't have an interruption in service ). I contacted XXXX XXXX customer service and asked them to reverse the " in advance '' charge b/c I wasn't certain I'd be renewing my services with them. They said " No problem '' and told me the charge was reversed. When I check my card activity, I see that XXXX XXXX only credited me {$11.00}. I disputed the remaining {$10.00} with Discover and also contacted XXXX XXXX about this. XXXX XXXX told me it was surcharge for the last-minute change of mind, but I explained that their own cancel rules indicate I cancelled early enough to not be taxed w/the {$10.00} charge. They agreed to look into it further and, a few weeks later, refunded me the {$10.00}. SEVERAL weeks after that, Discover Card went ahead and randomly ADDED THE FULL {$21.00} back to my balance! There's NO reason for that -- Blue Host refunded me. But, in spite of the evidence again, Discover card sided w/the retailer, in spite of their being NO charge to side with them on. 
********* This CLEARLY indicates a pattern of behavior at Discover Card where Discover is purposefully siding with retailers to ensure they get to keep whatever percentage of these charges that they make THEIR money from. They stealing from consumers, and I will be you they have been doing this FOR YEARS and that there are XXXX of Discover Card consumers whose Disputes were ILLEGALLY found in favor of the store and NOT the consumer JUST SO Discover can be sure to keep that small percentage of money which, of course, piles up to hundreds of thousands if not millions of dollars a year! 
XXXX  I would like to formally request that the CFPB not just research MY disputes but investigate the Discover Card company for FRAUD. I am 100 % certain you will find XXXX of cases of this fraud on the part of Discover Card over the last WHO KNOWS how many years. 
XXXX  Another, separate, example of Discover Card fraud : I put my credit card on " frozen '' status after a number of the errors so that I didn't use it any longer, but I left it as frozen ( as opposed to cancelling it ) just in case there was an autopayment that I missed. Well, while at the website eBay, I apparently accidentally chose the Discover card for 2 recent payments. Now, when the card is " Frozen '' ONLY autopayments ( like phone bill or gas, etc. ) are supposed to post ; everything else is supposed to be rejected, so this is another fraud being perpetrated by them. 
XXXX Now, I did make those purchases and accidentally choosing the Discover card is MY fault, but the fact that my card was " XXXX '' and the charges went through? That's a HUGE red flag ... and supports my point that Discover does NOT want to protects its customers but rather wants to wring as much money as possible out of its credit card users. Once more, I implore your organization to do a full, deep, and VERY detailed investigation. There is no doubt something rotten here! 
XXXX  Thank you.
Narrative Summary:
The consumer complains of two issues with Discover Card: 
1. Unauthorized charge from a book retailer who reapplied a cancelled charge to a new order, with Discover siding with the retailer despite proof of no approval for the new charge. 
2. A web hosting company's charge was partially refunded, but Discover later re-added the full amount despite the refund, again siding with the retailer.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Other problem
Consumer complaint narrative:
I wanted to sign into my Capital One account to apply for a savings/checking account and regain access to my Quicksilver card. When I called customer service, they said they could send a verification code to my new number to process the number change. This option did not work, so they asked me to send a copy of my drivers license using a link they emailed me. 

I did as requested, but the request was denied because the images were blurry. The second time, they asked me to resend the picture of my drivers license along with a screenshot of the reference number. I complied again, and it was denied once more. 

I called a third time about this issue, expressing my frustration as a customer. They then asked me to resend my drivers license along with a copy of the reference number and a written log of my address. Today, the claim was denied yet again. However, I applied for a new Capital One card using the same images requested to change my phone number and was approved. 

They could not explain how my identity was verified for a new Capital One card application, yet still couldn't be verified for changing the phone number on my account, to sign in.
Narrative Summary: A Capital One customer attempted to change their phone number to access their account, but was repeatedly denied after submitting required identification documents, despite using the same documents to successfully apply for a new Capital One card.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Can't use card to make purchases
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I attempted to use my AMEX on an international purchase for reservations abroad for roughly $ XXXX. My balance at the time was paid in full in prior months and I had an outstanding balance of around $ XXXX from prior usage. 

This card was tied to a transferred account from my mother, who passed away in XXXX XXXX ( see attached death certificate ). The timing of the transfer occurred in XXXX timeframe as her estate was being settled. 

Upon attempting to make my reservations online, I received an on-line " XXXX XXXX '' notice requesting a verification code for input. However, the verification code was being sent to my deceased mother 's old cell phone. I called Amex to inform them of their error, they acknowledged that they had all of my personal information, including my current cell phone, but security purposes, could only send the verification code to my deceased mother 's old cell phone number. And, they would continue doing this for 90 days following the date of transfer " for security purposes. '' At no time did Amex disclose to me that as a condition of accepting the transfer of my mother 's account and that I would need to also carry her cell phone for 90 days in order to fulfill a XXXX XXXX verification process. 

Additionally, at the time of attempting the transaction, I was on the phone with their customer service representative, who was able to validate my identity in real-time and directly. And, could see that I was trying to make the transaction. I had all of the requisite personal information and credit capacity under the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX to make a transaction, yet AMEX was unable to fulfill on their promise. 

As a result of inadequate operational/security controls, the card is rendered at best unreliable ( when would XXXX XXXX be triggered vs. not triggered since I used the card at other times ) and in this particular case, unusable. And, as a result of inadequate notice, a credit-worthy customer with track-record of timely repayment ( I had just repaid @ $ XXXX the day prior ) was unable to access credit. 

In the context of this situation, Amex 's " security '' process requires a deceased individual 's cell phone service to remain active with additional costs to the estate to be incurred. And finally, the process is painful for the new accountholder, as it would require the new accountholder to carry around their deceased mother 's cell phone on the off-chance they may need it to authenticate a future credit card transaction. This is absurd.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's AMEX card, transferred from their deceased mother's account, required a verification code sent to the mother's old cell phone number for security purposes, despite the consumer having provided their own cell phone number and having a verified identity.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Company closed your account
Consumer complaint narrative:
Account ending in XXXX Dear Sir/Madam, I hope this letter finds you well. I am writing to discuss a closed/charged-off account in the amount of {$2400.00} associated with my name and the above account number. After a recent review of my financial situation and credit report, I am seeking a resolution that would benefit both parties. 

I am proposing to settle the account for full satisfaction for the claim in the amount of {$250.00}. In exchange for this payment, I respectfully request that Capital One agrees to remove this account from my credit report. I believe this resolution would provide a fair and mutually beneficial solution, allowing me to take a positive step towards rebuilding my credit and financial stability while ensuring Capital One recovers a portion of the owed amount without further collection efforts. 

If you agree to this settlement offer, please arrange for an online payment invoice to be sent to me, or provide instructions on mailing a check to the address you prefer.
Narrative Summary: A consumer is seeking to settle a closed/charged-off Capital One account of $2400 for $250. In exchange, they request the account be removed from their credit report, allowing them to rebuild their credit while Capital One recovers a portion of the debt.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
This is regarding American Express chargeback dispute XXXX and I already provided American Express with the return tracking which shows the merchant signed for the return and received it. 

I am not sure if American Express chargeback team is being incompetent here or just XXXX against me because I am XXXX and this XXXX and I am disputing with is run by XXXX males. The issue is that I RETURNED the damaged product I received. First off I shouldnt have to pay for a product that arrived damaged. Second off I RETURNED it right back to the merchants address. The merchant have me many options to return including dropping it off at one of their satellite / other local stores etc. I paid for my own return shipping and had it returned to the merchants store address and XXXX tracking shows it was signed for by the store itself so there is NO dispute the store has it back. The store has lost the return since its been almost a month since it was delivered to them returned to them. I am owed my full money back for this order. 

This is regarding American Express chargeback dispute XXXX and I already provided American Express with the return tracking which shows the merchant signed for the return and received it. I also provided the return label which shows the merchant address was where it was shipped back to. I am owed my full money back for this return of the damaged product.

Despite providing return tracking and label, the consumer hasn't received a full refund, and the merchant allegedly lost the return after receiving it.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
ISSUE : While I was never enrolled in autopay and just paid off my card in full through a manual payment, Ally Credit Card without any of my knowledge and authorization tried to debit my bank account for more money and after the payment wasn't honored, they placed my card on hold claiming that my bank account was frozen and demanding to open a new bank account to make my payments. 

I am writing to dispute an unauthorized automatic payment of {$56.00} to my debit card account on XX/XX/XXXX by Ally Credit Card. 
The charge is in error because : 1. I never enrolled in autopay and Ally Credit Card doesn't have my authorization to debit my bank account 2. The amount of the payment is also wrong. My due amount was {$0.00} at the time. On XX/XX/XXXX ( a week before my due date ), I paid the entire current balance of {$270.00} ( while my statement balance was {$170.00} ) This brings any " Remaining statement balance '' down to {$0.00}, and on my due date on the XXXX, I owed nothing. 

EXPLANATION OF WHAT HAPPENED I have had an Ally Credit Card since XX/XX/XXXX, with a line of credit of {$300.00}, and a due day on the XXXX of each month. 
I have never set up an autopay. I make manual payments, always paying off my card in full shortly before the due date. 
This XXXX I also paid earlier and in full ( the current balance ). On XX/XX/XXXX I made a payment of {$270.00} ( which was processed as usual and by the XXXX I was using my card again ) However, after XX/XX/XXXX my card unexpectedly declined and my account showed that it was placed on hold. By checking my recent transactions Ive learned that on XX/XX/XXXX Ally tried to debit my bank account for some additional payment in the amount of {$56.00}. But since I never authorized an autopay, the payment wasn't honored and showed as returned. Upon which Ally concluded that my bank account was frozen and placed my card on hold. 

Too, Ally never sent any prior notice about the upcoming payment or the ballance due, and my account app never showed any ballance due either. It was comletely out of blue and came as a shock. 

I contacted XXXX Customer Service numerous times but they wouldn't do anything about it. They instantly dismissed any possibility of the error on their end, and bluntly insisted that the information in my account was correct. They were completely ignorant of what I was saying, solely relying on the info in my account kept telling me that I failed to make this payment for {$56.00} that it didn't get through because my bank account was frozen (! ) and that I need a different bank account to pay the balance or my card will remain on hold. I spoke with XXXX different Customer Service representatives, including the Customer Service Supervisor ( who was especially arrogant ) before giving up on trying to resolve this issue over the phone. After that I tried to dispute this in written but it was impossible. Ally Credit Card doesn't provide their email address and their link for a secure message within the app doesn't work. Otherwise, they don't offer any other form of communication ( except for some general mailing address ) and there's no way to dispute anything other than writing elsewhere.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Ally Credit Card attempted to debit the complainant's bank account for $56 without authorization, as they had already paid their balance in full. The payment was declined, and Ally placed the card on hold, claiming the bank account was frozen.

Sub-issue: Problem with fees
Consumer complaint narrative: In early XXXX I made a payment 3 times the amount of my amount due to payoff my account early. My payment applied just to principal and when I asked for a payment reallocation they told me they couldn't do that. Since I thought I was paid up for XXXX I then received a late fee. I asked for a payment reallocation and was told no and now they also charged me a late fee. So instead of owing {$7.00} total on my account I owe {$37.00}.
Narrative Summary: A consumer made a triple payment to pay off their account early, but it was applied only to the principal. They requested a reallocation to cover interest and fees, but were denied, resulting in a late fee and an increased balance from $7 to $37.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Problem with fees
Consumer complaint narrative:
Hello, I took a XXXX XXXX  of {$3300.00} on XX/XX/year> to deal with a temporary liquidity situation and repaid it in FULL on XX/XX/year>. 
On XX/XX/year> I saw a XXXX XXXX Fee of {$160.00} even though the website only talks of 27.24 % APR rate. 
I was shocked at this rate as this implies a Simple Interest Rate of 1825 % p.a When I spoke to the customer agent, I was told that they could not reverse the charge as it was a standard fee of 5 % for any cash advance. 
I find this rate/ fees eggregious and therefore resorting to a complaint with CFPB. 

On a different note, their website makes it extremely difficult to lodge complaints and requires us to call to dispute any charges. 

I hope my complaints can be addressed. 

Thanks XXXX
Narrative Summary: A consumer took a cash advance of $3,300 and repaid it in full, but was charged a $160 fee, implying a 1,825% simple interest rate. The company cited a standard 5% cash advance fee, which the consumer finds egregious and is disputing with the CFPB.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Card was charged for something you did not purchase with the card
Consumer complaint narrative:
WellsFargo Bank sent a card on XX/XX/year> as a replacement to the existing card that was set to expire in XX/XX/year>. This new/replacement credit card never arrived in my mailbox. On XX/XX/XXXX, I noticed multiple transactions on my card that happened between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX. I immediately called the bank and informed that credit card has fraudulent transactions of purchases, online payments and cash withdrawals. None of these transactions are done by me. Bank agent did acknowledge that card is compromised and logged the case for further investigation. We were told that we will hear back in XXXX  days. On XX/XX/XXXX, Bank sent a letter saying that transactions are valid and closed the case. 
We called the fraud claim department and got the case reopened and provided bank with Police case number that we got registered. Also, we did inform bank that lately there had been mail theft issue in and around the community. After the XXXX round of investigation, bank again sent a letter to us informing that transactions are valid, and asked us to pay {$14000.00}. On XX/XX/XXXX, again called the bank XXXX department and requested to reopen the case. While going over the case with us, the agent confirmed that all transactions are done by the card that we never got. It is a clear case of theft and forgery. Bank asked us to provide additional information as evidence such as Mobile/Telephone bill showing our location ( this we provided along with other evidence too. All of this is attached here as well. ) XXXX XXXX concern is that a ) WHO/how the replacement card got stolen b ) How was the card activated? c ) WHY bank did not have any alert mechanism activated and allowed multiple huge transactions in XXXX weeks ( my purchase pattern had been only few XXXX dollars each month for last many years since I had the card ). d ) When we never got the card, why bank is making us liable to pay. Bank can easily verify the card that was used for transactions with its expiration date and other details. It can also identify the location, mechanism and other details that was used to activate the card. The transaction on card is done across the country where as I have been at my home throughout the duration when theft happened. ( I have attached mobile bills as evidence. I have attached multiple other evidence as well ) BANK is NOT doing its due diligence to identify theft and ASKING me to pay this huge amount for no fault of mine. I have been a customer with Wells Fargo bank for last XXXX years and have been using its credit card for last multiple years.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A Wells Fargo customer received a replacement credit card that never arrived. Multiple unauthorized transactions occurred, but the bank initially ruled them valid. After multiple investigations and evidence provided, the bank still holds the customer liable for $14,000, despite acknowledging the card was never received.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Credit card company won't increase or decrease your credit limit
Consumer complaint narrative: In early XXXX of 2024 I accepted a promotional offer from Citibank to open an account and receive XXXX bonus miles with XXXX XXXX, after spending {$3500.00} on purchases by XX/XX/year>. They gave me a {$1500.00} credit limit, which barely gives me enough time to spend {$3500.00} by XX/XX/XXXX. I requested a credit limit increase and they declined. My first statement closed on XX/XX/XXXX and I paid it in full on XX/XX/XXXX, so I could start charging purchases to the card again towards the {$3500.00} requirement. For some reason my available balance is still only {$40.00}, even though I paid it in full 2 days ago, and the money has already cleared my bank. I called Citibank today to ask them what is going on. They told me there is a hold on my payment until XX/XX/XXXX, which is absurd! I have never had a credit card company do this before! Now I have only between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX to spend another {$1500.00}, to stay on track for the {$3500.00} requirement. It really does look like Citi is trying to limit my spending so I don't qualify for the bonus miles offer. I have excellent credit, and I have never had a credit card offer me less than {$10000.00} limit. I have several expenses coming up, which I won't be able to put on this card because the limit is so low. I have to plan strategically which expenses can go on this card, so nothing gets declined. I want Citi to release my balance immediately, so I can start using the card again. I also want them to increase my credit limit to at least {$3000.00}, so I can charge my upcoming travel expenses to the card and make sure I qualify for the bonus miles.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A Citibank customer claims the bank is hindering their ability to meet a promotional offer's spending requirement. After paying their first statement in full, a hold was placed on the payment, limiting their available balance and making it difficult to spend the required $3500 by the deadline.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Company closed your account
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Complaint Against Discover Card for Unfair Account Closure and Negative Credit Reporting Dear Sir/Madam , I am writing to file a formal complaint against Discover Card regarding their handling of my credit card account, which I believe constitutes unfair and potentially illegal practices. 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I received an email from Discover Card stating, " We have taken this action because we were unable to verify personal information on your account. We will report to the credit bureaus that the account was closed by creditor, and credit your account with your card rewards balance if you have one. '' This action was taken without prior notice or any attempt to contact me for verification of my identity. 

Here are the specific issues I have encountered : Lack of Prior Notification and Verification Request : At no point did Discover Card communicate with me to request any form of identification or verification of personal information. I opened this account on XX/XX/XXXX, and have been making timely payments on this account for several months, indicating my active and responsible management of the account. 

Unwarranted Account Closure : Discover Card closed my account on the grounds of unverifiable personal information without providing an opportunity for me to address or correct the issue. This closure was abrupt and unjustified given my payment history and consistent account activity. 

Negative Impact on Credit Report : Despite claiming an inability to verify my personal information, Discover Card has reported the account closure to credit bureaus, indicating that the account was closed by the creditor. This action negatively impacts my credit score and overall credit history, which is particularly troubling since I have not been delinquent or irresponsible with my payments. 

Extenuating Circumstances : In XX/XX/XXXX, I was hospitalized with XXXX for 10 days and spent months recovering from related health issues. I have documentation to verify this if needed. Additionally, I had to return to the emergency room on XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX, due to complications from my illness. Due to my hospitalization and recovery, I missed the XXXX payment. Upon resuming my financial activities, I discovered that Discover Card had closed my account. 

It is perplexing and concerning that Discover Card can claim they are unable to verify my personal information while simultaneously having enough information to report to the credit bureaus. Furthermore, at no time did Discover Card reach out to me to request any form of identification or verification to resolve this issue. 

Given the above points, I believe Discover Card 's actions are not only unfair but potentially in violation of consumer protection laws. As a responsible consumer, I should have been afforded the opportunity to verify my information before any adverse action was taken against my account. Additionally, if they were truly unable to verify my personal information, it raises the question of how they could report accurately to credit bureaus.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's Discover Card account was closed due to unverifiable personal information without prior notice or verification requests. The closure was reported to credit bureaus, negatively impacting their credit score, despite a history of timely payments and no delinquency.

I also got an email from the bank for my virtual card, so I can use it immediately. But I can't open the link with the computer and cellphone with different browsers. I didn't get the card until XX/XX/XXXX. So I have way less time to use the card. Now I find I am only {$250.00} dollars to reach the bonus. If I can open the link for the virtual card or if I can receive the card earlier, I will definitely get the open account bonus.
Narrative Summary: The consumer applied for an American Express business gold card with a welcome bonus. However, they couldn't access the virtual card link and the physical card was delayed, reducing the time to meet the spending requirement, resulting in a shortfall of $250 to earn the bonus.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Problem during payment process
Consumer complaint narrative:
I do not have a XXXX XXXX account. I paid my first credit card statement via a global money transfer. My second payment I attempted to do the same thing. I sent that XX/XX/XXXX and informed AMEX of the send. They said it would take 5-7 business days to show. On XX/XX/XXXX payment had not been applied and I had to recall it. I then contacted AMEX and was told as of XX/XX/XXXX they no longer accepted global wire transfers as payment. I was told to reach out to a friend or family member with a XXXX XXXX account and have them pay. This felt odd but I wanted to pay the bill. My daughter has a XXXX XXXX account but her bank wouldnt add AMEX as a payee because her name is not on the account. I contacted AMEX again and they told me to link her bank account with my AMEX account. I was deeply uncomfortable with this but was told they could do it so I could make a payment. I only paid the minimum amount because this just felt wrong. I even asked AMEX if this was really the only way and legal. AMEX manually entered my daughters banking information to my account and accepted payment. 
I have more money owing but am very concerned as to how to pay this. This situation has red flags all over it. I got back on with AMEX chat to figure out how I am going to pay the balance since I can no longer make a payment via my account. They said my daughter can pay but then she has to provide all her banking info again and she doesnt even have an account and is not on my account. I am just trying to pay this bill. Please help.
Narrative Summary: The consumer is having trouble paying their American Express credit card bill due to a change in payment policy. AMEX stopped accepting global wire transfers, and the consumer was advised to link a family member's bank account to their AMEX account to make a payment, raising concerns about security and legitimacy.

I spoke with some people from XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX and they said that they have no problems sending cards overnight. Yes It does cost mailing fees. 

Can they just produce one for XXXX XXXX as a damaged card then all of the cards are not effected. I have XXXX child out of state at XXXX who uses this card so we are not closing the misplaced card that is probably in the house.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative:
1 ) On XX/XX/year> I ordered a quantity of 5 giant skeleton decorations from XXXX in the amount of {$390.00}. Here is a link to the product and website. 
XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX 2 ) I did not receive the merchandise, so after several weeks of waiting I reached out to merchant to inquire about the status of my order and shipment.

3 ) I was informed that the items were delivered so I asked for tracking information since I did not receive the items. Based on the tracking information provided by the merchant, XXXX customer service, the items were delivered to an address in New York and not in XXXX XXXX, Texas. 

4 ) I asked that replacements be sent, but they told me now they are out of stock so I requested refund and was told a refund would be issued. 

5 ) After not receiving the refund and after the merchant stopped responded to my email inquiries about the refund, I disputed the charge with American Express. 

6 ) The merchant provided information to American Express including a new tracking number showing that item was delivered on XX/XX/year> to an address in XXXX XXXX, Texas but the delivery address did not get more detailed than just the City and State and did not indicate a street address. XXXX XXXX is a very large city and is part of the Greater XXXX area so a tracking number that just indicates the XXXX and State is meaningless and not helpful. Also, the merchant that submitted the documentation was not Geekfone.com but another company called BookishBunnyPillow.com and they submitted an invoice that showed different products than the skeletons. It was all very strange.

7 ) When I looked up this tracking number, the status on USPS showed that a label was created and nothing was shipped yet.

8 ) I submitted this information to American Express but the credit card company still sided with the merchant.

9 ) I called USPS and they informed me I could purchase additional historical archived information that was more detailed on that tracking number and so I did that. This was an additional charge of {$9.00} to receive this archived information.

10 ) Archived information showed that indeed some type of package was delivered to an address in XXXX XXXX, but that address was not my address, it was another address in XXXX XXXX, Texas. 

11 ) I submitted this to American Express to review the dispute again, but they again sided with the merchant stating that they can only rely on the information provided by the merchant and try to come to an amicable resolution and could not give me a refund. They said it was not their place to determine if the charge was valid or not since the merchant sent them documentation even though the documentation showed that the products were not delivered to my address.

12 ) I decided to XXXX XXXX and XXXX and found dozens of negative reviews from consumers expressing that this website was a fraud and they received either no products after purchase or deceptively marketed products and not what they expected. 

13 ) I called American Express to complain about this issue as they state that they offer 100 % fraud protection and this is indeed fraud in my mind. They said they could not refund me, but could offer me {$500.00} in credit if I agreed to stay an American Express customer for another year. I told them after 17 years as an American Express customer I no longer wanted to do business with them and was declining the offer but would keep my account open until XXXX when my {$690.00} per year membership expired and I was able to use all of my membership points that had been accrued. Last year I spent an estimated {$250000.00} on this credit card so was very taken aback by the way they handled this. Or rather their lack of handling the situation and not siding with their customer.
Narrative Summary: A consumer ordered 5 giant skeleton decorations for $390 but never received them. The merchant claimed delivery to a different address in New York, then later provided a new tracking number showing delivery to the consumer's city in Texas, but without a specific street address.

The service/solution provided by XXXX XXXX, an accounting software, was not the product that was advertised on the XXXX XXXX website. An attempt to contact XXXX XXXX was unsuccessful as I was told they have a no refund policy on software ( even though they falsely advertised their this software ). 
A dispute was made with DISCOVER ( the card used for the XXXX XXXX transaction ) and initially tentatively " ruled '' in my favor. Apparently, and randomly checking the Discover website, the " ruling '' was reversed on XX/XX/24 ( no documentation found in secure inbox on Discover website or in the mail. XXXX, not even an email that the " ruling '' has changed. ) An affidavit was signed and provided to DISCOVER among other screenshots showing the product they advertised was just XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX being it does not do automated reconciliation built in with the fee paid above.

I did not do these charges. these are fraud on my account when my card was stolen. the charges have not been taken off my account and i have not received any letters about the fraud claim being approved or denied.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Card opened without my consent or knowledge
Consumer complaint narrative:
XX/XX/scrub>XX/XX/2024 - According to XXXX, a new credit account lent by Capital One was opened on my account. This account was opened fraudulently. 

XX/XX/scrub>XX/XX/2024 - The date XXXX XXXX provided over the phone for the opening of the fraudulent card. 

XX/XX/scrub>XX/XX/2024 - I received an alert in my XXXX Inbox that this card 's balance overextended its credit limit of {$2000.00} by {$3.00}. 

XX/XX/scrub>XX/XX/2024 - I received an alert in my XXXX Inbox that this card 's balance payments are overdue by 30 days. 

XX/XX/scrub>XX/XX/2024 - I'm alerted by my sister and my brother of similar fraudulent events occurring with their identities, they encourage me to investigate my own, and I discover all the information listed above. 
I attempted to call Capital One, who required the last four digits of the card for me to get anywhere with their caller system, which I did not have because, obviously, I'm not in possession of that card. 
I called XXXX, my bank, who could not help much as the fraudulent card was opened with Capital One, not with XXXX. 
I called XXXX, who could not help me outside normal business hours. 
I called XXXX XXXX, who provided me with the full 16-digit credit card number, confirmed the existence of the suspicious address on the account for me, and told me the card was opened on XX/XX/2024. 
I recalled Capital One, now that I had the full credit card number, where they filed the card as fraudulent for me, couldn't comment on the date the card was opened, confirmed that purchases were made in XXXX XXXX, Florida ( the location of the suspect address ), made list of my two suspected individuals, and directed me to this website. 
And now I'm here. : )
Narrative Summary: A consumer reported a fraudulent Capital One credit account opened in their name, with a $2000 credit limit and unauthorized transactions. They discovered the issue after receiving alerts about overextended credit and overdue payments, and after family members reported similar identity theft incidents.

I alerted FNBO on or about XXXX about filing a dispute about a charge from XXXX XXXX They were in breach of contract when providing personal training services. I notified the credit card company that I would like them to investigate and reverse the charge because I did not receive the agreed services. They took approximately three months to follow up, requesting information I had already sent them two months prior. 
I called on or about XXXX to follow up on the status. The agent could not provide any details or progress on the requested information. I have noticed that XXXX charged three additional charges for the same amount I am disputing. 

Seemingly, they have not prioritized this, and nearly XXXX months later, they are dragging their feet to decide on this complaint. I requested a call back from an investigator, but to this date, I have heard nothing.

It is my understanding that they have 90 days to make a decision, which has already passed. I would like them to clear my account of any charges from XXXX XXXX and credit the incurred interest charges that have resulted. I have never been late on payment to this company despite their inefficiencies.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Problem with balance transfer
Consumer complaint narrative:
To whom it may concern, The terms and conditions for my American Express XXXX XXXX XXXX account opened XX/XX/2024 with the promotion states " 0 % intro APR on balance transfers for the first 15 months of Card Membership from the date of account opening, based on your creditworthiness and other factors. '' I have XXXX cards including the XXXX XXXX XXXX card with American Express and they are all in good standing. I have never had a XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX before. On XX/XX/2024 I made a balance transfer, which fell in the 60 days promotion offer agreement. On XX/XX/2024 I was charged {$56.00} in Interests charges. This came as a surprise since the promotion dealsays 0 % intro APR for 15 months and I also received different explanations from AmEX representatives after inquiry on the interest charges. 
On XX/XX/2024, an AMEX rep told me I received the interest charges because the promotion was only for a lower interests rate on balance transfers. Which was never stated in the advertisement or the terms and conditions. When I reached out XX/XX/2024 I was told that I was not eligible for the promo because I am already an AMEX card holder ( GOLD and PLATINUM ). When I asked for documentation on the justification, the rep could not send it to me and told me where to find it. I was not able to locate the information that refutes the 0 % intro fee does not apply to card holders. The only information I could find is " You may not be eligible to receive the welcome offer, intro APRs, and intro plan fees if you have or have had this Card, the XXXX XXXX  Card, the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX American Express Card or previous versions of these Cards .... If you are not eligible for the welcome offer, intro APRs, and intro plan fees we will notify you prior to processing your application so you have the option to withdraw your application. '' I have never had the XXXX XXXX card or anything similar in the past and I never received a notification while submitting an application. I would not have submitted my application if I received notification of ineligibility. 
Ultimately, I am disappointed with AMEX for misleading its current and new customers. The advertisement is a blatant lie, and no one can give me a straight answer or provide documentation on why I am paying interest on a promotion deal stating 0 % interests on terms and conditions for customers that never had the American Express XXXX XXXX XXXX card.
Narrative Summary: A consumer opened an American Express account with a 0% intro APR promotion on balance transfers for 15 months. Despite being eligible, they were charged $56 in interest after a balance transfer within the promotion period. American Express representatives provided conflicting explanations, claiming the promotion didn't apply due to the consumer being an existing Amex cardholder, but couldn't provide supporting documentation.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card

Consumer complaint narrative: I have had numerous problems for the three years I have had these accounts and they are constantly harassing me and my son and make it very inconvenient to continue a business business relationship. I use my credit card that has a secured {$400.00} limit. I overpay my balance 3 to 5 times a month. And I use it for everything. I am constantly being blocked or fraud alerts are out on almost every time we use our cards. I spent over XXXX on my card this year and have been a loyal customer for over three years. But I have never been offered to upgrade and was ignored twice when I asked to raise my credit limit. Then I was told to overpay my amount due and it should let me raise the available credit. This worked and I used my card for a rental car which I have been in a rental car for the last five months from XXXX rental cars. They made a mistake on my last rental and now they won't fix the problem. I have been impacted on my credit report and denied credit because of this error for the last three months. I have. Proof of there error fromt he papers they sent me denied my claim and took the money back again. This is very stressful and just want the money I am due and will be satisfied.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A credit card holder reports being constantly blocked or flagged for fraud despite overpaying their balance 3-5 times a month. They claim a rental car company's error led to an incorrect charge, damaging their credit report and causing denied credit applications for three months.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Problem with balance transfer
Consumer complaint narrative:
I took advantage of a 12 month, 0 % interest, balance transfer offer with Capital One for my Quicksillver credit card on XX/XX/XXXX for {$9600.00}. I was charged an upfront fee of 3 % for {$280.00}. The following XX/XX/XXXX billing statement included this balance transfer and respective fee. In the top left corner of the bill, an 'Interest Saver Payment ' option was included below the payment due date and new balance total. It stated that if I 'Pay at least this amount to avoid interest on new purchases shown on your next statement. ' I proceeded to pay this interest saver payment each month through XX/XX/XXXX. On the XX/XX/XXXX billing statement, this " Interest Saver Payment '' option was removed from my billing statement with no upfront notice or warning. Now the only payment option given was " Minimum payment due '' for {$88.00}. I proceeded to pay this minimum payment for {$88.00} on XX/XX/XXXX. Come to the XX/XX/XXXX billing statement and I was in turn charged {$160.00} in new interest charges. When I called Capital One on XX/XX/XXXX, to inquire about what took place, the supervisor informed me that my 12 month 0 % interest balance transfer offer had expired and I would now be charged interest on the statement balance. I informed him that I was not made aware of the expiration date of this offer in writing and notified him about the removal of the " Interest Saver Payment '' option from my XXXX statement. I asked for the interest charges to be credited back to my account. He refused and said this is normal Capital One business practices of which I believe is fraudulently deceiving millions of consumers with this misleading information. I asked to speak to his supervisor and he said that was not possible as they are only accessible via email. I proceeded to file a complaint with Capital One about this negative experience. The Capital One case number is XXXX. 

I proceeded to pay my full statement balance on XX/XX/XXXX, for {$9000.00}. 

Fast forward to the XX/XX/XXXX billing statement and I was once again charged interest in the amount of {$130.00}. 

I called Capital One on XX/XX/XXXX, and inquired as to why I was continuing to be charged interest after paying my statement balance in full on XX/XX/XXXX. I once again informed the supervisor, XXXX ( Employee ID # XXXX ), that I was not made aware of the expiration date of the balance transfer offer in writing and notified him about the removal of the " Interest Saver Payment '' option from my XX/XX/XXXX billing statement. I asked for the interest charges to be credited back to my account. He refused and said this is normal Capital One business practices, of which I believe is fraudulently deceiving millions of consumers with this misleading information. I asked to speak to his supervisor and he said that was not possible as they are only accessible via email. I proceeded to file a complaint with Capital One about this negative experience. The Capital One case number is XXXX.
Narrative Summary: The consumer took advantage of a 12-month, 0% interest balance transfer offer with Capital One, but was not informed when the offer expired. The "Interest Saver Payment" option was removed from their bill without notice, leading to unexpected interest charges of $160 and $130.

Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Can't close your account
Consumer complaint narrative:
My XXXX had a Elan credit card. I am not sure why. she is elderly and is now in the XXXXXXXX XXXX and all her social security goes for her care. I was appointed her Power of Attorney back in 2022 and took over her financial affairs last year. I called Elan to have them close the account out. She has no balance, she has no income to pay and Elan charges a {$99.00} annual fee. My mom has always had excellent credit, I am guessing rarely used the card and I am not sure why she agreed to this or why their is an annual fee on a consumer card. 

The Company told me I needed to fax in her Power of Attorney with a request to close the account. I did that. in XXXX I received a letter stating Elan would need my personal social security number and date of birth to add me to the account. I spoke to my Attorney, there is no reason why I need to be added to the account. I am legally working on my Mom 's behalf. My request was clear. Please close the Account. My Mother has no ability to pay. 

The Company recently sent my Mom an invoice again for her {$99.00} annual fee. Its like you can't close the account because the Company won't be able to collect this fee each year from her. She is XXXX. And again in a XXXXXXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The complainant, a Power of Attorney for their elderly mother, is trying to close her Elan credit card account due to her lack of income and inability to pay the $99 annual fee. Despite submitting the required documents, Elan is requesting additional information and continues to bill the account.

Issue: Problem with a purchase shown on your statement
Sub-issue: Credit card company isn't resolving a dispute about a purchase on your statement
Consumer complaint narrative: Someone stole my credit information and proceeded to charge up my card to over the sum of XXXX XXXX And also used my account to set up pay it later is a monthly billing for products that you dont want to pay in total upfront. So she created several reoccurring charges on my account.

Issue: Problem with a company's investigation into an existing problem
Sub-issue: Was not notified of investigation status or results
Consumer complaint narrative: I've consistently ensured timely payments on this account, never letting them become overdue. I'm unsure why there are reports of late payment remarks on my accounts. According to 15 USC 1666b - Billing Error, this should be rectified.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
