Issue: Issue where my lender is my school
Sub-issue: Issues with fees connected to the loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by The XXXX XXXX, the XXXX XXXX has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. 
My XXXX loans in the amount of {$58000.00} are being XXXX and my credit repaired. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were XXXX " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. 
These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools '', but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. 
I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of the borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX for profit online schools. 
After the XXXX settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the XXXX student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? 
Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the XXXX student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX XXXX XXXX could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? 
Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a XXXX XXXX XXXX program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who XXXX have filed XXXX XXXX claims against their schools and were approved. 
This application is a sham. 
Why do we need to prove anything? 
Navient knows who we are. 
Under the XXXX " XXXX XXXX '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. 
XXXX is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's XXXX  asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!
Narrative Summary: The complainant claims Navient scammed thousands of students into taking out predatory private loans for online for-profit schools, including their own school, which was found to have acted fraudulently. The complainant's $58,000 loan is being discharged, but they argue Navient should discharge all such loans immediately.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by Navient into taking out predatory private loans to attend for profit online schools such as the one I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, XXXX XXXX XXXX was investigated by the Dept of Consumer Affairs.

Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX An Affiliate of XXXX XXXX ( who purchased XXXX XXXX XXXX in late XXXX ), and my Fed. loans of approx {$50000.00} were discharged and my credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX for which I was a full class member. 
I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit online schools ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for Navient, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for profit online schools. After the AG settlement, didn't Navient also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't Navient have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of IDR/IBR payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't Navient been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which Navient is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? Navient knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' Navient is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for Navient to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to Navient 's CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time Navient do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools.
Narrative Summary: The complaint alleges Navient scammed thousands of students into taking predatory private loans for online for-profit schools. The complainant's federal loans were discharged, but claims Navient's settlement with 39 state AGs excluded many affected borrowers, and demands Navient discharge all predatory private loans.

I have made consecutive payments toward my student loans since the mentioned date, but no payments have been posted ; hence, not acknowledge as being received by Mohela. I get emails, calls, and letters reminding me that my account is past due! 
Consecutive payments were made as follows and received by Mohela a few days later : XXXX - {$250.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$680.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$250.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$250.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$480.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$630.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$310.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared XXXX XXXX - {$310.00} XXXX. XXXX Cleared projected date XXXX. 

Mohela stated that there was a system update and assured me that my account would be updated, but it did not happen to this day. When payments are received from customers they should be posted on the day they were received ( per XXXX XXXX ) ; hence, legit accounting practices. I would have understood if the posting had been delayed for 30 days due to system updates, but five months is even for a governmental/federal entity too long! Please do not allow them to ruin credit standings, and integrity on the scheme of earning interest in their own ( Mohela 's ) bank accounts on payments received by student loan payees. Your help is appreciated and needed before credit scores are ruined by so many in the same situation as I. Very Respectfully, XXXX

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I started in XX/XX/year> with my SAVE plan request. Every 3 to 4 months I got an email that my request was missing information. I called and asked what was missing each time. I suspected it was because by the time my documents were reviewed the items were more than 90 days old. I was always told that was not the issue. 

Once I was told they didn't receive all of the documents even though I saw them in my account online where I had submitted them. After that I was told several different reasons my self certification letter of unemployment had too much information or too little information, however it aways had the information required per the instructions. Also, they had my layoff notice from the beginning. 

I get letters stating documents are missing but customer service can fins them. I have been told differing payment amounts, different plans I am enrolled in, and different instructions every time I call. There is no consistent answer. No one follows up and I start all over after every resubmission. 

After the last submission, I received a notice that my case was aged out and they closed it and my payments were restarting. It has been 3 or 4 months and I have XXXX idea how to resolve this. I also have to recertify in a few months and can only XXXXmagine how that will go.
Narrative Summary: A consumer's SAVE plan request, initiated over a year ago, has been delayed due to inconsistent and contradictory communication from the company. Despite submitting required documents, the consumer received multiple emails stating information was missing, with varying reasons and no resolution.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Regarding Predatory Lending Practices by Navient dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint against Navient, the loan servicer, regarding predatory lending practices associated with my private student loans. 
Despite the closure of XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX due to numerous violations, and the subsequent approval of borrower defense to repayment for my federal loans, Navient persists in aggressively pursuing repayment of my private loans obtained for the same institution. 
During my enrollment at XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was subjected to egregious instances of predatory behavior and misrepresentations by Navient. These practices included : Coercion and Duress : Navient representatives, acting on behalf of XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX coerced me into signing loan documents under duress, I was forcibly removed from class and escorted to the office of a financial aid representative who was working with Navient the servicer of these loans who went by the first name XXXX Upon arrival, I was presented with loan documents and threatened with severe consequences, including expulsion from class and eviction from the dormitory, if I did not sign the documents immediately. Given that I resided in the dormitory at the time and my permanent home was in XXXX, New York, I faced significant hardship and felt compelled to sign the documents to avoid potential homelessness. 
Lack of Transparency : Throughout my time at XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Navient failed to provide clear explanations of interest rates, loan structures, and repayment options, leaving me uninformed and vulnerable to financial exploitation.These predatory lending practices by Navient have had severe consequences for me and countless other borrowers. The closure of the institution and the subsequent approval of borrower defense to repayment for my federal loans underscore the severity of these violations that occurred
Narrative Summary: The complainant alleges Navient engaged in predatory lending practices for private student loans, including coercion and lack of transparency, while attending a now-closed institution. They claim Navient representatives forced them to sign loan documents under duress, threatening expulsion and eviction, and failed to explain loan terms.

I have applied to have them XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX. I haven't had any information or change since. I would appreciate some forward stance about the loans status of discharging. Thank you.

Despite paying from XXXX to XXXX, they filed for bankruptcy and haven't made payments since. They applied for loan discharge on XX/XX/XXXX but haven't received an update.

Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative: Today The Biden Administration decided to discharge loans for students " who enrolled at any XXXX XXXX campus on or after XXXX XXXX, XXXX, through XXXX XXXX, XXXX '' I enrolled XX/XX/XXXX ( at the start of the term ), and suffered the same predatory lending and manipulation from the XXXX XXXX. I deserve to have these loans discharged just as much as someone who enrolled 3 months later ( in the middle of a term ).

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I went to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and took out a Federal loan thinking this was the best for my education. Like all schools, I had an admission rep and he gave a great sales pitch and told me how wonderful the school is and how I would be GUARANTEED a job after graduating. The admissions rep was sure to talk up how it was a strong name in the industry, world renowned, had some of the best award winning faculty, and that they didnt have open enrollment in the past and they made us present a portfolio of images and write a short page-long essay as to why I should be accepted into the Institute, something I thought as very cool but also extremely intimidating. Later I realized I had never heard of anyone being denied who applied to the school. Seemed like everyone who applied to XXXX got in... isnt that open enrollment? We were also told several times that XXXX had a 90 % graduation rate, and graduates got help with job placement before they were even done with school to ensure the 100 % job placement.. He told me that most graduates were already working jobs they had been placed in prior to graduation, and on average are making {$100000.00} per year or so after school ( the median income of the photography field is {$24000.00} a year ) ... this was in XXXX. I was really into XXXX XXXX at the time and thought that maybe was a direction I wanted to head. He told me that XXXX would propel me into the career of my dreams. We were told that a number of XXXX graduates were working for XXXX XXXX, and that frequently XXXX XXXX and other highly accredited publications would come in and pick and choose people to hire from graduating classes.The admissions rep made it seem like XXXX really had it together and really helped its students obtain jobs and figure their lives out, and for me, thats really what I needed to hear. 
I worked the plan. I went to XXXX, I graduated but in XXXX when that happened I did not have a job in photography as promised, I however had debt and was surrounded by thousands of people who never went to school and now claim to be a photographer with a newly introduced " digital camera '' .I couldn't get a job as a photographer because now any regular XXXX can be a photographer and charge {$20.00} - I wasn't told to do this, we were taught how to invoice and invoice at a proper price limit. XXXX, I have to pay my student loans.Fast forward to XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Closes and I still have student debt for a now closed school.Fast forward to Sweets vs XXXX where I am a Full class member " Although the final implementation deadline for the Sweet v. XXXX settlement has now passed, many borrowers have not received student loan forgiveness and other relief that they are entitled to under the court-approved agreement. The XXXX Department has materially breached Paragraph IV. '' Something needs to be done about this. 
How is it that a XXXX has forced the hand to have my loans forgiven and still nothing is happening. Are we not rich enough, large enough for it to matter. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX Please help.
Narrative Summary: A student claims a school misrepresented its job placement and graduation rates, inducing them to take out a federal loan. The school allegedly promised 100% job placement and $100,000 average salaries, but the student graduated without a job and now faces debt for a school that has closed.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative: I accidentally overpaid one of the loans by few cents. Customer support said they will take care of the issue as i instructed them to transfer that overpaid amount to another loan. Not only nothing came out of that, after 3 months, i realized that my negative amount ( overpaid ) accrued interest. With how difficult and unhelpful their customer support is, i thought of paying the interest amount so i don't have to deal with them ( around {$37.00} ). The next day i realized that they adjusted the amount back and now I'm overpaid by around {$40.00} on two account. They are not helping me distribute my overpaid amount to other loans which in return is keeping those account open and it's negatively affecting my credit score. If a company can't handle a simple issue in over 3 months, not sure they could be trusted with anything.
Narrative Summary: A consumer overpaid a loan by a few cents and was told the excess would be transferred to another loan. However, the overpaid amount accrued interest, and despite attempts to resolve the issue, the company failed to distribute the excess funds, causing ongoing credit score damage.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Navient claims to be unaware of the discharge and that I owe them the remainder of the student loans. As the amount owing far exceeds the amount of tuition it would have been wiped out in bankruptcy. Amount currently owing is {$55000.00}, the cost of attending the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was {$35000.00}, I graduated in XXXX and made payments until declaring bankruptcy. The amount owed does not include federal loans also used To pay for attending which total {$12000.00}. Navient has ruined my credit score in reporting that I have not paid them. As the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX was one of many for profit schools listed in the Attorneys general lawsuit against Navient for defrauding students through predatory loans and they should have been discharged under bankruptcy and or the Holder rule.
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims Navient is unaware of their 2004 bankruptcy discharge and is demanding $55,000 in student loans, despite the original tuition being $35,000. The consumer argues the debt should have been wiped out in bankruptcy, especially given the school's involvement in a predatory loan lawsuit.

Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I attended XXXX  school at XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX in XXXX and attained an XXXX loan at a high-interest rate. The school has been closed since then, and the degree was not utilized as I couldn't make any money in the field. Since then I have made payments but the loan was still at $ XXXX with no dent. 7 months ago, the loan payment went up to {$600.00}, and I couldn't afford it, so I stopped paying. Navient has been contacting my coworkers and employer to determine work, embarrassing and humiliating me at my place of work. Now, they have started emailing my employer again. I live in NC, and I believe as they are a private lender, they can't get this information from my employer, nor can they sequester my paycheck. Please help!

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan

Navient never provided me with this information despite their awareness for several months. I have requested Navient send me a school misconduct application twice. XXXX weeks ago I learned I can not access this application on their site and that it will need to be sent to me. I have contacted Navient about this twice and still have not received the application. In addition, my monthly payment has since almost tripled and I am being told I do not qualify for reduced payments despite a consistent history of paying when the monthly payment was financially reasonable. I can not afford the new monthly payment and Navient will not put my loans in forbearance status pending the school misconduct application. Assistance and resolution from Navient has been attempted for the past XXXX weeks.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's complaint is against Navient for failing to inform them that their federal student loans could be discharged due to a court case. Navient also failed to provide a school misconduct application, and the consumer's monthly payment tripled, despite a history of timely payments.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: Since student loan repayments resumed in XXXX, I have had countless issues with MOHELA. So far, they have taken months to process my XXXX have not emailed out billing statements to me, have put me on XXXX without notifying me, and they have removed my XXXX choice and moved me to the XXXX plan. Currently, I am not listed as being on the XXXX and my account on their website has no information about the status of my account. The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX shows my account is in XXXX, but the MOHELA website does not state that, and I never received an email that my account would be on XXXX. My MOHELA account also tells me I have no bills due, but no other information. The XXXX website tells me my next bill isn't due until XX/XX/XXXX, but MOHELA has not given me any information about a pause on my account. I tried calling their phone number, and their directory does not work. It just repeats the message without allowing me to dial the corresponding number to be directed to the department I need to speak to. I also never received notification from MOHELA that they will not longer be handling the counting of XXXX payments.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer is experiencing issues with MOHELA, their student loan servicer, including delayed processing, lack of billing statements, and unexplained changes to their repayment plan. The consumer's online account lacks information, and they are unable to contact MOHELA due to a non-functional phone directory.

Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: Loans were purchased from XXXX. Thousands of students were scammed by XXXX into taking out predatory private loans to attend fXXXX XXXX XXXX  schools such as the one I attended, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, The XXXX XXXX and their Parent company, XXXX were investigated by the attorneys general of several states and have been found to have acted in a fraudulent manner. Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by The XXXX XXXX, the Biden administration has just announced a blanket discharge for anyone enrolled at XXXX XXXX XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX to XX/XX/XXXX. My Federal loans ( Distributed and Repaid amounts Attached in XXXX  ) XXXX and my credit repaired. I am aware that XXXX was sued by XXXX state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these XXXX XXXX  schools and that XXXX XXXX were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXX 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " XXXX XXXX schools, '' but loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for XXXX, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of the borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX schools. After the XXXX settlement, didn't XXXX also get out of the XXXX student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't XXXX have to pay restitution to the XXXX student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX XXXX students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't XXXX been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which XXXX is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed XXXX XXXX claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? XXXX knows who we are. Under the FTC " XXXX XXXX '' XXXX is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with XXXX XXXX  schools. Time is running out for XXXX to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. XXXX XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to XXXX 's CEO ( Attached ) asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time XXXX do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools NOW!
Narrative Summary: The complainant alleges that thousands of students, including themselves, were scammed into taking out predatory private loans from XXXX to attend for-profit schools that committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves. The complainant demands that XXXX discharge these loans due to their predatory nature.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: In an attempt to consolidate my loans, I used a private lender to pay off my student loans held by EdFinancial Services. On XXXXXXXX a payment of {$37000.00} was made to pay the total of 10 student loans. Rather than applying the payment among the 10 loans, they applied it to half the loans, which resulted in in overpayment of half those loans, while the other half remain unpaid. I then learned in XXXX that automatic payments were made in XXXX and XXXX, which is when I discovered this issue. I then cancelled the auto payments and called EdFinancial to request that the large payment was reallocated to pay off each of the loans and refund the additional payment that were made. I was told that this would be processed at that time. However, after not seeing any changes made, I called to check on the status, only to hear that it would take longer for the issue to be resolved. I have called 4 times since and they continue to tell me the same thing and that no timeframe on resolution could be provided, since those transactions are made by another department. When I requested to speak to a supervisor during my last call, they had said that a supervisor would call me back within 24 hours, which did not occur. Meanwhile interest is accruing on the unpaid loans and I continue to get notices of late and missed payments. It has been 6 months since I made the payment to pay off the loans and there is no indication that they intend to resolve this issue anytime soon.
Narrative Summary: A consumer made a $37,000 payment to EdFinancial Services to pay off 10 student loans. However, the lender applied the payment to only half the loans, resulting in overpayment on those and leaving the others unpaid. Despite multiple calls, EdFinancial has not resolved the issue or provided a timeline.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Need information about your loan balance or loan terms
Consumer complaint narrative: Hi, I made several payments on my XXXX XXXX Consolidated loans from XXXX. I was also in the XXXX XXXX XXXX plan. I reached out to both XXXX and Nelnet and requested my payment history. I was told from XXXX and Department of education to reach out to Nelnet since they were my previous server to obtain my payment history which payments were made through XXXX XXXX  which is now closed. Nelnet send a letter stating I had made no payments which was totally incorrect. Attached is proof of some of the payments that I made on my student loans being deducted out of my account. I uploaded these documents to Nelnet as well and they are still saying I didnt make any payments.
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims Nelnet incorrectly stated they made no payments on their consolidated student loans, despite providing proof of payments deducted from their account. They were directed to Nelnet by the Department of Education and XXXX for payment history, but Nelnet refuses to acknowledge the payments.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Before federal student loan repayments resumed post-covid, I applied for the SAVE program, and was accepted with a monthly payment of {$0.00} due to my financial circumstances and birth of my child ( dependent ). 

I have repeatedly been emailed about missing payments. I called several times and asked them to adjust my payments to reflect my SAVE program, and was told that MOHELA was evaluating the plan. 

In XX/XX/2024, they called me due to missed payments, and I explained the situation again, and the rep put me in administrative forbearance, yet I still continued to receive emails about missed payments. 

I should have {$0.00} payments now, and be working towards forgiveness, but MOHELA is not processing my new payment plan.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer was accepted into the SAVE program with a $0 monthly payment due to financial circumstances. Despite this, MOHELA repeatedly sent emails about missed payments. The consumer called multiple times, and although placed in administrative forbearance, the issue remains unresolved, preventing progress towards loan forgiveness.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
With regard to actions I have taken to resolve the issue with the company, I have called and emailed the company over a week ago from today 's date XXXX. In addition, I have discovered new errors in my loan that suggest bad faith tactics at the hands of a predatory lender. Below I will clarify the issues I have contacted the company about and the new issues I have discovered in regard to my loan. 

Problems I contacted the company about on XXXX, I called and emailed : XXXX. My loan was agreed to have a FIXED interest rate of 5.69 %, but they have increased it to 5.94 %. 

XXXX. My monthly payment is currently {$220.00} because it increased from {$220.00} when it shouldn't have. 

The company 's response : They recognize the issue, but have no idea when it can be fixed. And currently I am still on tract to pay the higher monthly rate of {$220.00} New-found problems that lead me to believe this company is conducting predatory lending tactics : XXXX. My loan was supposed to be {$20000.00} at 5.69 % APR with payments made over 10 years. Now after calculating these numbers, my monthly payments from the beginning should have been {$210.00} after taking out the full {$20000.00} for school, NOT {$220.00} which they later increased further to {$220.00}.
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims a lender increased their fixed 5.69% interest rate to 5.94% and monthly payment from $210 to $220, despite the original agreement. The lender acknowledged the issue but has no fix timeline, leading the consumer to suspect predatory lending tactics.

Sub-issue: Information belongs to someone else
Consumer complaint narrative: I wrote ED/NELNET to XXXX OUT the Biden-Harris XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The XXXX 's and he XXXX Department has ruled the XXXX XXXX XXXX plan can be OPT OUT. ED/Nelnet I want to OPT OUT the Biden-Harris loan XXXX XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: A consumer is trying to opt out of the Biden-Harris loan forgiveness plan, citing the Department of Education's ruling that it can be opted out. They are having issues with ED/Nelnet, who they claim are not allowing them to do so.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/year>, I received a notice from Mohela that my pslf forgiveness payments that have been counted were 4. I knew this wasn't correct and sent a massage to Mohela to review my account due to payment forbearance during Covid counted as a qualifying payment, regardless I payments were made. In XXXX I received a massage saying that I had 62 eligible payments, 39 pslf qualifying payments and have 81 payments left. It bothers me that they really messed that up. 4 to 39 is a huge mess up. That is almost 3 years of qualifying payments they were going to XXXX me out of. I don't even know if I should trust the 39 qualifying payments.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer received an initial notice from Mohela stating they had 4 PSLF qualifying payments, but after reviewing their account, Mohela corrected the count to 39 qualifying payments. The consumer is concerned about the significant error and now questions the accuracy of the revised count.

Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Request for Relief for Private Student Loans Used to Attend XXXX XXXX XXXX I am writing to bring to your attention the financial challenges I am facing as a borrower who attended XXXX XXXX XXXX. Like many others, I relied on both federal and private student loans to finance my education at the institution.

Currently, I am diligently repaying my private loans through Launch, but I am encountering significant difficulty due to the terms of the loan. My lender, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, has imposed a high interest rate, rendering my monthly payments unmanageableespecially since I lost my job in XXXX. 

I am reaching out to urge you to consider extending student loan relief to borrowers who, like me, used private loans to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX between XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX. The Department of Education recently announced federal loan forgiveness for borrowers from this period, citing XXXX XXXX XXXX  misrepresentation of job prospects. 

It is reasonable to infer that similar misrepresentations may have affected students who relied on private loans. As a result, many of us are now grappling with significant debt for an education that may not have met the promises made to us, leading to undue financial hardship.

I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) consider providing relief for private loans used to attend XXXX XXXX XXXX  during the same period covered by the federal loan forgiveness program ( XXXX ). 

Thank you for your time and consideration of this matter. Your support in addressing the challenges faced by borrowers like myself would be immensely appreciated. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: The complaint requests relief for private student loans used to attend a specific institution due to unmanageable high interest rates and alleged misrepresentation of job prospects, mirroring the federal loan forgiveness program for the same period.

Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I am writing due to a crushing amount of private loan debt that I am stuck under as a cosigner for XXXX XXXX and XXXX, a very low value school that promised my stepson a good paying career that never materialized. I am asking that these loans be cancelled in their entirety. This school has been branded a low value school and all federal loans for this school have already been cancelled in full.
Narrative Summary: A cosigner is seeking cancellation of private loans for a stepson who attended a low-value school that failed to deliver a promised good-paying career. The school's federal loans have already been cancelled, and the cosigner is requesting similar relief for the private loans.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
About two weeks ago my loans were forgiven, which I am eternally grateful. I have been in repayment for over XXXX decades, however, the date of forgiveness indicates that it was XX/XX/year>. This is clearly an error, but when I called Mohela yesterday, the rep didn't seem to understand the issue and kept pointing to the wrong date. She then talked to a supervisor, and together they refused to acknowledge the dates prior to consolidation, even after I pointed it out to them that the law clearly indicates that forgiveness encompasses all months in repayment, including months prior to consolidation. They claimed Student Aid is responsible for setting the date of forgiveness and directed me to them. I immediately called SA, but their phone system goes through a loop and drops the call. Changing the forgiveness date helps avoid issuing a refund for years worth of overpayments. This needs to be corrected. On XXXX of my closed XXXX loans ( prior to being transferred to Mohela ), it indicated the term was for 405 months or XXXX years. This is the only count I've seen on any of my student loans with any company or organization, even after asking both Mohela and DE. I know other people could see how many months they were in repayment, but I never could, except on my closed XXXX accounts, which I am basing my count on. 

https : //studentaid.gov/XXXX  See this section : ***any time in repayment ( or deferment or forbearance, if applicable ) on earlier loans before consolidation of those loans into a consolidation loan. ***
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer's student loans were forgiven, but the forgiveness date is incorrect, excluding years of repayment prior to consolidation. Despite pointing out the error and relevant law, Mohela refused to correct it, directing the consumer to Student Aid, whose phone system failed to connect the call.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been denied my request for a School Misconduct Discharge Application. The reason I received was that my consolidation loans do not qualify. This does not make sense because both loans that were consolidated were issued by this company- Navient formerly Sallie Mae and consolidated by Sallie Mae Private Consolidation as well. 

The original loans were disbursed on : XX/XX/XXXX in the amount of {$13000.00} and XX/XX/XXXX in the amount of {$10000.00}. They were both consolidated through the Sallie Mae Private Consolidation Loan Program in the amount of {$27000.00} on XX/XX/XXXX. ( All documents attached ) I am aware that Navient was sued by 39 state XXXX regarding their predatory loans to attend these for-profit schools and that Sallie Mae/Navient were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early 2000 's. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " for profit schools ''. 

My school, The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX closed it's doors in 2017. Students at these schools were mislead by admissions representatives to sign up for loans by their preferred lender- Sallie Mae ( now Navient ), and they knew students would not be able to pay back in a timely manner. We were also guided to apply for forbearance and deferment by the school 's student loan office. These predatory lending practices are unethical and unfair to thousands of students that put their trust in these institutions. We were also mislead with career services and job opportunities upon graduation. There was zero assistance or correspondence in anything upon completion of these programs except how to put ourselves into more debt by forbearance or deferment.
Narrative Summary: A borrower was denied a School Misconduct Discharge Application by Navient, citing ineligible consolidation loans. However, both original loans were issued by Navient (formerly Sallie Mae) and consolidated through Sallie Mae's program, leading the borrower to dispute the denial.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/XXXX, I received a direct student loan for the spring semester. My balance was {$3000.00}. On XX/XX/XXXX, I paid the entire balance in full. MOHELA took the money from my checking account and has not credited my account for the payment. The balance still shows {$3000.00}. I have called and emailed multiple times to get them to update my balance and send me a payoff letter. Multiple emails have been sent. They refuse to update my account balance. I have been given multiple excuses, and I was even told I should not have paid the money because I was still in school. 

Every email reply is : " We see that you have recently contacted us, and we are assuming the issue has been resolved. '' The issue is never resolved. I simply need my balance updated and a payoff letter to be sent. It should not take 5 months to do this.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer paid off a $3000 direct student loan in full, but MOHELA failed to update the account balance and provide a payoff letter, despite multiple calls and emails over 5 months, with the company repeatedly claiming the issue was resolved when it was not.

Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I reached out to Navient in 2023 regarding my remaining private student loans. I received loan forgiveness for my federal student loans and had a borrowers defense application filed with Navient. However, was not included in the attorney general requirements for forgiveness for the private student loans even though the private student loan met all other criterias except one. And the loan was obtained from a for profit school that has successful lawsuits regarding defrauded students. I really need some help with getting clarification and guidance on how to deal with this private student loan. Also, my loan balance is literally 98 % interest which is also something of concern. I am also aware of Navient XXXX XXXX discharge application which I would like to be able to complete because I would qualify having all the other loans qualified under borrowers defense as I am a defrauded student for the same exact school. I hope someone can please help me. I do also apologize for the description as this is just a frustrating situation and I am explaining everything the best way I know how having been dealing with this for some time.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's private student loan from a for-profit school was not included in the attorney general's forgiveness requirements, despite meeting most criteria. The loan balance is 98% interest, and the consumer seeks guidance on dealing with the loan and applying for a Navient discharge.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: I went to XXXX XXXX from XXXX. Before I applied and got accepted, the school had a prestigious reputation. There were some rumors and talks about a lawsuit where there were false claims from the school telling students they would make certain amounts of money. Everyone working at the school reassured me and the prospective students that these claims were in the past and the school was different now. Of course, I believed it and proceeded to apply to the school and be surprised when I got accepted thinking it meant they liked my work and saw potential in my photography. Then shortly after I started going to XXXX XXXX, it got sold to XXXX. Immediately everything changed. They sold the old school where XXXX XXXX started. XXXX changed a bunch of staff members. And as a young adult, I got pressured in to always applying for and taking the maximum amont of student loans that I could. Even after asking why because I could tell it was too much, the " counselors '' pressured me in to taking the max amount. I was told multiple times to take the max amount and then immediately pay back whatever I thought I didn't need. Looking back, I see how obviously predatory this was but at the time I did not know any better. I was not alone in this practice. All of my friends and classmates that needed help paying for the extremely expensive schooling were told the same things. Take the max amount whether you need it or not. We were also told time and time again that we could come out of school and immediately be making upwards of XXXX per year as XXXX XXXX Few of my classmates found work as XXXX  and none of them made anywhere near that amount. XXXX and XXXX XXXX lied and preyed on students repeatedly for many years. This is why all students who attended that school should have their loans canceled and all the money, including interest, should be returned to the students who fell victim to that predatory school. To date, I have paid {$97000.00} in private loans and I'm one of the lucky ones that managed to have a relatively lower, though still predatory and ridiculous, amount coming out of that school.
Narrative Summary: The complainant alleges that XXXX XXXX, a school with a previously prestigious reputation, misled students about potential earnings and pressured them to take maximum student loans. After the school was sold, the complainant claims the school's promises were false, and they're seeking loan cancellation and repayment of $97,000 in private loans.

Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
Apologies if I didn't select the correct category for this, but this is what I am complaining about. 

I hope this correspondence finds you well. I am writing to bring to your attention a matter concerning my educational loans that necessitates careful consideration and resolution. 

During the period spanning from XXXX to XXXX, I pursued my education at XXXX XXXX located in XXXX XXXX, IL ( now closed ), culminating in my graduation in XXXX. Throughout my academic journey, I availed both federal and private loans to facilitate my educational endeavors. 

Recently, my federal loans were XXXX in XXXX owing to instances of misconduct and the subsequent closure of the institution. This development prompted me to explore the possibility of a similar discharge for my Signature Select private loans, which are currently serviced by Navient, formerly serviced as Sallie Mae. 

In light of the circumstances surrounding the discharge of my federal loans, particularly the misconduct associated with XXXX XXXX and the application of the FTC 's " Holder Rule, '' I firmly believe that my private loans merit equitable consideration for discharge on grounds of misconduct. 

For your reference, I have enclosed a copy of the letter titled " Notice of Borrower Defense Discharge Approval, '' which pertains to the discharge of my loans from XXXX XXXX in XXXX. 

I kindly request your assistance in assessing the eligibility of my private loans for discharge in alignment with the aforementioned grounds. Your attention to this matter and timely response would be greatly appreciated.
Narrative Summary: A borrower is seeking discharge of their private Signature Select loans, serviced by Navient, due to misconduct by their former school, which led to the discharge of their federal loans. They believe their private loans merit similar consideration under the FTC's "Holder Rule."

Sub-issue: Problem with forgiveness, cancellation, or discharge
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX is cancelling Federal Student Loans due to findings of misconduct but mine haven't been cancelled when they should have been. I enrolled into the XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX in the fall of XXXX. I was forced to get a student loan so that I could attend the school. I was lied to and misinformed about there being a guarantee that I would receive a job once I graduate in XXXX XXXX. I wasn't able to get a job in my field and because of that I've worked odd jobs trying to get by and have been in debt trying to pay my student loans with high interest. 
My student loans are {$53000.00}. My interest is half of that. 
I am also apart of the XXXX lawsuit.
Narrative Summary: A borrower claims their federal student loans weren't cancelled despite alleged misconduct by their school. They enrolled in a program with false job guarantees, leading to debt and high-interest payments of $53,000. The borrower is also part of a related lawsuit against the school.

Issue: Unable to get your credit report or credit score
Sub-issue: Other problem getting your report or credit score
Consumer complaint narrative: In XX/XX/2022 I took out a loan from Status Financial LLC. I was told that the XXXX of every month I must pay the loan and that the loan amount is subject to change considering it is a variable loan. Even though the interest rate was high on this loan I still took it considering I knew that my credit from this loan would build my credit score so later I could refinance. The only issue is I haven't received any credit even though I contacted Stratus Financial multiple times. I have not made a late payment or missed a payment.
Company public response: Company believes the complaint is the result of a misunderstanding
Narrative Summary: The consumer took out a variable loan from Stratus Financial in 2022, making timely payments, but despite this, they have not received any credit score updates or benefits, contrary to their initial understanding that the loan would help build their credit score.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX Mohela increased my monthly payment from {$270.00} to {$2100.00} without any warning. The online account shows my recertification deadline had been extended until XX/XX/XXXX for {$270.00}, however, I received a letter stating my payment had been increased to {$2100.00}. When I called Mohela to discuss this, the agent confirmed the new payment amount, but said she could see where I was previously paying the {$270.00}. At first, she said the repayment plan had been applied prior to my loans transferring to them and the repayment plan had not been transferred with and no new applications were received. This was old news and had been resolved in XX/XX/XXXX through a CFPB complaint. When the agent was directed to the communication from Mohela with the new approved amount because of the CFPB last year, the agent stated they could not find that letter in their system. Requests to speak to a supervisor were not honored at first. The agent placed us on hold and then said that Mohela is in the process of updating borrower accounts due to the Department of Education pushing back the IDR recertification deadline again. She said Mohela will apply for a forbearance, no payment is required, and guaranteed the forbearance will count for PSLF. None of this information could be validated on the Department of Education 's website and the agent stated she could not provide anything in writing. The agent also gave conflicting information as she stated that the forbearance will not be automatically applied, and I would need to request it ( even though she said it would be applied in the beginning ). I had also just received several notices showing a 1-day forbearance being applied each month from XX/XX/XXXX- XX/XX/XXXX.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: MOHELA increased the complainant's monthly payment from $270 to $2100 without warning, despite the online account showing a lower payment amount and a recertification deadline extension. The agent provided conflicting information about a forbearance that would supposedly count for PSLF, but couldn't provide written confirmation.

Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended XXXX from XX/XX/XXXX, to XX/XX/XXXX. My federal loans were forgiven under the XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX lawsuit due to school misconduct. 

However, my private loans have continued with an interest rate of 10 %, resulting in monthly payments nearing {$500.00}. Despite making these payments, the total amount owed continues to increase. Navient has been uncooperative, only offering a temporary interest-only plan.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's federal loans were forgiven due to school misconduct, but their private loans with Navient remain, with a 10% interest rate and increasing balance despite monthly payments of nearly $500. Navient has been uncooperative, only offering a temporary interest-only plan.

Sub-issue: Problem lowering your monthly payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was in school with XXXX University in XXXX XXXX  from XX/XX/XXXX through XXXX of XXXX where I received my XXXX XXXX XXXX degree in XXXX XXXX. 
I ended up with around $ XXXX in Federal debt in student loans, and another $ XXXX in private loans. 

My federal loans were through XXXX, and as of a year ago, those have been forgiven through a Borrowers Defense Claim. 

My Private Loans were with MOHELA, and in XXXX of XXXX, I refinanced with XXXX. 
I had XXXX loans that I was paying with a total every month around {$470.00}, all three with varying interest rates. 

With XXXX it is a little easier on my wallet, with a XXXX XXXX rate and a payment of {$320.00}
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: A consumer complains about high student loan debt, but the issue isn't the debt itself. The narrative doesn't explicitly state a complaint, but it implies dissatisfaction with the original loan terms. The consumer had multiple private loans with varying interest rates, but refinancing with a new lender reduced their monthly payment.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
I contacted Earnest, the loan company that current holds my private loans taken out for my education at the now defunct XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I attended from XXXX. My Federal loans have been XXXXischarged due to flagrant, persistent and malicious misconduct by the school in question. I reached out to Earnest, because I do not believe I should have to repay my student loans taken out privately when the Federal government has determined their loans should not have to be repaid. The response from Earnest was laughable and pathetic : " Our records show that you refinanced with Earnest in XX/XX/2019. The payoff information from your original loan shows that it was a Private Loan that was serviced by XXXX XXXX. Unfortunately, your loan would not be eligible for consideration for discharge through Earnest given that it is a private refinance loan and not a loan directly for attendance for a school that may have engaged in misconduct. You may wish to consult an attorney about any rights you may have to loan forgiveness or other relief programs. '' Essentially they are saying that since it was a private loan, and I can not show it was used for my education at school, they are not obligated to even discuss discharge options with me. It would be incredibly easy given modern technology to prove what the funds were used for and when. I am extremely unsatisfied with their answer and I wish to pursue this further. I do not believe I should have to repay my loans for this schooling when the Federal government has publicly stated they are discharging loans for fraudulent and malicious behavior. As well, I am post class in the XXXX XXXX vs. California settlement, where a judge ruled in favor of the students who attended many for profit colleges ( including mine ), and were intentionally misled about the education they would receive and the loans they had to take out to complete it. 
The fact that Earnest won't even attempt to back track and see what the funds were used for ( oh and by the way, my loans used to be held by XXXX, Earnests parent company!! ) is ridiculous. I would like to discuss my options with someone to see what can be done moving forward. I have the litigation to back up my reasoning, and I'm not sure how to apply it to the situation in a meaningful way. Help would be incredibly appreciated! 

Thank you, -XX/XX/XXXX
Narrative Summary: The consumer disputes having to repay private student loans from Earnest, citing the federal government's discharge of their federal loans due to the school's misconduct. Earnest claims the private loan is ineligible for discharge, prompting the consumer to seek further assistance and potential litigation.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
I write to request assistance in getting clear answers regarding discharge and refunds I am entitled to under XX/XX/XXXX and the IDR Waiver Adjustment. I took out loans to attend XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) and XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ). These loans are eligible for discharge via theXX/XX/XXXX case. A third loan, for XX/XX/XXXX ( XX/XX/XXXX) should be discharged under the Dept. of Educations ( ED ) one-time waiver adjustment.

I. BACKGROUND ON STUDENT LOANS My loan history is as follows : -XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXXloans that entered into payment status on XX/XX/XXXX. 

XX/XX/XXXX loans that entered into payment status on XX/XX/XXXX. 

-XX/XX/XXXX: A mix of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX loans entered that into repayment on XX/XX/XXXX & XX/XX/XXXX. 

My XXXX loans were serviced by the following : ( XXXX ) XX/XX/XXXX ( XXXX ) and ( XXXX ) Nelnet ( XXXX ). 

The XXXX Loans were serviced by XXXX ( XXXX ). 

On or about XX/XX/XXXX the XXXX and XXXX loans were consolidated ( the XXXX Consolidation '' ) into an XXXX consolidation loan, which was serviced by XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( " XXXX ). XXXX serviced the 1st Consolidation from XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX. 

My XX/XX/XXXX loans were originally serviced by both XX/XX/XXXXand XXXX XXXX, aka XX/XX/XXXX. 

On or about XX/XX/XXXX all of my XXXX loans and the previously consolidated XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX loans were combined into a XX/XX/XXXX loans ( subsidized and unsubsidized ) with XX/XX/XXXX( the 2nd Consolidation ). After XXXX stopped servicing federal student loans altogether, EdFinancial took over and is the current servicer of my XXXX XXXX loan ( the XX/XX/XXXX ). 

II. BORROWER DEFENSE APPLICATION HISTORY On XX/XX/XXXX, I filed Borrower Defense Applications for my XXXX ( XX/XX/0152 ) and XXXX ( XX/XX/0152) loans, respectively. Due to these XX/XX/XXXXapplications, I am a class member in the XX/XX/XXXX. My XXXX XXXX application is eligible for discharge as an Exhibit C school. My XXXX XXXX XXXX ( I attended prior to ownership by XXXX XXXX ) is part of the XX/XX/XXXX 

On XX/XX/XXXX, I initially received notice that both XX/XX/XXXXApplications were denied, and an interest credit of {$12000.00} would be applied to my account because it took XXXX an extended period of time to review my claim. See, XX/XX/XXXX Correspondence from XXXX attached. I have been unable to verify whether XXXX properly applied the interest credit to my account. 

After the Settlement Agreement was approved in XXXX XXXX XXXX, both XX/XX/XXXXdenials were rescinded. By XX/XX/XXXX I received an email from ED, advising me that my XXXX XXXX application would be re-reviewed. Specifically, the letter states that : Your federal loans will stay in forbearance or stopped collection status until your application is granted or denied and any relief is provided. For this period of forbearance or stopped collection status, the Department will not make you pay any interest that accrues on your federal loans.

The Settlement Agreement also meant that my XXXX loan would be discharged via the automatic discharge provision as XXXX is an Exhibit C school. I received confirmation of this via an email from ED on XX/XX/XXXX. On XX/XX/XXXX, ED notified me that my XXXX XXXX application had been approved and that the loans were eligible for discharge. 

Even with two XXXX XXXX approvals, little activity has occurred on my account. That is why it came as a huge shock when I received a letter dated XX/XX/XXXX from EdFinancial stating that they discharged 100 % of my XXXX loans : {$31000.00} in principal, and {$10000.00} towards interest because it took an extended period of time to review my claim. See, XX/XX/XXXX EdFinancial letter attached.

I also attach EdFinancials payment account history from its website as of XX/XX/XXXX. As you can see, it reflects none of the adjustments or credits stated in the XX/XX/XXXX letter. If you review my EdFinancial account history, the only credits and/or adjustments after made to my account are as follows : {$5300.00} on XX/XX/XXXX, and {$2800.00} on XX/XX/XXXX. Where is the alleged {$31000.00} that was 100 % discharged? Where is the {$10000.00} interest credit? To put things in perspective, my starting balance at the time EdFinancial took over my loans was {$150000.00}. As of XX/XX/XXXX, my balance with EdFinancial is {$140000.00}. How is it that my discharge is complete when my {$30000.00} + {$10000.00} discharge resulted in a net different of {$13000.00}?

Even more troubling is that EdFinancial inexplicably added back {$12000.00} as interest, back-dating the charge to XX/XX/XXXX. This is in the exact same amount of interest credit I was entitled to receive when my XX/XX/XXXXApplications were denied on XX/XX/XXXX. To add insult to injury, credit adjustments were made on XX/XX/XXXX for {$2800.00} ; however, all of this was applied to interest, which had now ballooned due to EdFinancial charging me {$12000.00} in interest. Keep in mind that the {$12000.00} in interest that was supposed to be credited accrued prior to XX/XX/XXXX, and includes interest that accrued while all my loans were consolidated ( XXXX, XXXX & XX/XX/XXXX). It is completely inappropriate to be re-assessed this full amount of interest, which basically accrued prior to any of my loans being discharged. It is also unfair to after-the-fact try and tack this back on, after being advised that it would be removed.

It is HIGHLY DISTRESSING to see, after my discharge is 100 % complete letter that ( a ) none of the supposed credits or discharged amounts even show up in EdFinancials account history, ( b ) only smaller amounts were discharged {$5300.00} and {$2800.00}, ( c ) it doesnt appear that deductions were made to account for interest that accrued, capitalized, or interest that I paid for prior over the course of the loans lifetime, and the coup d'tat : seeing my balance drastically increase due to unexpalined interest charges.

When I questioned EdFinancial on this, they indicated they have no record of even sending me the XX/XX/XXXX letter and that my discharge is still processing. They had no idea why the interest was added, stating they were instructed to do so by ED. EdFinancial has no idea on when or whether a refund should be issued. They know absolutely nothing. What is the point of even having a loan servicer if they cant answer a basic question such as why interest was added to my account? These confusing messages are frustrating and are symptomatic of how disjointed this entire process has been for each class member and all student loans borrowers overall. I am tilting at windmills and see no end in sight and feel that I am being victimized by continued bungling of my accounts. This is crushing, after holding out such hope that I would see some form of relief.

More recently, on XX/XX/XXXX, i spoke by phone conf w/ an Edfinancial customer service agent, by the name of XXXX . I asked him to explain about what instructions EdFinancial received from ED regarding the large interest charge. 

XXXX confirmed a XX/XX/XXXX notation someone EdFinancial had made, indicated that per XX/XX/XXXXemail w/ borrower defense write off portion of interest due to delayed process : applied {$960.00} XXXX ( loan XXXX ) ; {$1800.00} XXXX ( loan XXXX ) interest credits. It also noted " w/ new interest CREDIT prev [ previous ] applied on XX/XX/XXXX for {$4900.00} XXXX and {$7800.00} XXXX has been reapplied to loans. '' I asked him for clarification regarding the {$4900.00} and {$7800.00} amounts. XXXX indicated that those should be applied as credits. I asked him to review account history to see credits/debits applied to my account and tell me what he sees. This is interesting he says. It shows the write off on XX/XX/XXXX : {$2800.00}. Then he acknowledges he saw : {$12000.00} ( which is the grand total of {$4900.00} and {$7800.00} ) was ADDED to my account as a charge. I asked him to confirm additional credits he saw on my account. He confirmed that after the XX/XX/XXXX was added back to my account, that a {$2800.00} credit was then applied against the XX/XX/XXXXXXXX interest that was wrongly added to my account. 
I advised him that due to this error : -Since the XX/XX/XXXX wasnt applied properly as a credit, interest is accruing daily on an incorrect, higher principal balance ; -Instead of the {$2800.00} being applied properly as a credit against my balance, it was applied to the wrongfully added XX/XX/XXXX, thus diluting my overall discharge to which I am entitled. 

-I advised that if further credits come in and/or discharge requests come in from ED it will now be applied to an incorrect balance, due to the incorrect addition of XX/XX/XXXX to my account, along with the daily interest rate continuing to accrue. 

XXXX says : sees my complaints : on this : Says XX/XX/XXXX[ customer resolution unit ] team taking a look at it. Trying to figure out how to resolve it. He asked if I recd any resopnses from XX/XX/XXXX? I told him yes, I recd several emails from Edfinancial saying they are looking into it that my account is in admin forbearance, that this request has been given emergency status I asked which dept entered XX/XX/XXXXXXXX interest credit as a charge. He says it was entered Edfinancials Finance dept. 
I asked him when was XX/XX/XXXX added as a charge to the account : It was entered on XX/XX/XXXX @ XXXX XX/XX/XXXX. The code for entry : XXXX [ Per XXXX, payments & billing code ]. Comment about XX/XX/XXXX addition is the per XX/XX/XXXXemail as cited above. 

I asked him to explain why the XX/XX/XXXX in interest, being that it was entered to my account on XX/XX/XXXX, why was it back dated to XX/XX/XXXX. He says the notes dont explain why and he cant give me an explanation as to why it was back dated. While he acknowledged the error, he can not tell me when it will get fixed.

III. XXXX MISSING PAYMENT HISTORY POST-CONSOLIDATION Student loan payments I made after the 2nd Consolidation with XX/XX/XXXX( between XX/XX/XXXX through XX/XX/XXXX that total approximately {$1400.00} ) are missing from my payment history. ( Refer to my Student Aid Feedback XXXX # XXXX ). XXXX assured me they would look into this, but it was never resolved. EdFinancial, as the successor servicer, also shows that I made no payments after XX/XX/XXXX. Considering that I was on an IDR plan, missing payments have major consequences. Notably, these missing payments are crucial to have for my loan servicer to be able to calculate my refund payment under XX/XX/XXXX, as payments made during that time period were after the 2nd Consolidation, and paid towards both my XXXX and XXXX loans. 

In XXXX XXXX XXXX filed on XX/XX/XXXX in XX/XX/XXXX, he indicated that for borrowers with loans transferred from decommissioned servicers, obtaining additional payment information can be difficult if not impossible. As a borrower who has three loan servicers who are no longer in operation since loan inception, ( XXXX, XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX), and who actually has payments missing from my account history through XXXX, I have grave concerns this means that I will be short-changed on the relief to which I am entitled.

IV. ONE TIME WAIVER ADJUSTMENT STATUS Per EDs IDR one-time waiver adjustment, I am entitled to total discharge of all of my loans. My graduate loans were consolidated with my oldest undergraduate loans in XXXX. Since my oldest loan has been in repayment status since XXXX, I have now surpassed 25 years mark of payment months. Per guidance on EDs website regarding the one-time waiver adjustment [ a ] ssuming your repayment history overlaps for each loan, the consolidation loan will be credited with the longest amount of time in repayment of the loans that were consolidated. As I am not receiving any form of monetary refund for payments held under XXXX loans, those payment should count towards IDR payment months. In light of EDs acknowledgment of missing payment history, and indeed, I have three decomissioned loan servicers in my loan history, I am concerned that I am not being given the proper payment credits, because I I have yet to receive any notice that all my loans qualify for forgiveness due to reaching the 300 month payment mark.

V. CONCLUSION Based on the above issues, I request detailed answers to the following questions : Why did EdFinancial charge me {$12000.00}, back dated to XX/XX/XXXX, which shouldve been applied as a credit on my account? 

Why is my payment history missing and what will ED do to resolve this prior to calculating my refund amount?

Does EdFinancials have a complete payment history for my XXXX and XXXX loans since inception from all prior loan servicers, including XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX from XXXX through the present? 

If EdFinancial is unable to obtain my entire payment /account history since the loans inception, advise me immediately as to : ( i ) Which specific servicers records are missing ; ( ii ) How will Edfinancial calculate interest I paid over the loans life history, which I am entitled to receive credit for as part of my settlement relief ; ( iii ) How will Edfi calculate the interest amounts that accrued over and above the amount of interest paid, which also should be credited as part of my settlement relief ; ( iv ) How will Edfi calculate my refund payments where servicers records are missing, including my missing XX/XX/XXXXpayments. 

( v ) Where loan servicer payment history is confirmed missing, how will this impact my IDR one-time waiver adjustment for the period of time where payment history is missing; and ( vi ) Where loan servicer payment history is confirmed missing, how can Edfi legally continue to collect on my debt?

Provide confirmation that discharge of my loans through XX/XX/XXXX will not impact my eligibility for the IDR one time waiver adjustment, since I will not be receving a refund on any amounts paid on XXXX Loans ; I require confirmation in writing about EDs position for IDR waiver adjustment counts for those who do receive discharge under XX/XX/XXXX who also had loans consolidated with non-eligible schools?

What exact instructions has ED provided to EdFinancial in regards to discharging my XXXX XXXX, including amounts to be discharged for principal and interest.

For the {$10000.00} interest credit that was supposed to be applied pursuant to my discharge letter, what period of time does this interest cover? When will this be applied to my account?

For the {$31000.00} in principal discharge that was supposed to be applied to my account when will this reflected?

What is the amount of interest that accured and capitalized on my XXXX loan since inception that is being applied as a credit to my account? 

What is the status of my refund? I was expecting a refund by XX/XX/XXXX. The delay has caused me to incur hefty interest for expenses I had to charge to my credit card because I did not receive the funds timely.
Narrative Summary: A borrower is disputing the handling of their student loan discharge and refund. Despite receiving a letter stating that $31,000 in principal and $10,000 in interest were discharged, the borrower's account history shows only smaller credits of $5,300 and $2,800. Additionally, $12,000 in interest was incorrectly added to the account, and the borrower's payment history is missing. The borrower is seeking clarification on the errors and the status of their refund.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been making timely payments on my student loans ( can prove with screenshots of bank account debits from MOHELA ) but I am being hounded with " missed payment '' notifications. When I call MOHELA about this, I wait for hours only to be told that they actually *do* see the payments have been made but their " new system '' is misreporting those payments as missed. They claim this will be fixed before my credit score is affected, but I do not trust that as I was told by one agent that credit reporting begins in XXXX whereas one more recently told me credit reporting would not be until this fall. 

Timeline : XXXX '' Friendly Payment Reminder - One Due Date Has Been Missed '' Letter from MOHELA XXXXI call MOHELA and after an hour wait on the phone am told I should not receive further correspondence regarding missed payments going forward as the problem has been resolved. 

XXXX '' Account is Over 30 Days Past Due '' Letter from MOHELA XXXXI call MOHELA and am told the letters are due to a " new system '' but that the issue will be fixed before credit reporting begins in XXXX XXXX '' Friendly Payment Reminder - One Due Date Has Been Missed '' Letter from MOHELA XXXX '' Cascading Delinquency Letter - 30 Days '' Letter from MOHELA XXXXI call MOHELA and they claim that my payment isn't yet processed because it takes 37 days to process a payment. I am now told not to worry about credit reporting until XXXX, contradicting what I was told last month.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: MOHELA is sending "missed payment" notifications despite timely payments. The company blames a "new system" for misreporting payments, but provides conflicting information on when credit reporting will begin, causing concern about potential credit score impact.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: I enrolled in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX with the deceiving tactics of indirectly hinting to guaranteed job placement in the XXXX  industry upon the completion of XXXX XXXX XXXX with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. To cover the expensive cost of XXXX, I had to take a combination of private and federal loans. Some of the private loans structure were confusing and got sold out to different lenders before even finishing the school. In XXXX, after completing the program and XXXX, they denied committing to any responsibility of job placement. At the same time, I start receiving multiple bills from different lenders. The Wells Fargo bill had different loan interest rates than the previous lender issuer at 8.99 %. The number of payment became overwhelming and I refinanced all private loan with XXXX for a fixed interest rate of 5.5 %. I have been paying this for the last XXXX  years and still owe large portion of the principal. The XXXX XXXX was not recognized in all my attempts to obtain employment. The XXXX  misconduct caused me a life long sense of failure. It has been discovered the XXXX  had operated with bad faith and many complains had shown it.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims a school misled them with guaranteed job placement in a specific industry, leading them to take out private and federal loans. After completing the program, the school denied responsibility for job placement, and the consumer struggled with overwhelming debt from multiple lenders.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: Between the years of XXXX and XXXX I was enrolled in the XXXX institute of XXXX  I was coerced into their deceitful practices as a minority that they had high graduation rates, employment rates, credible and transferable classes. I was told I would have all federal loans ( At the time FFELP loans ) and was pressured to get massive loans to go to the now closed school, the XXXX XXXX of Washington. During my tenure there, the classes were horrible, nothing was really being taught. I could not transfer out because their credits were not accepted at other school so was forced to try to finish. Eventually, had to withdraw due to ongoing issues with the school and financially debt they put me in. I received no value for the the predatory loans that were given to me during that time. XXXX institute has be in lawsuits by multiple states and class action. I have received a portion that was held by this predatory practices back as a refund and I am requesting the remaining amount held by Navient regardless if my loans have been paid off by me.
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims they were misled by the XXXX Institute of XXXX about graduation and employment rates, and coerced into taking large FFELP loans. The school's poor education and non-transferable credits led to withdrawal, and the consumer seeks refund of remaining loan amounts held by Navient.

Consumer complaint narrative: I applied to the XXXX Repayment plan on XX/XX/year> and am still waiting for a response. Mohela has continued to charge me my monthly payment, even though it is my understanding that the loan is placed on an administrative forbearance while the application is still pending. I called on XX/XX/year> and was advised that I needed to contact XXXX as they were processing my Consolidation application. I called XXXX XX/XX/year> and was advised consolidation application was closed because my loans were already consolidated and that I would receive a response within 2 weeks. Today, XX/XX/year>, I call again XXXX and was advised that Mohela is in charge of processing the XXXX application to call them. I again called Mohela on XX/XX/year> and was told the application is still pending, and no new information given. At this point, it has been almost 4 months since my application was submitted and I am still waiting for my payment to be recalculated. I am not able to afford the current payment. Please help.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
