Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
MOHELA has incorrectly billed me and is negligent in following fair billing regulations according to the Federal Student Aid Office. 

Today, XX/XX/year> I received written correspondence from MOHELA delivered by XXXX including a billing statement dated XX/XX/year> and confirmation of consolidation XX/XX/year> addressed with the incorrect name As this is XXXX of many ongoing grievances with MOHELA and I am still awaiting communication, correction, rectification, and restitution from MOHELA about those matters, this letter adds on to a building case demonstrating MOHELAs unfair, harmful, and negligent practices. I first address errors made by MOHELA regarding my legal name then I address the most recent errors, negligence, and unfair billing practices in collecting debt. 

The correspondence for my recently processed consolidation loan is incorrectly addressed to a previous name I had. I have already submitted name change documentation with MOHELA and this name change was correctly reflected on my application documents for loan consolidation. With thousands of dollars being exchanged on my behalf, it is a reasonable expectation that MOHELA maintain accurate records without my reminding or needing my attention of correction such as but not limited to my legal name. 
MOHELA is negligent with their billing practice and fails to follow consumer regulations of and rights under consumer protection and violates fair debt collection practices. According to the Federal Student Aid OfficXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) Your loan servicer will send you your billing statement at least 21 days before your payment is due. 
The bill is dated XX/XX/year>, which is less then the 21 days stipulated by the Federal Student Aid Office and Code of Massachusetts Regulations XXXX XXXX. The bill was generated on XX/XX/year> which is XXXX calendar day before the written notice of consolidation and loan servicing was created meaning that the MOHELA billed me prior to giving me notice of a schedule of terms, payments, and details of the loan. As I received this bill statement less than XXXX calendar days before the due date of XX/XX/year> and the statement itself is dated less than 21 days prior to the due date, this written notice violates the guidelines, regulations of the Federal Student Loan Office. It is also a clear violation of Code of Massachusetts Regulations Title 209.

The written correspondence does not match the payment due as listed on the website. The written notice has a different amount due on XX/XX/year> then what is on the website. Furthmore this is a new website that MOHELA uses. MOHELA 's old website does not give notice of my account migrating to a new website nor does it redirect consumers to the new one. This is intentionally misleading and creates another obstacle and hindance to access online accounts to make timely payments. 

Without a reasonable timeline for written notice, a reasonable time to make payment, and obstacles such as the company 's website failure to reflect to accurate amounts with written correspondence and misleading users from XXXX old website, along with incorrect information such as my name, MOHELA creates an burden and hardship to make timely which negatively impacts my financial and consumer well-being and could constitute MOHELAs intentional obstruction and negligence As indicated in prior correspondence and prior issues with the company, including a case that is still open through the CFPB, MOHELA has XXXX pattern of negligent and harmful practices that negatively impact my financial and consumer well-being.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: MOHELA incorrectly billed the consumer, violating fair billing regulations. The billing statement was dated less than 21 days before the payment due date, and the amount due didn't match the website. The statement also had the consumer's incorrect name, despite previous name change documentation.

Sub-issue: Problem with the interest rate
Consumer complaint narrative:
I had subprime loans from Sallie Mae which was later transferred to Navient and is currently with XXXX after refinancing. Sallie Mae offered these loans at exorbitant rates at a time when I wasn't even a US resident or had a SSN. My rates were in the 12-15 % range at a time when nationwide average was between 1-4 %. Total loan amount was around {$75000.00}, I was paying interest while I was in college. After graduating, I haven't missed a payment, paid over XXXX and still have over $ XXXX to go. After reflecting on this, my loan seem to have quadrupled while I was on school. 
I am seeking the remainder of the loan be forgiven. 

Thank you, XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: A borrower claims Sallie Mae (now Navient) issued subprime loans with exorbitant 12-15% interest rates, despite the nationwide average being 1-4%. The borrower, then a non-US resident without a SSN, was lent $75,000 and has paid significantly but still owes, seeking loan forgiveness.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Need information about your loan balance or loan terms
Consumer complaint narrative:
My loans from Nelnet for The XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX, VA are to be fully discharged due to the fact that this school was found by the U.S. Department of Education to have operated on false promises, lies, manipulation, falsified data, knowingly misled students, cheated borrowers into taking on mountains of debt without leading to promising career prospects at the end of their studies. This was all done by this school in order to profit off students loans.

Therefore, and with that being said, Nelnet has yet to fully discharge my loan ( s ) balances listed on my account and forward all refunds due to me per the U.S. Department of Education 's rulings.

Thank you.
Narrative Summary: The complainant's loans from Nelnet for a school found by the U.S. Department of Education to have operated deceitfully should be fully discharged. However, Nelnet has not discharged the loans or provided refunds as required by the Department of Education's rulings.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
Formal Complaint Regarding Unauthorized Auto Withdrawal by Aidvantage I am writing to formally lodge a complaint regarding an unauthorized auto withdrawal from my bank account for my student loan payment. This incident occurred in the context of the recent restart of student loan payments mandated by the government. 

After the government restarted student loan payments in XXXX, I noticed that Aidvantage had automatically withdrawn a payment from my bank account on XX/XX/year> without my prior authorization. Given the changes and uncertainties surrounding the resumption of student loan payments, I had not opted into auto payments nor had I provided any recent authorization for such a transaction. 

This unauthorized withdrawal has caused significant inconvenience and disruption to my financial planning. As a result, I have incurred unexpected overdraft fees and have had to rearrange my budget to accommodate this unforeseen expense. 

I request an immediate investigation into this matter and a prompt resolution. And did not receive a reply I trust that Aidvantage will be reprimanded of this matter with the urgency and seriousness it warrants. Please confirm receipt of this complaint and provide a timeline for resolution. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this issue. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: Aidvantage made an unauthorized auto withdrawal from the complainant's bank account for a student loan payment, despite no recent authorization or opt-in for auto payments. This resulted in overdraft fees and financial disruption, prompting a request for investigation and resolution.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have enrolled in the SAVE plan so monthly payments would be applied to the principal and not to the interest. I have been enrolled into SAVE since XX/XX/XXXX. My monthly loan payments have only been applied to the loan interest. Nothing is applied to the principal until the interest is paid off. I continue to accrue interest onto the principal. Mohela can not provide a sufficient response on when they will fill their obligation to this part of the SAVE plan. They do not provide a time line when this will occur. 
I need to know when this will occur and if these payments will ever be retroactively applied to the principal.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer enrolled in the SAVE plan to apply monthly payments to the principal, but Mohela has only applied payments to interest, not principal, since enrollment in XX/XX/XXXX, and cannot provide a timeline for when this will change or if past payments will be retroactively applied.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/2023 I made a lump sum payment of {$11000.00} to Mohela in order to pay off 2 of my student loans ( Loan Sequence # XXXX and # XXXX ). I received a statement dated XX/XX/2023 claiming that I only paid off XXXX of those loans ( Loan Sequence # XXXX ) but that I still owed a total of {$210.00} on the loan ( Loan Sequence # XXXX ). I contacted Mohela via phone about a possible mistake with the payment, and they claimed the amount that I owed was correct so I made a direct payment towards Loan Sequence # XXXX in XX/XX/2023 in the amount of {$210.00} prior to the payment due date. I reviewed a bill letter from Mohela dated XXXX stating that they had received my payment of {$210.00} towards Loan Sequence # XXXX, but that I still owed a total of {$2.00} even after I used their payoff calculator to help me determine the payoff costs of my loan. I contacted Mohela twice in regards to the issue via phone on XX/XX/XXXX & XXXX, 2023 and they told me the issue would get resolved, but that it could take anywhere from XXXX days to resolve. I made a follow-up call to Mohela on XX/XX/2023 with no new update. Finally, after the issue had not been corrected I filed a complaint with the XXXX XXXX XXXX The XXXX helped me mediate the conversation with Mohela, but nothing was ever resolved. Instead of correcting my issue, Mohela made financial adjustments to my account to where I paid off Loan Sequence # XXXX instead of Loan Sequence # XXXX, but no instead of owning {$2.00}, I owed the completed {$210.00} again. Numerous messages and documents were sent to Mohela showing that this was incorrect, and eventually XXXX closed the complaint stating that Mohela was making their best effort to correct the issue. Only then did Mohela reverse their financial adjustments to reflect my initial payment of {$11000.00} which paid off Loan Sequence # XXXX and part of Loan Sequence # XXXX. The only issue now is that Mohela is claiming that I never paid the {$210.00} at all even after I've showed them documentation of payment through bank statements and their own website. Now Loan Sequence # XXXX is accruing interest on {$210.00} and not {$2.00}, even though this loan should have been paid off with Loan Sequence # XXXX initially back in XXXX of 2023. Mohela has been participating in some unethical and shady business practices when it comes to student loan payoffs or disclosing the actual amount due by their customers, and has been dragging their feet for months when it comes to making any meaningful corrections to my account.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer made a $11,000 payment to Mohela to pay off two student loans, but Mohela incorrectly applied the payment, claiming the consumer still owed $210 on one loan. Despite multiple calls and a mediated complaint, Mohela failed to correct the issue, and now claims the consumer never made the $210 payment.

Sub-issue: Confusing or misleading advertising
Consumer complaint narrative: I enrolled in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX with the deceiving tactics of indirectly hinting to guaranteed job placement in the film industry upon the completion of XXXXXXXX XXXX  XXXX with XXXX in XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. To cover the expensive cost of tuition, I had to take a combination of private and federal loans. Some of the private loans structure were confusing and got sold out to different lenders before even finishing the school. In XXXX, after completing the program and XXXX, they denied committing to any responsibility of job placement. At the same time, I start receiving multiple bills from different lenders. The XXXX XXXX bill had different loan interest rates than the previous lender issuer at 8.99 %. The number of payment became overwhelming and I refinanced all private loan with XXXX for a fixed interest rate of 5.5 %. I have been paying this for the last 15 years and still owe large portion of the principal. The school degree was not recognized in all my attempts to obtain employment. The school misconduct caused me a life long sense of failure. It has been discovered the school had operated with bad faith and many complains had shown it.
Narrative Summary: A consumer enrolled in a film industry program, misled by implied job placement guarantees. After completing the program, the school denied responsibility for job placement. The consumer was left with overwhelming debt from private and federal loans, and the degree was not recognized by employers.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative: I keep getting letters about my PSLF application asking for more information. I have provided the same information multiple times prior to and then after consolidating my loans with Mohela. A year ago in XXXX they assured me they had everything they needed. Then this XXXX they asked for W-2s for XXXX XXXX. I have faxed them weekly for months. I finally uploaded them because sending a fax was not recognized or acknowledged. Then I received a letter to have my employer call them within 60 days. They did today and were told they no longer are doing PSLF. This should have been discharged 3 years ago.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer's Public Service Loan Forgiveness (PSLF) application is stalled due to repeated requests for the same information, despite prior assurances that everything was in order. The lender, Mohela, now claims they no longer handle PSLF, after a year of delays and unacknowledged submissions.

Sub-issue: Can't get other flexible options for repaying your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
On Saturday, XX/XX/XXXX I was sent an email telling me that my UAS XXXX account was 60 days past due. Since XX/XX/XXXX, I have sent {$170.00} every XXXX of the month, occasionally throwing in an XXXX XXXX  or so if my monthly budget allowed. 

I have been consistent with my payments and on XX/XX/XXXX, my monthly payment was increased to {$400.00}. I spoke with a lending XXXX via email and they explained that as long as I continued making payments that my account would not become a delinquent account. 

Since XX/XX/XXXX it has been a tug of war with them and the credit bureaus. They would report specifically to XXXX that I had not been making any payments thus lowering my credit score significantly. 
I tried getting into contact with a loan officer again in an attempt to renegotiate my payment plan and the only offer they gave me was three month forbearance. I explained to them that I can pay up to {$200.00} and it wouldn't make sense to apply for forbearance because I would not realistically be able to make {$400.00} in as little as three months. They told me they couldn't do anything because that is all XXXX offers.

I asked for a number to speak directly to a XXXX XXXX  and I was sent to the website where I originally applied to the loan. There was no number to contact only a chat bot. When speaking with the chat bot about lowering my monthly payment, they directed me to a debt collection company called XXXX XXXX. 

I explained to the XXXX XXXX operator that I intend on paying the loan but needed some sort of repayment plan and she spoke about another " forbearance program '' but refused to provide a link to apply to it and instead asked me to pay {$86.00} in order to start the " application process ''. 

So after three hours on the phone I am left in the same place as before. XXXX XXXX has another link that leads me to XXXX XXXX. I have no idea if these companies are even linked to XXXX XXXX boasts a collaboration with students who can not repay their loans but are misleading in their attempts to negotiate in any other form than an extremely temporary solution that is provided by a third party they do not openly disclose on their website. 

I just want to pay off my student loans without them throttling my credit score and affecting other financial aspects of my life. This practice is confusing and predatory.
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims their UAS account is being reported as delinquent despite consistent payments. The lender increased the monthly payment to $400, which the consumer cannot afford, and only offered a three-month forbearance or a third-party debt collection program with a $86 application fee, causing frustration and credit score damage.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative: After several intense recruiting calls from thXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) I enrolled into their XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in 2006, taking out many federal and private loans to attend this school. I have since suffered a great deal of financial harm, emotional and mental damage, and professional difficulty as a result of their misrepresentation of their hiring rates, graduation/completion rate, and abusive and confusing lending practices. I am a member of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX, so my federal loans for this predatory college have been forgiven, however, despite many calls to Navient 's private loan department over the years, they refuse to give me a discharge despite several lawsuits and several rounds of loan forgiveness for The XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX . I ask that the CFPB review my case, as I feel I took out these loans for a college that was predatory in their approach in recruitment and financing and completely misrespresented the value of their degree ( which is essentially worthless, barring me from an opportunity to pursue a XXXX XXXX in my field of study ).
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims a for-profit college misled them about hiring rates and graduation rates, leading to financial and emotional harm. They had federal loans forgiven, but Navient refuses to discharge their private loans, despite multiple lawsuits and forgiveness rounds for the college's predatory practices.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Concerned Parties, I write to bring to light a matter of grave concern affecting thousands of students ensnared in the predatory lending practices of Navient, particularly those who, like myself, attended for-profit online institutions such as the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 

It is a stark reality that the XXXX XXXX, along with their parent company, XXXX, have been subjected to investigations by numerous state attorneys general, resulting in damning findings of fraudulent activities. 

Recently, in response to the egregious actions of institutions like the XXXX XXXX, the XXXX  administration has taken a commendable step by announcing a sweeping discharge of loans for individuals enrolled at these institutions between XX/XX/XXXX, and XX/XX/XXXX. This move offers a glimmer of hope for those burdened by the weight of unjust debt. 

As I await the impending discharge of my federal loans and the subsequent repair of my credit, I am compelled to address the insidious practices of Navient. Not only have I dutifully repaid a significant portion of my original loans, including interest in the amount of {$41000.00} in Federal loans and {$31000.00} in Private loans, but I also demand restitution for the predatory behavior exhibited by Navient. 

The symbiotic relationship between Navient and for-profit online schools, facilitated by preferential lending arrangements, is a stain on the integrity of the education finance system. It is evident that these loans, fraught with a high risk of default, were designed to exploit vulnerable students, leaving many in financial ruin. 

Navient 's track record of malfeasance extends beyond its collusion with for-profit institutions. The company has faced legal action from state attorneys general, allegations of deceptive loan practices, and accusations of illegal collection methods. Their recent attempts to absolve themselves of responsibility through superficial " pilot programs '' are a slap in the face to those who have suffered at their hands. 

Under the FTC " Holder Rule, '' Navient bears accountability for its role in perpetuating predatory lending practices, particularly in conjunction with online for-profit schools. Time is of the essence for Navient to rectify the injustices inflicted upon students who were lured into a web of deceit and financial exploitation. 

The call to action has been sounded by esteemed voices such as XXXX XXXX XXXX, who rightfully demands immediate discharge of these predatory loans. It is incumbent upon Navient to heed this clarion call and take swift and decisive action to alleviate the burdens of those they have wronged. This should also include refunds for payments made on these predatory loans. 

In conclusion, I implore all stakeholders to recognize the urgency of this matter and to stand in solidarity with those seeking redress. The time for accountability and restitution is now. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: The complaint alleges Navient engaged in predatory lending practices, particularly with for-profit online schools, resulting in thousands of students being exploited and left with unjust debt. The complainant demands restitution and refunds for payments made on these loans, citing Navient's malfeasance and accountability under the FTC "Holder Rule."

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
My student loan was through XXXX for years last year the transferred it to Mohela, they said because I met the following qualifications : The Biden-Harris Administration has already cancelled {$45.00} XXXX in student debt so far for nearly 1 million borrowers who have been in repayment for at least 20 years, but never got the relief they were entitled to because of administrative problems with income-driven repayment plans. The Administrations new proposals, if finalized as proposed, would cancel student debt for borrowers who first entered repayment 20 or more years ago. Borrowers with only undergraduate debt would qualify for forgiveness if they first entered repayment 20 years ago ( on or before XX/XX/XXXX ), and borrowers with any graduate school debt would qualify if they first entered repayment 25 or more years ago ( on or before XX/XX/XXXX ). Both Direct Loans and Direct Consolidation Loans that repay only undergraduate study or graduate study for 20 or 25 years respectively are eligible for relief in this proposal. Borrowers would not need to be on an income-driven repayment plan to qualify.

I've called Mohela and was told yes I qualify, however they do not tell me why it hasn't been cancelled.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer's student loan was transferred to Mohela, and they were told they qualify for debt cancellation under the Biden-Harris Administration's proposal due to being in repayment for over 20 years. However, Mohela has not cancelled the debt, and the consumer is seeking an explanation for the delay.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I attended the XXXX XXXX of XXXX from XXXX. I went on the tour and decided to attend. It was during that process that I started being pressured to max out my loan application to the max allowed, about $ XXXX each ( 4 total loans ). I was barely XXXX and did not fully understand what this would mean latter in life. Nor were the details of this loan or subsequent ones. It all felt like a blank check that was being written, but the feeling was that of. This is what everyone here is doing. They had this extensive process to get graduates into high earning jobs in the XXXX area. This is now well documented part of XXXX XXXX deceptive and fraudulent practices. 

XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX The U.S. Department of Education ( Department ) found that XXXX XXXX XXXX  and its parent company, XXXX XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX ), made pervasive and substantial misrepresentations to prospective students about postgraduation employment rates, salaries, and career services during that time. In XX/XX/XXXX, XXXX sold its remaining XXXX XXXX campuses, and all existing XXXX XXXX campuses closed under separate ownership in XXXXXXXX XXXX. Today 's action brings the total amount of student relief approved by the Biden-Harris Administration to almost {$160.00} billion for nearly 4.6 million borrowers. 

After my graduation my loans started to activate and I needed to pay on these loans, added in my income I was now into a forced poverty. I struggled too many times to make these payments and needed several " breaks ''. I remember the first time I needed to decide if I was going to pay or be broke. I called and spoke to a rep. They said there was nothing they could do I did not have any money and I would still have been behind on payments. I was told there were no options available to me, beyond a temporary forbearance. Which when ended, I still could not pay. So, I needed to stop paying, my credit was destroyed for the better half of a decade and my loans accrued more interest than the original loan. I remember when I started making more money and I called to resume payments and suddenly, they could help. Help is probably a strong word. They asked for savings, XXXX, for me to beg relatives for money. Literally I was asked to find family or friends I could beg for money. I couldnt pay my loans, I had no savings or XXXX and I did not have anyone who could help. The help they could provide was to make a payment and push the past due onto the balance so I wouldnt be in default anymore. Navient ruined my life. This debt will consume my entire life. I will never be financially stable. I think about this so often. This one decision when I was barely an adult ruined the next XXXX  years of my life. I will never retire, own a home, know what security is. Now we know that Navient was not a good faith actor. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Navient, one of the largest student loan servicers, has reached a settlement with 39 states, in which it will cancel {$1.00} XXXX in private student loan debt. The settlement marks an end to six separate lawsuits filed against the student loan company, which was accused of giving out loans to XXXX of borrowers who were unlikely to be able to repay them, and also improperly recommending XXXX XXXX XXXX instead of better relief options. 
The company will also pay {$140.00} XXXX to the states and provide some restitution for borrowers in its former XXXX XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: The consumer complaint alleges that a for-profit college and its loan servicer, Navient, engaged in deceptive practices. The borrower was pressured to take out four large loans with unclear terms, leading to financial hardship and debt accumulation. The borrower struggled to make payments and was offered inadequate assistance.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Prior to my acceptance in the school, XXXX XXXX was known as XXXX of the strongest and most elite schools in the country for XXXX  education. The admissions representative used the prior elite level of the school in convincing me that it was the right decision for me. Unfortunately, in the years prior to my arrival, the selectivity and elite status of the school had been tarnished. During the ownership by XXXX XXXX XXXX, the admissions skyrocketed and the level of quality in education went down. I thought I was accepted on the strength of my portfolio and experience, but it later came out that they were accepting anyone who was willing to take on student loan debt. I was mislead continually through the student loan process about work placement rates, ability to pay back student loans, and the quality of education I would be receiving. I attended XXXX XXXX from XXXX, XXXX to XXXX, XXXX. 

I am a class member in the the class action lawsuit " Sweet v. XXXX, '' where the Department of Education has listed XXXX XXXX in Exhibit C which was labelled in court documents that attendance at one of these schools justifies presumptive relief because of strong signs that they carried out misconduct.
Narrative Summary: A student claims they were misled by an admissions representative about the elite status and quality of education at XXXX XXXX. They allege the school's quality declined due to increased admissions and lower selectivity, and they were deceived about job placement rates and loan repayment abilities.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPD, I am writing to express my deep frustration and concern regarding my recent interactions with Navient. I reached out to request the Navient School Misconduct discharge application to get my loans discharged due to attending XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX This institution, along with other XXXX XXXX XXXX, has been found guilty of misconduct and fraud. 

However, my experience with Navient has been extremely disappointing. I was transferred from representative to representative, with none of them addressing my request adequately. One representative even claimed that the application either does not exist or is in the early phases of being rolled out. This statement is contradictory for two reasons : firstly, they initially claimed the application doesn't exist, and secondly, I am aware of individuals who have already received this application. 

This inconsistency suggests that Navient is selectively distributing the discharge application, which is unfair and potentially unlawful. Withholding or denying access to this application from borrowers who have a legitimate right to it is unacceptable and could be considered a form of misconduct in itself.
Narrative Summary: A borrower requested a Navient School Misconduct discharge application due to attending an institution found guilty of misconduct and fraud. However, Navient representatives provided inconsistent information, claiming the application doesn't exist or is not available, despite others already receiving it, suggesting selective distribution.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
Thousands of students were scammed by XXXX into taking out predatory private loans to attend for XXXX XXXX XXXX such as the one I attended, The XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX. As a matter of fact, The XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX was investigated by Senator XXXX XXXX. 
Because of the numerous claims of fraud and misconduct perpetrated by these online for profit schools, such as The XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was able to file a Borrower Defense claim with the Dept. of Education against The XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX, and my Fed. loans of {$14000.00} should be discharged and my credit repaired. 
My Borrower Defense Claim was also part of the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX settlement for which I was a full class member. 
I am aware that XXXX was sued by 39 state AGs regarding their predatory loans to attend these online for-profit schools and that XXXX XXXX were a " preferred '' lending company in a " deal '' with these schools during the early XXXXXXXX XXXX. These private loans with a high risk of default were part of a package deal offered to " XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ''. But loans made to students in states outside of the agreement, or those who were not in default for 7 months or more during a " specific '' time frame, were excluded. I am sure this was a big win for XXXX, but what a sham of a settlement deal for the rest of borrowers scammed into taking loans to at least 150 for XXXX XXXX XXXX  After the AG settlement, didn't XXXX also get out of the Federal student loan business due to scrutiny from lawmakers and borrower advocates? Didn't XXXX have to pay restitution to the Federal student loan borrowers for not informing students of XXXX payments students could have enrolled in, but instead steered toward forbearance? Furthermore, hasn't XXXX been sued at least a half dozen times for other predatory loan practices and illegal collection practices? 
I am also aware of a " pilot '' program by which XXXX is sending out " applications '' to select students who may have filed Borrower Defense claims against their schools and were approved. This application is a sham. Why do we need to prove anything? XXXX knows who we are. Under the FTC " Holder Rule '' XXXX is liable for giving predatory loans in connection with online for-profit schools. Time is running out for XXXX to do right by students who were scammed into taking out private loans to attend online for profit colleges who have committed misconduct and misrepresented themselves to the public to entice students to enroll. Senator XXXX XXXX has sent a letter to XXXXXXXX XXXX CEO asking to discharge these loans NOW! It's time XXXX do the right thing and discharge all these predatory private loans made to attend online for profit schools. 

Because my private loans originated with XXXX, my MOHELAXXXX student loans should also be discharged
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims they were scammed into taking out a predatory private loan from XXXX to attend a for-profit online school. They filed a Borrower Defense claim and were part of a settlement, but their $14,000 federal loan was not discharged, and they demand it be discharged along with their private loan.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: My student loans will never go down and theyve price gouged me and I struggled out of college to pay these loans and they have never been helpful. My school was the XXXX XXXX which were a fraud and Navient is still trying to collect a debt on their behalf
Narrative Summary: The consumer alleges Navient is price gouging and unhelpful in managing their student loans from XXXX XXXX, a school they claim was fraudulent. Despite struggling to pay, the loan balance remains unchanged, and Navient continues to collect on the debt.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was assigned NelNet after Great Lakes Borrowers was absorbed. In XXXX of XXXX I applied for an IDR plan. It is now XXXX of XXXX and it has STILL not been processed. In this excessive wait, I have accrued almost {$400.00} in interest. I have called ( multiple times ), Emailed ( multiple times ) to no avail. Just this morning I got an email with all of my personal information including my full SSN, and a note saying they can't locate my account - even though I've contacted them from their online portal. 

I am at my wits end. They are doing nothing to resolve this, and I have gotten no communication other than. " We are working on it. '' Or the newest " We can't find your loan. '' I am livid with this useless loan company and feel I am being taken advantage of. I literally can't do anything other than wait for them to process my application all while my interest grows on a matter which should have been resolved within a month to two months, tops.

Come on Nelnet.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's IDR plan application, submitted to NelNet in XXXX, remains unprocessed after an excessive wait, resulting in nearly $400 in accrued interest. Despite multiple calls and emails, NelNet claims it cannot locate the account, leaving the consumer frustrated and feeling taken advantage of.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have student loans and Mohela is my student loan servicer. During the pandemic, student loans were placed in forbearance where payments were not required. At this time I was also enrolled in a employee-sponsored loan repayment program that continued to make payments on my loans- there was not flexibility in the program to pause payments, and I had to either remain in or withdraw from the program. 

I learned recently on a phone call with Mohela that there was an opportunity to request a refund for payments made during the forbearance period, however those requests had to be made by XX/XX/2023. In reviewing all of my communication from Mohela in the months leading up to this date - emails and messages through my loan portal - I was never made aware that I could request a refund. I feel that this represents negligence by Mohela. I have filed a complaint with the Department of Education and also wanted to file a complaint with the CFPB.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer's student loan servicer, Mohela, failed to inform them about the opportunity to request a refund for payments made during the pandemic forbearance period, despite the consumer continuing to make payments through an employee-sponsored program. The consumer only discovered this after the refund request deadline.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service
Consumer complaint narrative:
After filing my first CFPB complaint and receiving a form response, I contacted Navient by phone on XX/XX/XXXX to get the form for school misconduct. I was told by the operator in the servicing department that she would refer my account for review and I would be sent the form if my loans qualified for school misconduct discharge. After two weeks of waiting, I still have not been sent the form. 

There is no question that my private loans qualify to receive the form. My federal loans were just discharged because of misconduct by the XXXX XXXX. From the Department of Education 's executive summary ( attached ) : " This group discharge is based on EDs finding that The XXXX XXXX and its parent company, XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ), made pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment. '' " Due to its pervasive and widespread substantial misrepresentations that borrowers relied on to their detriment, ED concluded that The XXXX XXXX misrepresentations likely would have negatively affected all or nearly all students who enrolled on or after XXXX XXXX, XXXX, through XXXX XXXX, XXXX, and thus a group discharge is appropriate. '' Furthermore, Senator XXXX XXXX and 8 other Senators urged Navient to discharge predatory loans from schools like the one I attended because of " well-established school misconduct and predatory lending '' in a letter ( attached ) sent to Navient last month : We write to urge the Navient Corporation to cancel the decades-old, predatory student loans in its portfolio that are governed by the FTCs Holder Rule and subject to claims and defenses based on well-established school misconduct and predatory lending, said the senators. [ Y ] our company should provide relief to borrowers immediately, before the impending servicing transfer of these and other student loans to the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX  of the State of Missouri.
Narrative Summary: Complainant claims Navient failed to send a school misconduct discharge form despite being told they would receive it. The complainant's federal loans were already discharged due to school misconduct, and they believe their private loans qualify for similar relief.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: on XX/XX/year>, I contacted Mohela because I noticed for the payment on XX/XX/year> the interest charged was doubled compared to prior months. They said the interest was accrued for XXXX because of forbearance. To my surprise, I never requested forbearance and I have always been on auto debit. They said because they were changing their platform in that period they did not draw payment from my account. I explained multiple times that it was Mohela 's fault if they forgot or failed in any way to withdraw the payment. Why should I pay for their mistake and bad accounting practice. I requested the payment to be properly adjusted and they refused. Surely, there are many other borrowers in the same situation, but failing to recognize they have been punished and charged double interest for Mohela 's dishonest accounting and lack of professionalism. It is easy to fix the overcharged interest but they refuse.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: A borrower contacted Mohela about a payment with double the usual interest. Mohela claimed it was due to forbearance, but the borrower never requested it. The issue occurred when Mohela failed to withdraw an auto-debit payment during a platform change, and they refused to adjust the overcharged interest.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: PrepMD has taken the entire payment from Meritize XXXX student loan financial services for a 2-part course, but I am unable to access my course. I have started the first part, but have not finished. I intended to take the course to prepare for the XXXX exam, but the course does not offer education to prepare for the XXXX exam. XXXX, my representative baited me into taking the course, and the course did not provide and education for the XXXX. I don't have access to my course, and so the first part has not been completed, and the 2nd part hasn't been started.
Narrative Summary: PrepMD took full payment for a 2-part course, but the consumer can't access the course. The course also doesn't provide education for the intended exam, contrary to the representative's claims. The consumer has only started the first part and can't complete it or access the second part.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I had a private loan with NAVIENT from XXXX. However it was for a college that has engaged in misconduct. XXXX XXXX shut down in XXXX and filed bankruptcy the following year. 
I knew in XXXX that this college was defrauding students. By overstating income potential, Not transferring any credits. After deciding to leave XXXX XXXX, Navient would commit XXXX XXXX by calling in the early morning hours and late at night harassing my family & friends. In the end, the next year I paid the {$5000.00} private student loan off, the XXXX XXXX was too much to handle. I had to sell my family memories to pay off the loan. At the end of the day I was financially XXXX by XXXX XXXX XXXX Navient. 
I'm asking for Navient to refund the payment based on the colleges misconduct.
Narrative Summary: A consumer is requesting a refund from Navient for a $5000 private student loan. The loan was for a college that shut down due to misconduct, including overstating income potential and not transferring credits. The consumer claims Navient harassed them and their family to collect the loan.

Sub-issue: Can't temporarily delay making payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to lodge a formal complaint against the law firm Fein Such Kahn & Shephard PC , specifically concerning the conduct of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX in relation to their handling of debt collection practices against me. This complaint is rooted in what I believe to be a violation of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ). 

Without any prior written communication that detailed the nature of the alleged debt, Fein Such Kahn & Shephard PC, under XXXX XXXX direction, initiated a lawsuit against me. It is important to note that I never received a demand letter that outlined the debt or provided an opportunity for me to respond or arrange for payment. This omission deprived me of my rights to dispute or verify the debt before any legal action was taken. 

As a result, a lawsuit was pursued, culminating in a judgment issued against me for {$6000.00}, without providing any opportunity to settle or contest the claim outside of the courtroom. The lack of preliminary communication clearly contradicts the FDCPAs mandate that debt collectors must provide a written notice of the debt within five days of initially contacting the consumer, outlining the amount of the debt and the creditors name, and informing the consumer of their right to dispute the debt. 

Given these circumstances, I urge the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to investigate this matter thoroughly. I seek the reversal or, at minimum, the suspension of the judgment against me, in addition to any other appropriate remedies. Such actions by debt collectors should not go unchecked as they significantly impact consumers rights and well-being. 

Enclosed are copies of the relevant documents pertaining to the case. I am willing to provide additional information if required and am hopeful for a resolution that corrects the disregard of consumer rights demonstrated in this case. 

Thank you for your attention to this urgent matter. I await your prompt response and assistance.
Narrative Summary: A consumer alleges Fein Such Kahn & Shephard PC, specifically XXXX XXXX, violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act (FDCPA) by initiating a lawsuit without prior written communication detailing the debt, depriving them of their right to dispute or verify the debt before a $6,000 judgment was issued.

Although the school I attended, XXXX XXXX XXXX has lost several lawsuits brought by Attorneys General of almost every state, the state I resided in when I attended XXXX and the state I currently live in now have not been part of those lawsuits.

When I called Navient 's main number, they told me that only that department can discuss the issue and they will have to forward my call to the exact same number where the situation just repeats. 

As XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX, XXXX ), now XXXX XXXX XXXX has lost multiple lawsuits, mentioned below, I firmly believe that their deceptive practices would fall under the Holder Rule, which would qualify all of my loans for XXXX, both federal and private, to be fully discharged and completely refunded. As mention above, my federal loans already have been as a full class member of XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. 

Additional lawsuits against XXXX and it's parent companies where XXXX or its parent company was found guilty of deceptive practices : Settlement of 49 attorneys general investigations of XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX Opinions by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Story, XXXX : XXXX XXXX that it was complying with Title IV and was accredited, but Relators allege that these certifications were false . They claim that, in reality, XXXX was violating the XXXX incentive compensation ban, failed to verify students proof of graduation ( POG ), and lied to its accreditorthe XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX  ) to falsely retain its XXXX. 

XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: The consumer's private student loan debt forgiveness application with Navient was denied without reason, despite the school's history of deceptive practices and multiple lawsuits. The consumer has paid nearly $20,000 on a $6,000 loan and believes they qualify for full discharge under the Holder Rule.

Consumer complaint narrative: While the VA was in the process of making its determination that I was XXXX  % totally and permanently XXXX, Sallie Mae rejected my XXXX application despite my XXXX % rating from the VA and additional medical  documentation. On XX/XX/2024 and XX/XX/2024 I submitted letters to inform Sallie Mae that the VA then determined I was XXXX  % totally and permanently XXXX and also requested forbearance be reinstated. At Sallie Mae 's request, I submitted a new application with that documentation on XX/XX/2024. Sallie Mae refused to directly or timely acknowledge the XX/XX/XXXX application. After following up with Sallie Mae by phone on XX/XX/2024 representative ID XXXX placed me on extensive holds before acknowledging my letters and application, eventually describing the application as " pending, '' but providing nothing in writing. On XX/XX/2024, Sallie Mae sent a letter merely stating, " Thanks for contacting us about your loan. We'll review your concerns and get back to you shortly. '' Sallie Mae is refusing to acknowledge the forbearance request or XXXX application and has been billing me and charging me late fees.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: My account went into administrative forbearance in XXXX due to MOHELA moving to a new servicing platform. I received a letter in the mail in XXXX that my account was transitioning to the new platform. I have always had autopay set up on my account. However, I have since been getting letters that my account is past due. I have called MOHELA XXXX or 6 times now to understand how my account was past due, if I was in forbearance during the transition, and my account had always had autopay set up. Each time I call I seem to get a slightly different answer. I have been told my account is not past due on their end, even though I reiterate that my account on the new platform shows I am. I have been told that my case is being escalated, but I have never heard anything back in the two times I have called since being told that. I have also been told my account has been placed back in forbearance until this situation is resolved. However, MOHELA just pulled the autopay from my account last week, although I was told that would not occur now that I'm back in forbearance. Originally I was {$240.00} past due, I am now {$310.00} past due. Each time I call I request a letter in the mail confirming my account is not past due. Each time I am promised a letter. However, I have never received any additional information, just more past due notices. I have tried sending emails, to keep a paper trail, but I have never gotten a response to my emails.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: MOHELA's account transition caused a discrepancy, resulting in the consumer receiving past-due notices despite having autopay set up. The consumer has called multiple times, receiving conflicting information and promises of resolution, but the issue persists, with the past-due amount increasing from $240 to $310.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I am filing this complaint with the CFPB and the Federal Student Aid Ombudsman because EdFinancial continues to act in an atrociously incompetent and downright evil manner. Compliance AVP XXXXXXXX XXXX recently authorized the closure of my CFPB Complaint case ID : XXXX simply because she was embarrassed that my legitimate case outlining the ongoing flaws with the Mortgage Verification Letter had gone on well beyond the 60-day limit provided by the CFPB guidelines, however, the first file she shared was unable to be opened on a XXXX XXXX XXXX and the second one missed the mark on my correct student loan balance end date by a full year ( see provided attachments ). When will federal regulators stop pulling their punches and start fining EdFinancial ( as with XXXX and other federal student loan servicer peers ) for gross incompetence? Enough is enough! I am demanding fines and penalties of {$5000.00} per day retroactive to my original 60-day CFPB limit for CFPB Complaint case ID : XXXX. I also want an injunction on EdFinancial requiring XXXX XXXX to personally take charge of my case including all email correspondence and updates through a comprehensive final resolution inclusive of detailed root cause analysis reporting, creation and submission of a formal corrective action plan for federal review and approval, as well as mandatory retraining for the entire EdFinancial customer service team on federal student loan servicing standards and mandates.
Narrative Summary: EdFinancial allegedly mishandled a student loan account, providing incorrect Mortgage Verification Letters with errors, including an incorrect balance end date. The consumer claims the issue persisted beyond the 60-day CFPB limit, and they're seeking fines, an injunction, and corrective action from the company.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to express my concerns regarding the student loan [ predatory ] practices at the XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington XXXX XXXX ), a branch of the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, which have led to significant financial difficulties for my family and I. The servicer they used for XXXX XXXX XXXX was XXXX XXXX. 

Since my initial enrollment in XX/XX/XXXX, I was consistently compelled rather than encouraged to pursue private student loans to finance my education at XXXX. This sense of coercion has led to profound financial ramifications, significantly impacting my financial stability and future prospects. These private loans have been the source of considerable financial strain and has had an exceedingly negative impact on my financial well-being. 

Throughout my tenure at the XXXX XXXX of Washington, interactions with counselors were infrequent, and when they occurred, it was near the conclusion of each academic term. During which the focus was predominantly on securing additional student loans, including private student loans, specifically from XXXX XXXX ( now with Navient ). In retrospect, the emphasis of the XXXX counselors seemed to be on facilitating the acquisition of funds rather than providing comprehensive guidance on the implications and long-term consequences of such financial commitments. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington guaranteed help and placement of/for XXXX XXXX or XXXX related jobs after graduation in XXXX. I was not helped by XXXX XXXX. I was sent links to XXXX positions that I did not have experience to qualify for. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington brought in artists that had no degree at all during my years there from XXXX to XXXX, which clearly demonstrated to students in attendance, that a degree would not be necessarily required to succeed in our respective industries. 

The XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington guaranteed help and placement of/for XXXX XXXX or XXXX related jobs. I was not helped by XXXX XXXX. Upon graduation in XXXX, I was emailed links to XXXX positions that I did not have experience to qualify for. 

I was not able to obtain a job in a related field until 4 years after graduation on XXXX XXXX  and had already began paying back loans not using the degree that was given, as well as The XXXX XXXX closing down and not being able to have transcripts to show employers The XXXX XXXX was sued by the federal government and lost, in the amount of {$95.00} XXXX, for fraud with student tuition. 

I had already graduated, but I did not have anything valid to show employers there after. 


I was not able to obtain a job in my respective field of study for 4 years after graduating. I had to take alternative routes to get into the industry that I studied, and was not able to pay back anything above interest on student loans. My credit has suffered due to late payments, forbearances, etc. 

I never transferred, so that does not apply, but, I was not able to obtain official transcripts for the classes I did take. 

The Art Institutes have been deemed irresponsible by the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX, and hereby forgiven loans of all students that attended any of The Art Institutes during the years of XXXX thru XXXX, In which I did attend. I have received documentation for that forgiveness and need private loans to reflect that forgiveness.
Narrative Summary: The consumer alleges that XXXX XXXX XXXX Washington, a branch of XXXX XXXX XXXX, engaged in predatory student loan practices, coercing them to take private loans, and failing to provide adequate guidance or job placement assistance after graduation, resulting in significant financial difficulties.

Sub-issue: Can't temporarily delay making payments
Consumer complaint narrative: This XXXX loan was specifically acquired to attend The XXXXXXXX XXXX on XX/XX/04. I've always managed to stay on top of it but recently have become unemployed due to the lack of job opportunities within XXXX XXXX and due to constant job outsourcing because of foreign subsidies. In this case I have asked and requested American Education Services many times for some sort of help in the form of forbearance or temporary pause but have not received any help whatsoever to my lack of employment. Most recently in light of the my borrowers defense approval, my federal loans have been completely XXXX and credit repaired due to crimes committed my XXXX and XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, found guilty in many cases and subsequently closed down. I submitted an email requesting a school misconduct XXXX  loan discharge from American Education Services, which they also refused me. In this case of all the legal precedence against XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX, the federal Borrowers Defense approval and the provided FTC holder rule, this loan acquired for these found criminal institutions ( including private ) are ill gotten due to seller misconduct. In the meantime, American Education Services still refuses to provide even a forbearance, while destroying my credit and cause undue harm while I'm unemployed.
Narrative Summary: The consumer is struggling to pay a loan for a now-defunct school due to unemployment and job outsourcing. Despite requesting forbearance or temporary pause, American Education Services refused, even after the borrower's defense approval and federal loan discharge due to the school's misconduct.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I am auto class member of XXXX XXXX  XXXX. My federal has been discharged due to being defrauded by XXXX University. I should get full resolution with my private Navient Loans as well. Ive been reading online that they are starting a pilot program for borrowers defense and some lucky individuals are getting their private loans discharged and some even refunded because they were tricked into going to school which has happened to me. I would like my payments to Navient and Sallie Mae before that refunded to me because this falls into the same scam schools.
Narrative Summary: The complainant's federal student loans were discharged due to being defrauded by their university. They seek full resolution, including discharge and refund, for their private Navient loans, citing a pilot program that has provided similar relief to other borrowers in similar situations.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: Thank you for all your efforts to protect the rights and freedoms we share today, and I appreciate your time to review my concern. on XX/XX/year>, the court granted preliminary approval for federal loan cancellation and refunded payments for class members who applied for the Borrower Defense to Repayment. The class action lawsuit : XXXX XXXX  XXXX, which is involving predatory and fraudulent for-profit colleges such as the one I attended ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX now known as XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) , proves without a doubt that we have absolutely and massively been scammed and ripped off for thousands if not hundreds of thousands of dollars per applicant. It's wonderful news hearing we have received preliminary approval, but we need to also take a look at the private loans borrowers have taken out to attend these scam schools. Many of us have even more debt in private loans than federal loans, and we are still expected to pay it despite overwhelming evidence of fraud, mishandlings, losing payment records, deceit and other criminal activity involving our loans and payments. We need to take action while this issue is in the spotlight, to have these private loans discharged in addition to the federal student loans. Loan balances through companies such as Navient should all be canceled and refunded if those loans are taken out for a university on the list of fraudulent schools from the XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX case .
Narrative Summary: A consumer complaint regarding private student loans taken out to attend predatory for-profit colleges. The complainant seeks cancellation and refund of private loans, citing evidence of fraud and deceit, as federal loans have already received preliminary approval for cancellation.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Problem with customer service

I attend XXXX  XXXX XXXX of XXXX from XXXX to XXXX. I left for a brief period and joined the military. Upon my honorable discharge I returned to XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX. I received a federal loan discharge via the recent borrower defense discharge available to certain XXXX XXXX XXXX. During my first term at the XXXX XXXX, I acquired XXXX XXXX private student loans.

On XX/XX/XXXX I called Navient for information on school misconduct discharge of private loans and was told to follow up in XX/XX/XXXX. I am filing my complaint to establish a record and my inform of my relationship with Navient.
Narrative Summary: The complainant, a former student of XXXX, is seeking a school misconduct discharge of private student loans from Navient. After receiving a federal loan discharge, they inquired about discharging private loans, but were told to follow up at a later date, prompting them to file this complaint.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative: I completed my IBRP application and have confirmation emails from student aid.gov on XX/XX/year>. My previous payment was around {$140.00} which I have been paying faithfully on time because I signed up for autopay. The new plan, the new SAVE plan is the one I chose. It estimated my payment to be around {$400.00}, as my family income has increased. Today MOHELA took {$1500.00} from my account. I called customer service because that is in no way what I signed up for. They had no even processed my application!! No record of it. The customer service person was kind, and agreed the situation didn't sound right. After putting me on hold came back saying something about there is an account " monitor '' that " checks on ability to pay on time '' and that's why they did that. She mentioned something about the promissory note saying they can do that. I mentioned to her I have applied for ( and am close to qualifying for PSLF ) She also said there is nothing they can do to refund my account but they put the account in forbearance until the application is processed. This behavior is not okay.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: MOHELA withdrew $1500 from the complainant's account, despite their IBRP application estimating a $400 monthly payment. The customer service representative claimed an "account monitor" took the excess amount, citing the promissory note, and refused to refund the difference, instead placing the account in forbearance.

Sub-issue: High pressure sales tactics or recruiting
Consumer complaint narrative:
I'm filing a complaint against Navient with the CFPB with the intent to receive a School Misconduct Discharge Application ( SMDA ). I am confident that I should qualify for the SMDA pilot as I attended the XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX ) from XX/XX/XXXX - XX/XX/XXXX and was pressured into getting additional private loans by the recruiting staff at the school to be able to attend. The government just announced a XXXX XXXX dollar discharge for XXXX students who attend the XXXX XXXX between XX/XX/XXXX and XX/XX/XXXX due to widespread fraud including, but not limited to, dishonest recruitment practices, false reporting for job placement, using non-related job data as placement statistics, false reporting on income to expect after graduation, and aggressive recruitment tactics. I am a part of this most recent wave of discharges by the Department of Education, which comes after pressure from the XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX case and I assume a significant volume of new Borrower 's Defense to Repayment ( BDTR ) applications.. 

Additionally, Navient has been found to have pushed former students toward forbearance rather than income based payments plans or deferment, which consequently caused them to add to their principal and, ultimately, the interest that they would have to pay. I experienced this myself several times between XXXX ( before the loans were separated from Sallie Mae ) and XXXX when my in-school deferment ran, including multiple times that I had to speak with representatives and make payments in XXXX, XXXX, XXXX, and XXXX. 

I took out XXXX private loans with a cosigner, the first with an original principal of XXXX taken out on XX/XX/XXXX with a current balance of XXXX at 12 % interest and a payoff date of XXXX/XXXX/XXXX, and the second with an original principal of XXXX taken out on XX/XX/XXXX with a current balance of XXXX at 16 % interest with a payoff date of XXXX/XXXX/XXXX. To date I have paid a total of XXXX on these loans since XX/XX/XXXX and XXXX has been paid since XXXX of XXXX, which is significantly more than the original principal.
Narrative Summary: The consumer is filing a complaint against Navient to receive a School Misconduct Discharge Application (SMDA) due to attending a school with a history of widespread fraud, including dishonest recruitment practices. They claim Navient also misled them into forbearance, increasing their loan principal and interest.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
I went to XXXX  XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX from XXXX. I racked up over {$100000.00} of private and federal loans. XXXX  XXXX  XXXX promised us they would become accredited which never happened, and left me high and dry after i graduated with no support for finding a job. 

The Department of Education recently found XXXX  XXXX XXXX of fraudulent and exploitative practices and discharged my federal loans. 

Navient services, my private loans. I have called them numerous times over the years, asking for my private loans to be discharged, and my money returned due to multiple attorney general and legal investigations proving that they are literally servicing fraudulent lo I want all of my money to be paid back to me from Navient, and all credit reportings are annulled. This company has ruined my adult life and continues to take my money and thousands of other students who were duped. They are complicit in this fraud.
Narrative Summary: A student claims XXXX XXXX XXXX misled them about accreditation, leaving them with over $100,000 in debt after graduation. The Department of Education discharged federal loans due to the school's fraudulent practices, but the student seeks Navient to discharge private loans and refund their money.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
My private student loans were refinanced with Sofi, away from XXXX XXXX who have begun programs to discharge debts acquired from both school misconduct and XXXX 's business practices. 

XXXX has refused me application to this program due to refinancing, which is discriminatory against myself and others who have made their best efforts to be current on payments. If I had simply allowed these debts to fall into default and live comfortably, they will have forgiven this debt. 

Additionally, I have an approved Borrower to Defense application through the Sweet vs. Cardona lawsuit. The US government has found debts accrued from my school to be egregious and deserving of loan forgiveness.
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims XXXX denied their debt discharge application due to refinancing with Sofi, despite having an approved Borrower Defense application. They argue this is discriminatory, as those in default may be eligible for forgiveness, while they're penalized for making timely payments.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I attended the XXXX XXXX and was recently informed by the Department of Education that my federal loans are being fully XXXX. I called Navient, my loan servicer, to verify that this information is reflected on their end and to confirm that I will not be penalized if I stop making payments on my Federal Loans as I was instructed to do by the federal government. The loan servicer said I WILL be penalized for not making payments since they haven't received further instructions on how to handle the loans on their end. They said I need to upload the email I received and it will take 10 days to review, with no guarantee of resolution on their end.
Narrative Summary: A borrower's federal loans are being forgiven, but Navient, their loan servicer, claims they haven't received instructions to stop collections. Navient requires the borrower to upload proof and wait 10 days for review, threatening penalties if payments aren't made during this time.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Don't agree with the fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: I was a student at XXXX University, a school which knowingly defrauded students/borrowers. I have a private loan through Navient in regards to this school, and it was taken out due to XXXX giving false statements about increased job opportunities, better placement, and better hiring rates. I've paid this loan for years, even with an exorbitant interest rate of XXXX  %. I am not in default, nor have I ever been. It would seem fair that this loan be forgiven - I only have about {$400.00} left in payments.
Narrative Summary: A student claims XXXX University defrauded them with false job opportunity statements, leading to a private Navient loan with an exorbitant interest rate. Despite making years of payments, they seek loan forgiveness due to the alleged deception, with only $400 left to pay.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
********NOTE : THIS IS NOT A " DUPLICATE COMPLAINT '' DO NOT CLOSE : ****** This is another issue entirely. 

I have a private student loan with Navient that consolidated XXXX loans from attendance at XXXX XXXX XXXX. The school listed on the loan application was XXXX XXXX XXXX. The loan application date was XX/XX/XXXX. The loan was disbursed on XX/XX/XXXX. Navient has the loan labeled as a XXXX  XXXX XXXX loan. This is incorrect and I have asked them to correctly label the loan as XXXX XXXX XXXX. They refuse to do so. 

They state that although the loan was for XXXX XXXX XXXX, I was attending the XXXX  XXXX XXXX at the time the loan was disbursed. This is incorrect. 

The Navient loan was disbursed on XX/XX/XXXX. My dates of attendance at the XXXX  XXXX XXXX started on XX/XX/XXXX and Navient acknowledges this in the letter they sent me. 
XXXX XXXX dates of attendance : XXXX Private loan application date : XX/XX/XXXX Loan originated : XX/XX/XXXX Loan disbursed : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX  XXXX dates XXXX attendance : XXXX I was not attending any school at the time of origination ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and disbursement ( XX/XX/XXXX ) and the most recent school I HAD attended was XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
NO loans associated with the XXXX  XXXX XXXX are included in this loan, at all and Navient acknowledges this. 
This loan is NOT a XXXX  XXXX XXXX loan and the documents attached attest to these facts. 
The loan needs to be labeled accurately as an XXXX XXXX XXXX loan. 
Any attempt to call this a XXXX  XXXX XXXX loan is FRAUD ( as defined by the state of XXXX  ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : means to knowingly obtain, by deception, some benefit for oneself or another, or to knowingly cause, by deception, some detriment to another ). The dates speak for themselves. Navient is clearly attempting to realize some benefit to their company by labeling this loan as something other than an XXXX XXXX loan.
Narrative Summary: The consumer disputes Navient's labeling of their private student loan as a loan from one school when the loan was actually for another school. The consumer claims Navient is mislabeling the loan despite acknowledging the correct school in their documents, which they believe is an attempt to deceive and obtain a benefit.

Sub-issue: Credit inquiries on your report that you don't recognize
Consumer complaint narrative: I have been XXXX  since XX/XX/XXXX I should not have any inquiries on my credit report until this month of XXXX XXXX XXXX

Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan

I just recently received three letters from Aidvantage, requesting a payment of XXXX. I made that payment in early XXXX of XXXX. In XXXX, they sent a email to my account on Aidvantage, but I did not receive a personal email from them for the next time, I was supposed to pay. They are now saying that I owe over XXXX because they did not inform me prior to today. Please help me solve this issue.
