Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Received bad information about your loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have spoken with over a dozen employees about my SAVES plan, and my account being automatically put into deferment without a letter or email stating so because XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. When I first inquired about what this meant several representatives told me the government will ONLY pay for the interest on unsubsidized loans. I was not receiving a bill, there was {$0.00} amount due on my online portal. I started to notice my principal balance was increasing. I called again, and was told by another representative that if I disenrolled from the deferment the government would cover BOTH unsubsidized and subsidized loans... WHY WOULD A STUDENT WANT TO HAVE TO PAY INTEREST IF THE GOVERNMENT WOULD DO IT FOR THEM? 

So I requested to be removed from deferment. The next day I received an email with a {$60.00} bill from interest. Again my bill online still was showing {$0.00}. The representative I got today first started to tell me the government pays interest off every 3 months. She then came back to tell me " my bad its actually monthly '' When I asked her why the principal balance on my account had increased {$4.00} since calling yesterday, she advised me it will continue to be added to my account until the monthly payment is made. There is no history of previous interest being paid by the government on my behalf. My account history shows increase after increase on principal balances, despite multiple representatives telling me I will not be charged interest. 

HELP ME! I am willing to sue them and pay attorney fees. This is fraud and they need to be held accountable.
Narrative Summary: A borrower's SAVES plan account was automatically put into deferment without notice. Representatives provided conflicting information about government payments on unsubsidized and subsidized loans, leading to increased principal balances and unexpected interest charges, despite assurances that interest would be covered.

Issue: Dealing with your lender or servicer
Sub-issue: Trouble with how payments are being handled
Consumer complaint narrative:
-On XXXX XX/XX/2024, I paid off the balance of my student loans ( {$5100.00} ) via Mohela/ePayment XXXX I received a payment confirmation email from Mohela with a confirmation number ( XXXX ) -On XXXX XX/XX/2024, {$5100.00} was withdrawn from my checking account reflecting the XXXX XX/XX/2024 payment ( XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ) -As of XXXX XX/XX/2024, my Mohela account still reflects a balance of {$5100.00}. There is no record of the payment in my account history. 
-I have called Mohela and spoken with customer service three times from XXXX XX/XX/2024 and was told that the payment is in the system, will be processed and the accrued interest will be cleared. However, I have not been given a date to expect this to take place by nor an explanation on why this can not be processed sooner. 
-I have continued to receive emails stating I have a payment due. 
-The payoff of this loan has not been reflected on my credit report. 
-I am getting impatient with the delay in processing the payment. I successfully paid off my student loans in full and almost three months later the payment is not reflected due to a delay of unknown reason in processing by Mohela. 
-I have documentation to support all dates, amounts, and statements.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: A consumer paid off their $5,100 student loan balance through Mohela's ePayment on a specific date, receiving a confirmation email and withdrawal from their checking account. However, nearly three months later, the payment is still not reflected in their Mohela account or credit report.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently was in the process of purchasing a home for my family and I and a week before closing I am being made aware that I have detrogarty marks on my credit from XXXX. 

I originally entered into an installment loan contract with XXXX XXXX and my terms were 12.49 % interest rate, finance charge of {$5800.00} amount financed {$11000.00} for a total of payments {$17000.00}. This would be XXXX payments at {$200.00}. 

I always paid more on my loan with XXXX XXXX and was ahead on my loan. 

In 2020 the account was transferred to XXXX XXXX XXXX. They changed the account from an installment loan to a revolving card. The payments are not applied properly and then they are now adding late charges and then adding finance charges that are already calculated in my monthly payments. 

Reviewing the statements from XXXX the statements have many errors and again my payments are not applied correctly. Just recently i have XXXX credit delinquency hits but yet my loan has been paid off way before the maturity date with all the extra money that was being sent. 

I attempted to reach out to XXXX myself and after I had XXXX minutes wasted with an unprofessional representative, I finally spoke to a supervisor XXXX who followed me step by step with all of my concerns. Although he was understanding, he stated that he would not be able to rectify the situation and would need to esculate it but told me that I would need to mail my credit report to XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX XXXX, CA. When i asked why XXXX XXXX XXXX when my statements say XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX. I explained that would take too long and also offered me an email address. 

I sent an email to XXXX but this is very time sensitive and will cost me a home for my family and I if not corrected immediately. 

I am a XXXX XXXX and not readily available to discuss things and even authorized and signed a XXXX party release form to speak to my mom XXXX XXXX. Still have not received any communication from them. 

I think they need to reverse and repost all of my payments including the payments ahead when I was with XXXX. They can also refund me ALL late fees and additional finance charges charged to me.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's complaint is about incorrect credit reporting by XXXX XXXX XXXX, which is affecting their home purchase. The issue started when the account was transferred from an installment loan to a revolving card, resulting in misapplied payments, late charges, and incorrect finance charges, despite the loan being paid off early.

Sub-issue: Loan balance remaining after the vehicle is repossessed and sold
Consumer complaint narrative: Hyundai Motor willfully repossessed the vehicle in 2022, however, upon recent discovery I found that the account states it was charged off. Since it has been reported as inaccurate information it should be removed immediately.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims Hyundai Motor repossessed their vehicle in 2022, but the account was incorrectly reported as "charged off". The consumer is requesting the inaccurate information be removed immediately.

Sub-issue: Loan opened without my consent or knowledge
Consumer complaint narrative: I am a victim of identity theft loans and inquiries was open and applied for without my consent. I have sent the Experian a copy of my identity theft report but they have yet to help me in this situations.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer's identity was stolen, resulting in unauthorized loans and credit inquiries. Despite sending an identity theft report to Experian, the issue remains unresolved, with no assistance provided by the credit agency.

Sub-issue: Problem with fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/year> I made my payment of {$300.00} which covers my loan and Insurance to cover the vehicle because I am unable to afford auto insurance at this time. An hour later I received a call from a lady saying I needed to pay {$200.00} more because their insurance rates when up, when I disputed the charges and told her I never received anything in writing, she proceeded to tell me how she has to pay for insurance on her two cars!! I told her I'm low income and had to wait till my check came in, she got irate with me so I hung up on her. XX/XX/year> I received a call from a gentleman who said he was in collections and I needed to pay {$200.00}. I mentioned how they are a predatory lender, he said nobody else gave us a loan then he laughed at me when I said I'd go to another lender like I was a stupid poor person who can't afford help from anyone but them! I am a XXXX XXXX  for my XXXX wife who needs the vehicle, I make my payment every month without fail and we never received anything stating our payment was going up {$200.00}. I don't believe my credit should be attached considering I'm not even a month late.

Original payments were {$260.00} Then {$310.00} to include insurance Now {$500.00} for payment and insurance, the lady said rates went up and the guy said to include insurance. None of this doesn't make sense
Narrative Summary: A consumer made a loan payment of $300, covering loan and insurance, but was then told they owed an additional $200 due to increased insurance rates. The consumer disputes the charge, citing no written notice and previous payments of $260-$310, and claims they're being treated unfairly.

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Problem with paying off the loan
Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint Letter to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, FL XXXX : XXXX : XXXX Date : XX/XX/XXXX Consumer Financial Protection BureauOffice of XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXWashington, D.C. XXXX Subject : Formal Complaint Against Nissan Finance and Authorized Dealerships for Misleading Practices and Poor Customer Service Dear CFPB, I am writing to formally lodge a complaint against Nissan Finance and its authorized dealerships, specifically XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX, for their misleading practices, unscrupulous behavior, and overall poor handling of my vehicle lease end and purchase process. 

Background : I am the co-owner, along with XXXX XXXX, of a XXXX XXXX XXXX leased from Nissan Finance. As the lease neared its end, I attempted to either return the leased vehicle or purchase it, starting from XX/XX/XXXX. However, my efforts have been met with consistent evasion, misleading information, and highly unprofessional behavior from the staff at the aforementioned dealerships. 

XXXX XXXX : XXXX. Misleading Sales Tactics : Despite clear communication regarding my intent to return the vehicle or explore options for a new lease similar in terms to my previous arrangement, dealership personnel repeatedly attempted to steer me toward unfavorable and unsolicited trade-in deals. 
XXXX. Failure to XXXX XXXX : On multiple occasions, after receiving direct assurances via phone and email that my concerns would be addressed, I was subjected to the same unhelpful and aggressive sales tactics, with no genuine effort made to resolve my situation. 
XXXX. Negligence and Potential Financial Harm : Most concerning is the handling of my visit on XX/XX/XXXX, after receiving a repossession warning from Nissan Finance. The dealerships staff ran my credit without achieving any result and proposed switching me to an inferior vehicle make, not aligning with the contractual agreement of having the option to purchase the leased vehicle. 

This series of actions demonstrates a pattern of deceptive practices and customer manipulation aimed at maximizing dealership profits at the expense of consumer rights and transparency. 

Request for Action : I urge the CFPB to investigate these practices and take appropriate action to ensure accountability and prevent further exploitation of consumers. I also seek assistance in resolving the matter with Nissan Finance directly, ensuring that my consumer rights are upheld and that any negative impact on my credit score is avoided. 

Please find attached all relevant communications and documentation supporting my claims. 

Thank you for your attention to this serious matter. I look forward to your prompt response and assistance in resolving these issues. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: A consumer filed a complaint against Nissan Finance and its dealerships for misleading practices and poor customer service during their vehicle lease end and purchase process. The dealerships allegedly used high-pressure sales tactics, ran the consumer's credit without consent, and proposed inferior vehicle options, potentially causing financial harm.

Sub-issue: Loan balance remaining after the vehicle is repossessed and sold
Consumer complaint narrative:
I don't believe I owe the amount listed on my consumer reports. I am tad bit confused ; there is an inflated balance on this charge-off account from the balance amount. Also, my date of last payment which is listed as XX/XX/year> I am uncertain about that as well. May I request for the information for this account. 

Thank you
Narrative Summary: A consumer disputes the balance on a charge-off account listed on their credit report, claiming it's inflated. They also question the listed date of last payment. The consumer requests information about the account to clarify the discrepancies.

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Problem with paying off the loan
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/2024 I bought a car from XXXX and financed it through their in-house financing company, Bridgecrest. On XX/XX/2024, my husband and I closed on a new loan at a much lower interest rate at XXXX XXXX XXXX. The payoff check, as per the amount provided by Bridgecrest, was mailed that same day by the XXXX XXXX. Bridgecrest did not process the loan payoff in a timely fashion. In fact, they debited another payment from my checking account on XX/XX/2024 in the amount of {$530.00}. I called Bridgecrest an inquired when I would receive a refund - they told me that I would receive {$490.00} because the check had not arrived within the 10-day payoff window. It is now, XX/XX/XXXX, and I have not received the check.
Narrative Summary: The consumer refinanced their car loan at a lower interest rate, but Bridgecrest failed to process the payoff in a timely manner. Despite the new lender sending a payoff check, Bridgecrest debited another payment and has not issued a full refund, claiming the check arrived late.

Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I recently received information from XXXX regarding a decrease in my credit score due to a 30 day late payment being reported from Ally Bank in XXXX. The collateral for this auto loan was a total loss reported in XXXX. Ally Bank was paid over {$30000.00} between the insurance claim and the gap insurance. I phoned Ally Bank today and was told that the late payment was accessed and reported to the credit bureaus in XXXX due to issues with the insurance checks - I was never made aware of any issues with these checks. By XXXX of XXXX, the insurance and the gap insurance payments were made to Ally leaving a {$1700.00} balance. When an attempt was made at the beginning of XXXX to pay the balance in full, their on line portal would not accept the payment - a phone call had to be made to pay the balance in full. Although the customer service agent did not want to accept the {$1700.00} payment because she wanted the payment made on line which we couldn't do she ended up taking the payment. After this payment was made, we received another notice of {$15.00} balance which was also paid. 

In closing, Ally Bank received $ XXXX between insurance and gap. Ally Bank applied these payments and the outstanding balance in XXXX was {$1700.00}. In XXXX Ally was called regarding payment arrangements for the outstanding {$1700.00}. Ally advised that they would accept a {$250.00} payment and then the remaining balance in XXXX. The {$250.00} was received by Ally in XXXX along with the final payment in XXXX. The account now has a {$0.00} balance. 

There was never an issue with the dates on the insurance checks which was the reason given to me today for the 30 day delinquency being reported. Ally agreed to accept a {$250.00} payment in XXXX and still reported a 30 day delinquency.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer's credit score decreased due to a 30-day late payment reported by Ally Bank. Ally claimed the late payment was due to issues with insurance checks, but the consumer disputes this, stating they were never informed of any issues and had made timely payments, including a $30,000 insurance payout.

Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I was unable to make a successful payment on my auto loan as of the statement of XX/XX/year>. This has caused Ford Motor Credit to accrue late fees, Submit a XXXX late payment, and a repossession on my credit report. I have continuously submitted payments that were returned on the account. As of sometime in XX/XX/year> the online access was revoked. 

I proceeded to contact Ford Credit. They told me to make a payment through XXXX XXXX or XXXX. I exercised that this was extremely convenient because of my work schedule. However, on my free time that was convenient I attempted to make the full payment at my earliest convenience. 

I then found out that the vehicle was repossessed on the morning in XX/XX/year>. This caused over {$1000.00} of fees to be added to account balance, me to take off work, and to travel over XXXX miles without my vehicle. 

I paid the balance in full immediately and still had to wait a business day to receive the vehicle. At the same time Ford Credit did not give me a solution to release the vehicle to a third party. I stated I was not available due to work. However, the repossession company gave me Ford Credits process to release the vehicle to the XXXX-party. I had to be on hold for a total of around XXXX hours. This was attempting to contact XXXX credit to make a payment, review the statement, retrieve the account number for payment, and request a third party release form. 

As of today, I have not received a statement since XXXX 2024. I do not have access to the online account. My credit report is reporting a XXXX late, a closed auto loan, an open and closed collection account, and a repossession.
Narrative Summary: The consumer's auto loan payment was returned, and online access was revoked. Despite attempts to make payments, the vehicle was repossessed, incurring over $1,000 in fees. The consumer paid the balance in full but faced difficulties retrieving the vehicle and resolving account issues.

Sub-issue: Loan opened without my consent or knowledge
Consumer complaint narrative: someone purchased a vehicles using my information i did not authorize nor did i sign any paper works and also taking a cell phone using my name without my permission
Narrative Summary: A consumer's personal information was used without permission to purchase a vehicle and obtain a cell phone, with no signed paperwork or authorization given.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX I submitted notarized revocation of POA, instructional letter detailing the problem and acceptable remedy, security instrument, all was sent together via registered mail to XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX to, Toyota Motor Credit Corporation XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX did make XXXX previous attempts to speak with XXXX XXXX XXXX regarding my concerns of the auto contract and what I believe to be deceptive and fraudulent practices. Both of my attempts to resolve the matter with XXXX XXXX resulted in the call being intentionally transferred to other departments, multiple abrupt disconnected calls and XXXX reps refusing to transfer the car to XXXX XXXX XXXX as I requested, nor would the person allow me to leave a message. Per 16CFR433.1 ( C ), the contract is actually between the bank- Lexus financial and 16CFR 433.1 ( J ) the dealership- XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX The only legal parties that may enter into contractual agreement are the creditor-Lexus Financial and the seller- XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX In addition as a consumer as defined by 16 CFR 433.1 ( b ) and TILA I am protected against deceptive and fraudulent business practices. However I noticed that after reviewing and comparing the documents that I received in hand from XXXX XXXX XXXX on XX/XX/XXXX prior to my leaving XXXX XXXX and the requested " copy '' that I received XX/XX/XXXX, my signature was forged on page XXXX of XXXX of the NOTE aka " retail installment ''. 
Upon my signature on the NOTE I am holder in due course and should have also receive a check reimbursing the full amount plus interest for my investment. Unfortunately I didn't realize nor did I understand that I also signed POA and security interest to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and as a result the check that I was unaware of and which was payable to me was received and processed by the security transfer agent for XXXX XXXX of XXXX. I Have since revoked Power of Attorney to XXXX XXXX of XXXX.
Narrative Summary: A consumer alleges Toyota Motor Credit Corporation engaged in deceptive practices with their auto contract. They claim their signature was forged on the retail installment note and that they unknowingly signed a power of attorney, resulting in a check meant for them being processed by the security transfer agent.

Sub-issue: Loan balance remaining after the vehicle is repossessed and sold
Consumer complaint narrative: The original loan was with US Auto, I had the loan and had been paying it since XXXX of XXXX to US Auto, one morning in XXXX of XXXX, I woke up to my vehicle being pulled off by a tow truck. Apparently my auto loan had been sold to westlake Portfolio MGM and I was not made aware of this by US Auto. When I researched further is when I found out. When I went to retrieve my belongings out of my vehicle, they tow yard explained what had been occurring because my vehicle was not the only. I had no communication with Westlake Portfolio nor did I sign any paperwork for them. Nor have I given them permission to have any communications with me. So according to 15 U.S. Code 1692 c, they should not be reporting on my credit report and I want it removed.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A consumer's auto loan was sold from US Auto to Westlake Portfolio MGM without their knowledge or consent. The vehicle was repossessed, and the consumer claims Westlake Portfolio MGM is reporting on their credit without permission, violating 15 U.S. Code 1692c.

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Problem with paying off the loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I purchased a vehicle from XXXX XXXX that is financed by Bridgecrest. During the first year of the loan, I experienced a financial hardship due to fraud, and was unable to make payments. The company deferred those payments ( even though those payments were deffered they still reported them negatively on my credit reports ). Since that time I made all payments as required and at some points paying over {$50.00} extra per month. Theyre now saying that the remaining balance is due in full, and are refusing to help even though Ive made all payments for the last 4 years. In addition, to requiring the remaining balance be paid in full, they stated if it isnt paid by 5/30 they will begin reporting negatively on my credit report, even though Im continuing to make my $ XXXX week payment. Vin of the car XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Complainant claims Bridgecrest unfairly demands full payment of their vehicle loan balance after 4 years of timely payments, despite previous hardship deferment and extra payments made. They also threaten to negatively report to credit if not paid by the deadline, while payments are still being made.

Sub-issue: Account status incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative: I paid loan online thinking it was my last payment. I selected monthly payment amount. I did not realize there was still a {$96.00} balance left on my account. I was not notified by email or phone call, I received a letter over a month later stating that it appears I intended to pay off my loan but there was still a {$96.00} balance. This caused Santander to report me late to the credit bureas. I paid well over {$38000.00} on this loan most of that being interest. I had a good payment history up until the very last payment that i thought I was paying the loan in full. I did not realize there was still a {$96.00} balance. If they had contacted me to let me know other than through the REGULAR MAIL over a month later I would have paid it IMMEDIATELY so it would not harm my credit report. Because, my credit is so important to me so that I can take care of my family with low interest rates, but this company is hurting me and my family gravely.
Narrative Summary: The consumer paid their loan online, thinking it was the final payment, but a $96 balance remained. Santander didn't notify them by email or phone, instead sending a letter over a month later, resulting in a late report to the credit bureau and damaging their credit score.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative: since XX/XX/year> i paid almost XXXX dollars then since they took my XXXX for standard payment other half goes to past due so for XXXX i should have gotten XXXX plus because of XXXX ish past due but i reviewed my bill i got XXXX ish dollars
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer claims they overpaid by almost $XXXX, but due to past due amounts, they only received $XXXX. They argue that the excess payment should have been applied to the current balance, not the past due amount, resulting in a discrepancy in their bill.

Sub-issue: Problem with fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative:
Kia is predatory in charging fees to clients. They shut off your online account if you have a returned payment and make you pay through one of their customer service representatives. To pay with the customer service agent, they charge you a fee. 

The only other option would be to mail a check, per their representatives, which costs money for postage and could delay payment being made.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Kia charges a fee to customers who pay through a customer service representative after their online account is shut off due to a returned payment, with the only alternative being to mail a check, incurring postage costs and potential payment delays.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative: I had a situation with XXXX XXXX XXXX in XXXX CA. I came down and put XXXX dollars down on a used XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX, the CCT was not done correctly, ended up being a good faith contract, for one the sum of all charges was incorrect, violation # 1, violation # 2 was the CCT requires it to be a cash in hand transaction, it was not. There fore by them breaking the contract that was written I am entitled to all the money financed and XXXX per violation of the contract and the property. The down I paid everything!. I will be thankful once I have a check in my hand to start to make this really long stressful process finally to rest
Narrative Summary: A consumer paid a down payment on a used vehicle at a California dealership. The Contract of Conditions of Transaction (CCT) was not executed correctly, resulting in incorrect charges and a non-cash transaction, violating the contract. The consumer claims they are entitled to a refund and compensation.

Sub-issue: Denied request to lower payments
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing this letter in order to request your help and understanding. Back in XXXX, XXXX [ when the negative items was listed on my auto loan ], I lost my job and made a couple of late payments, even though I hated paying late. I do feel bad about it even now. However, I did get current on the account ( listed above ) as soon as my financial standing improved. I have in fact made timely payments since then. I've been working hard to make financially responsible decisions and get better control of my money. 

I am now buying a home but having difficulty in receiving an affordable mortgage rate due to the negative listing on my credit report. Thereby, I would request you to kindly remove this negative item as a gesture of goodwill. Your kind gesture would be sincerely appreciated.
Narrative Summary: A consumer is requesting removal of a negative auto loan listing from their credit report as a goodwill gesture. The listing resulted from late payments after job loss, but payments have been timely since regaining financial stability. The listing now affects their ability to get an affordable mortgage rate.

Sub-issue: Problem after you declared or threatened to declare bankruptcy
Consumer complaint narrative: I've reached out to Capital One XXXX on XX/XX/year> to schedule the pick up for the voluntary repossession of my vehicle per the instructions from my bankruptcy attorney. The representative that I spoke with first stated that a form was incorrectly signed and has to be redone in order to go on further. I asked them why they haven't sent it back to them and he stated that they were waiting for a call from them and permission to do so. It was back and forth until I requested to speak to someone else about this matter and the lead that I was transferred to did not even mention the incorrect form and said something completely different about setting it up for pick up. I reached back out to my attorney and she said to wait a few days and try again. So I tried today, XX/XX/year>, I got the same agent on the phone who stated the same thing about the form being incorrectly signed so I asked him why wasn't it sent since the last time we spoke. His response quickly changed to saying that they did send it and got it back still incorrect. I asked again to speak to another agent and the current agent refused to do so and said that I should call back later. I have been bombarded with calls from Capital One to get payments before I filed and now since I did, they are delaying their end of the agreement of my case.
Narrative Summary: The consumer is experiencing issues with Capital One regarding the voluntary repossession of their vehicle as part of a bankruptcy agreement. Despite multiple calls, the company has provided inconsistent information and failed to resolve the issue, citing an incorrectly signed form that was allegedly resent but not corrected.

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Excess mileage, damage, or wear fees, or other problem after the lease is finished
Consumer complaint narrative:
I had a two year lease on a XXXX  XXXX XXXX XXXX through Ally and XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
My vehicle, aside from a small stone chip on the right bottom front windshield that I immediately had filled after it happened, was in perfect condition. I was warned to make sure that I take as many pictures of my car as possible when grounding it and now I know why. I took pictures of my car in broad daylight from every angle and Ally said they can not accept them because they are blurry They most certainly are anything but blurry. 
I am fully prepared to pay for any overage on mileage but I am certainly not paying for fraudulent charges. I found several posts on XXXX regarding Ally doing the same thing to other people and one specifically referenced an XXXX XXXX lease. 
I attached a copy of the charges which references {$2400.00} but Ally is now charging me {$3100.00} with no explanation. 
When I try to call and speak to someone, I hold for 20-30 minutes and then the person I speak to says they cant help me and when I ask for a supervisor they disconnect my call.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A consumer leased a vehicle through Ally and returned it in good condition, but Ally is charging them $3,100 for damages, despite clear photos showing no issues. The consumer disputes the charges, citing similar complaints from others and a lack of explanation for the increased fee.

Sub-issue: Problem with fees charged
Consumer complaint narrative: We had a late payment, due on XXXX paid on XXXX, so we got a {$50.00} fee, thats fine my mistake. I paid the over due payment & my next payment that was paid early had a {$50.00} Late Payment Fee? So 2 {$50.00} fees for 1 missed payment?
Narrative Summary: A consumer received two $50 late payment fees: one for a missed payment and another for the next payment, which was made early. They dispute the second fee, arguing it's unfair to charge two fees for a single missed payment.

Sub-issue: Denied request to lower payments
Consumer complaint narrative: I went for a car loan that I've already had to refinance. The interest is so high it's like they are double dipping. I feel like I will never pay this loan off
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims their car loan has an excessively high interest rate, forcing them to refinance, and feels they'll never pay off the loan due to the high interest, likening it to "double dipping."

Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Unable to receive car title or other problem after the loan is paid off
Consumer complaint narrative: i paid off my chase auto loan early and payment processed on XX/XX/XXXX. today is the XXXX and they refuse to notify the state of florida that it is paid off. i have called them 4 times, and every time they tell me a different lie than the previous call. i can't sell the car without a clear title. today they told me they would do it on the XXXX!! 2 calls ago they told me it had been done already!
Narrative Summary: Chase Auto Loan failed to notify the state of Florida that a loan was paid off, despite multiple calls and conflicting information from representatives, preventing the consumer from obtaining a clear title to sell the vehicle.

Sub-issue: Problem with additional products or services purchased with the loan
Consumer complaint narrative: I have reached out twice to Bridgecrest Bank, who currently holds my vehicle 's Lien, which I bought in early XX/XX/year>. Shortly after, I received military orders to PCS ( permanent change of station ) OCONUS, and in order to ship my car on the military 's dime, one of the documents required is a Lienholders authorization letter. So I called the Bridgecrest, and made the request, submitted my orders per the instructions, and my timeline. A month passed and didn't hear back. Now it's been XXXX months, so I called back to check the status, and this time I was told that in order for me to receive this letter I have to pay an additional {$1800.00} ( XXXX more payments ) before they could release this letter. This is unreasonable and not to mention never initially part of the original contract or conversation I had in XXXX. I am to ship this car on XXXX XXXX and this issue is against the Service Member Civil Relief Act and adding additional unwarranted stress to an already stressful situation.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: Bridgecrest Bank is withholding a required Lienholders authorization letter for a military member's vehicle shipment, demanding an additional $1800 payment (not part of the original contract) before releasing the letter, despite the member's initial request and submission of military orders.

Sub-issue: Deficiency balance after repossession
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/year>, I received notice in the form of a Deficiency Letter that Credit Acceptance had sold the vehicle to another consumer through a third party auctioneer named XXXX XXXX. I called Credit Acceptance on that same date and requested a copy of the XXXX XXXX because the amount they claimed to have sold it for seems to be incredulous. I even told them that they can edit or black out with a marker the consumers personal information that bought the car. They have refused to send this information violating federal law so that I can verify what it was actually sold for and pay what my remaining balance my be.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer received a Deficiency Letter from Credit Acceptance stating their vehicle was sold at auction. They requested a copy of the auction document to verify the sale price, but Credit Acceptance refused, allegedly violating federal law, to confirm the remaining balance owed.

Sub-issue: Notice to repossess
Consumer complaint narrative: They Discriminated on me Via contract agreement, by Denying I my unalienable rights to my benefits, and Titles as I examined the DISHONESTY thru out the XXXX years, I addressed it with honor XXXX transparency, and the outcome is ( repossession vehicles assignment...
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims a contract agreement was breached, denying them benefits and titles. They allege dishonesty over several years, which they addressed with transparency, but the outcome was vehicle repossession and assignment.

Sub-issue: Loan balance remaining after the vehicle is repossessed and sold
Consumer complaint narrative: The company Bridgecrest stated that my vehicle was in a tow yard and incurred extra fees. The vehicle was at the mechanics. Bridgecrest stated in the first phone call that it was too dirty ( that doesn't make sense ), that it was broken ( it was at the mechanics ), and finally that they had abandoned it even though they knew were it was ( GPS was installed per contract ). Finally, I called again and someone did some investigating saying that they verbally negotiated and decided that they did not want to get the car. There are no verifying documents. The car was abandoned and auctioned without applying the amount to the loan, they continued to have this open on my credit charging my account as a bad debt until XX/XX/XXXX because I called in to ask questions. This has been affecting my ability to provide my family safe housing and the account was mishandled seeing as they said the car was auctioned in XXXX. To have the account showing late up until XXXX is obscene.
Narrative Summary: Bridgecrest incorrectly reported a vehicle as abandoned and towed, despite GPS tracking and knowledge of its location at a mechanic. The vehicle was auctioned without applying the amount to the loan, and the account remained open as a bad debt on the consumer's credit until they inquired.

Consumer complaint narrative: Cant log into my workout day portion do proceed with the tasks for the orientation I need to complete, but long in provide to me isnt
Company public response: Company believes the complaint provided an opportunity to answer consumer's questions
Narrative Summary: A user is unable to log in to the "workout day" section to complete orientation tasks, despite being provided a login.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative: Signed a lease on XX/XX/2023 on a XXXX with the XXXX of XXXX, NJ via Ally Bank. Section 6c showed no amount to be paid in cash, but I was charged a cash monthly payment anyway. According the least, the full amount due at signing, including the first monthly payment, was to be covered by " Rebates and noncash credits ''. The cash payment I made was not counted toward anything. I bought out the vehicle shortly before the end of the first monthly period, trying unsuccessfully to get Ally or XXXX to correct the contract by that point, making several calls to both parties. Ally claims any errors in the lease would be checked and corrected during the buyout process. The buyout price did not reflect my cash payment having been made. The dealer claims Ally took the monthly payment. Ally will not provide any response at all other than that they can not give a refund.
Narrative Summary: A consumer signed a lease with Ally Bank, but was charged a monthly cash payment despite the lease stating it would be covered by rebates and noncash credits. After buying out the lease, the consumer's cash payment was not reflected in the buyout price, and Ally refused to provide a refund.

Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
Well, for the past year I have made payments to my car loan and when I thought I was caught up I decide to try for a home loan and found through both XXXX XXXX and XXXX that I had XXXX missed or late payments and that the account had not been update since XX/XX/2023. 

So I called twice to ask for information and they gave me the run around about a glitch. 

Then I sent them a letter and return all they sent was a current invoice.
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer's car loan account was not updated since XX/XX/2023, showing missed or late payments, despite regular payments made over the past year. The lender provided no clear explanation, instead blaming a "glitch" and only sending a current invoice after a written inquiry.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative: On a phone call in XX/XX/XXXX I was told I have my final payment in XX/XX/XXXX ... because of contradictory statements I decided to call right back 5 mins later and on this subsequent call I spoke with a supervisor at American Credit Acceptance and he told me I have 20 more payments! I was stunned... and he told me that I requested an extension... .which is completely false and deceitful. The only extension ( or because of XXXX XXXX ) I asked for a 2 month payment hardship and resume payments on the third month as scheduled. That was the one and only time I requested due to financial hardship because I had contracted XXXX and XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX! There is such fraudulent and deceitful practices within American Credit Acceptance and I have been victim for years now and still they are making false statements, contradictory claims regarding requests I've never made. They have caused agreat financial and emotional hardship by fraudulent activity and claims on my account. I have just this week consulted with an attorney ... you have done nothing to investigate the aggregious and fraudulent actions by American Credit Acceptance regarding my account... how is that one agent says XX/XX/XXXX is final payment and 5 mins later a supv says 20 more payments because of a request I NEVER made for an extension? On time and early payments for years now ... my situation is one of the worst if all my research into their history of other customers with same history as mine and in New York that is one of most recent cases ... this has to stop ... to date I've paid over {$40000.00} on an original sticker price of {$15000.00} ... at XXXX XXXX interest and unknown amount of fees attached. I want them investigated for their illegal and fraudulent actions with my account for my XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims American Credit Acceptance made contradictory statements about their loan, initially stating the final payment was in a certain month, but a supervisor later claimed 20 more payments were needed due to a non-existent extension request, resulting in alleged financial and emotional hardship.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative: I've been looking at my credit report lately because I am trying to get in position to buy a house. I noticed Ally Financial reporting late payments on my report that is not at all accurate and this information is extremely damaging to my credit worthiness. I was taking a look at my card member agreement and noticed thatI have the right to arbitration in disputes. I am demanding Ally Financial update these late payments asap as they are a violation of my consumer rights under 15 USC 1666b in which a creditor is not to report late payments. Also I do not give Ally Financial permission to report any information to ANY third party that is adverse to me the consumer. Time is of the essence
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: A consumer disputes late payments reported by Ally Financial on their credit report, claiming inaccuracies and violations of their consumer rights under 15 USC 1666b. The consumer demands correction of the errors, citing their right to arbitration and refusing permission for adverse reporting.

Consumer complaint narrative: so back in XXXX i bought a vehicle with us auto sales and in XXXX they sold the company to west lake portfolio and now its as if my auto loan started over and im being charged XXXX for a used hyumdai tuscan XXXX this car is not worth that amount

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative:
I have been defrauded by Toyota Financial. In XX/XX/XXXX, I went into Toyota in XXXX Illinois to help my husband obtain a car. He was looking to drive XXXX part time for extra money and wanted to obtain a newer vehicle for safety purposes and for the comfort of his passengers. I co-signed the loan willingly. At that time, I was told I was just the co-signer and XXXX XXXX was the owner of the loan, listed as the first person on it and the lien after the car was paid off would be in his name. 

In XX/XX/XXXX, my husband and I decided he should be on his own loan and I should be on my own for the sake of building our own strong credit histories. We went to XXXXXXXX XXXX in XXXX, IL because we had banked with them for more than 10 years and trusted them. I explained I did not want to be on the loan or any paperwork for him. They ran his credit and had both of us sign paperwork because I advised them I was on the last loan and needed to be taken off for this new one. I signed multiple documents, as did my husband. We proceeded to have an email conversation with the representative we filled paperwork out with where I specifically stated again I did not want to be on the loan or any paperwork. She said she understood and I would not be on any paperwork. A few months later, my husband got a speeding ticket while XXXX in XXXX. I called the XXXX of XXXX and advised that it wasnt my car, I was not driving and was not the owner or on any paperwork. They advised me that I was listed as the owner of the car. Because of the XXXX my husband and I were sent documents twice and asked to fill them out. They were emailed back twice via docusign and driven in person to the XXXX XXXX XXXX of XXXX. 

I recently pulled all 3 copies of my credit report because I am trying to move into a new apartment and the owners are all asking that you have a XXXX XXXX XXXX to rent ( which sounds illegal to me- but here I am filing my 4th or 5th complaint over how I have been treated in a way that was either illegal or unlawful ). When I pulled the XXXX credit report, I noticed XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX shows the owner as UNDESIGNATED- yet XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX said I was listed as the owner. Additionally, it shows the last payment on this loan as XX/XX/XXXX. This loan was not closed until XX/XX/XXXX, so where are my payments? I was paying someone so who was it when I didnt sign off on another loan? Why was the title in my name as a co-signer? My husband was primary on the account, not me. I received a speeding ticket from XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX as well as one from Iowa traffic cameras because of their negligence. And my payments are missing. It's just complete fraud. 

The documents attached contain the loan/lien and documents that was supposed to be only under my husbands name and XXXX was told this verbally and in writing. They still added me as a co signer and said I was on the lien though I told them know. This documentation is to show the actual date the loan was redone. Not before, which shows me payments are missing and were sent to a 3rd party that I did not authorize XXXX XXXX ( and my husband didnt ) to send to. No loan changes were made until XX/XX/XXXX. Inaccurate payments noted as well as the wrong owner are designated by XXXX XXXX information,
Narrative Summary: A consumer claims Toyota Financial defrauded her by listing her as the owner of a car loan despite her verbal and written requests to be removed as co-signer. She alleges missing payments and incorrect credit reporting, with attached documents supporting her claim of unauthorized loan changes.

Sub-issue: Deficiency balance after repossession
Consumer complaint narrative: In XX/XX/year> my vehicle was repossessed. I am requesting the following information : Itemization of Account : Kindly provide a detailed breakdown of all charges, fees, and expenses associated with the aforementioned account. * Documentation Regarding Original Contract : Please furnish all relevant paperwork pertaining to the original contract, including finance documents signed and a complete account payment history. * Repossession Details : I seek clarification regarding the repossession of the vehicle linked to this account : * What was the amount for which the vehicle was sold at auction? * When and where was the car repossessed? * What was the amount due upon repossession? * Compliance with Illinois Repossession Laws : I request confirmation on whether the original creditor complied with Illinois repossession laws throughout the repossession process. * Statute of Limitations : Kindly provide information on the statute of limitations applicable to this account, along with a detailed explanation of how it was calculated. * Participation in Lawsuits : I inquire about the possibility of joining any lawsuits that may arise against the original creditor. Please advise on the procedures necessary for participation in such legal actions.
Narrative Summary: A consumer's vehicle was repossessed and they're requesting detailed information about the account, including charges, original contract documents, repossession details, and compliance with Illinois repossession laws, as well as the statute of limitations and potential participation in lawsuits against the original creditor.

In XXXX, the repairman told me that I needed to scrap the car. Yesterday, the insurance officer told me that my compensation had already paid for my car loan. I leased the car so I can not get my compensation. I find it hard to understand.

Consumer complaint narrative: My name is XXXX XXXX and my phone number is XXXX. I have ordered my Tesla XXXX XXXX  under this email and I had applied for loan financing. My order number is XXXX. I have reached out to your sales representatives over this week many times and this has not been the best experience. I was XXXX through the Tesla application for a loan and I was XXXX to pay {$750.00} in order to XXXX XXXX XXXX and to apply for financing through Tesla. Now that I have done everything been asked by Tesla and I have provided my XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX deposit & been XXXX to {$750.00} and I was informed that I am approved through their prequalifying system. It is been over a week and my credit been ran and my score went down due to Tesla running my credit and I have not been in communication with Tesla financing team once because they conduct all their business via Tesla application which I have followed all their steps. Issue: Problems at the end of the loan or lease
Sub-issue: Unable to receive car title or other problem after the loan is paid off
Consumer complaint narrative:
On XX/XX/XXXX, I was in a serious car accident that totally wrecked my XXXX XXXX XXXX. 
Because the car was a lease, my insurance company, XXXX issued payment {$200000.00} to the Lease holder, American Honda Financial Corp. for the value of the car. 
However, I only owed XXXX {$16000.00}. XXXX informed me that I would receive a check from them within 7-10 days of them receiving a check from XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX received the payment from XXXX in XXXX and I still have not received my check for {$4100.00}.

Sub-issue: Damage caused or loss of personal items in vehicle during the actual repossession
Consumer complaint narrative: I leased a XXXX XXXX through XXXX XXXX, XXXX XXXX, AR, financed through Santander Consumer USA. Within the first three days I noticed the vehicle was driving bad. After inspection it was found that the transmission was slipping. After a tedious time of trying to return the vehicle, I was allowed to. The day that XXXX XXXX paid off my loan, Santander had the vehicle repossessed. I have not been able to retrieve my items. I tried and tried and have filed multiple complaints. I also, contacted Santander multiple times regarding this vehicle and was advised to not return the vehicle because XXXX XXXX could resale it. My items and money that was in the vehicle were never returned to me. This too has been a tedious time. When the vehicle was repossessed Santander should have sent me a letter, that allows me to pay off all debt to get the vehicle back but they took the vehicle directly to Texas from Arkansas. My next step is getting an attorney. My dads ashes were in the vehicle.
Narrative Summary: A consumer leased a vehicle through a dealership, financed by Santander Consumer USA. The vehicle had transmission issues, and after returning it, Santander repossessed the vehicle without notice, taking the consumer's personal items, including their father's ashes, which were never returned.

I can not get through to anyone to finish the process. I filed a complaint and they said multiple things. They sent me an email and said i could upload the documents. And I had unril lte XXXX early XXXX. I can not uoad now and I can not get through to anyone. Capital One is giving me the runaround.

We came up with an agreement if I pay {$3800.00} they will release the car and then we are in agreement every month till XXXX I pay XXXX till remainder is paid off which in total came to {$7200.00} to get title. In XXXX we made are last payment we did XXXX payments they stated that was our last payment are account is closed and they would provide title in XXXX  days. Now they aren't trying to give us our title because in XXXX we made a payment XXXX days late and told us that the case manager was not suppose to continuing honor our old agreement that a new one was suppose to be made so they can not give us the title. No other agreement was giving to us we kept our end of the deal and they have the video recordings of every phone call showing proof that they made the mistake and now their not trying to give us our title and now they are avoiding our phone calls and not returning them back.

Sub-issue: Credit denial
Consumer complaint narrative:
I, the consumer and natural person was denied credit by Penfed Credit Union, on XX/XX/year>, when I applied for an auto loan to purchase a new car. 

Adverse Action against a consumer is AGAINST THE LAW according to the Equal Credit Opportunity Act which is codified in 15 U.S.C 1691c and is pursuant to civil liability under 15 U.S.C 1692k. 

You are subject to criminally liability for violating 15 U.S.C 1691 as I have proof that I was discriminated against by Penfed Credit Union due to the response I received. 

Penfed Credit Union, is in violation of 15 U.S code 1642 U.S.C 1681m and 12 CFR 1002 because I, the consumer made an application in good faith, but credit was not issued. 

Furthermore, because my social security number was used and I received NO benefit. This is proof of fraudulent activity on behalf of Penfed Credit Union. 

If Penfed Credit Union fails to make any reasonable procedures to resolve this matter and compensate me for the use of my social security, I will indeed make Penfed Credit Union criminally and civilly liable for all actual damages pursuant to 15 U.S.C 1681m and 15 U.S.C 1681o. 

I will also follow up with an invoice for said violations ( {$1000.00} ) per violation. 


Thank you, XXXX, XXXX XXXX
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response
Narrative Summary: The consumer was denied an auto loan by Penfed Credit Union, claiming this denial was discriminatory and in violation of the Equal Credit Opportunity Act. The consumer alleges Penfed used their social security number without issuing credit, constituting fraudulent activity, and demands compensation and resolution.

Sub-issue: Credit denial
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, I am writing to bring to your attention a matter regarding a recent denial of a car loan application and to inquire about potential violations of federal equal rights laws and CFR laws. 

On [ XX/XX/XXXX ], I applied for a car loan with [ Navy federal ]. Unfortunately, my application was denied, citing reasons that were not adequately explained to me. Upon further investigation, I believe that my application may have been denied in violation of federal equal rights laws and CFR laws.

According to the Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ) and Regulation B of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), lenders are prohibited from discriminating against applicants on the basis of race, color, religion, national origin, sex, marital status, age, or receipt of income from public assistance programs. I have reason to believe that my application denial may have been influenced by one or more of these protected factors.

Furthermore, Regulation B requires lenders to provide applicants with a written explanation of the reasons for adverse action, such as a loan denial. However, I did not receive a clear and specific explanation for the denial of my car loan application, which may be a violation of Regulation B.

I am deeply concerned about the potential violation of my rights under federal equal rights laws and CFR laws. I respectfully request that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau investigate this matter to ensure compliance with applicable laws and regulations.

Additionally, I would appreciate any guidance or assistance you can provide in addressing this issue and seeking recourse for any violations that may have occurred. 

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.
Company public response: Company believes it acted appropriately as authorized by contract or law
Narrative Summary: The consumer's car loan application with Navy Federal was denied without a clear explanation, potentially violating Regulation B. The consumer suspects discrimination under the Equal Credit Opportunity Act (ECOA), citing a lack of transparency in the denial reasons, and requests a CFPB investigation.

The consumer claims no contract with the third-party company and Westlake won't return the car, despite planning to sell it.

Sub-issue: Billing problem
Consumer complaint narrative: I am five payments away from paying my XXXX XXXX XXXX off. I lost my secondary employment, so things have been tight, and I have been late. I did seek help from Ally Auto, and they told me that they couldn't help me. Well, I have been paying the best way I can. So now I owe for XXXX and XXXX and my next payment is not due until XXXX XXXX XXXX  Well first on Friday I tried to gain access to my account, they have it blocked, I called and spoke with 2 people and then was passed off. This is the second time that I have been locked out of my account and not allowed to go in to pay something or see what is owed. I have no idea, what they are doing. I don't know what they are doing and at this point I don't know why I'm constantly being locked out. Then today I received mail, a certified letter saying that on the XXXX they will repossess my vehicle. I don't get paid until the XXXX XXXX XXXX and I won't be 3 months behind until XX/XX/XXXX. I have had issues with this company since I got this vehicle and now that I'm almost done and facing financial hardship, I believe I'm being harassed and not giving a chance to get things in order. Then I'm having issues when talking with someone, I have been transferred around and hung up on. I have issues with Ally financial auto when it comes to reporting, they report to my credit very quickly when late, but when I'm on time they barely report to the credit bureau, I have to call and force it.

Sub-issue: Account information incorrect
Consumer complaint narrative:
I gave Bridgecrest permission to report to the 3rd party credit agency but In regards to reporting negative items, According to 12 CFR 1016 and 15 USC 6802-6805. A consumer may exercise the right to opt out at any time. I am exercising my right to opting out. Any consent I have given whether implied spoken, unspoken, written, unwritten or otherwise is revoked and rescinded immediately and indefinitely. 

Removal of all derogatory items. 
Bridgecrest Shall remove all late payments past, present and futurefrom my credit report.15 USC 1681a ( 2 ) ( A ) ( i ) It is illegal to report transaction history. 2 ) All inaccuracy gives reason to delete late payments past present and future. 3 ) No permissible purpose FCRA 15 USC 1681b ( a ) ( 2 ). 4 ) Privacy Act 1974 Violation. 5 ) 15 USC 1666b Can not be reported late under an open end consumer credit plan for any purpose. Truth in lending defines open end consumer credit plan as payable in more than 4 installments. consumer credit reporting companies can not report income on the credit report. Update to paid as agreed.
Narrative Summary: The consumer is exercising their right to opt out of Bridgecrest reporting negative items to credit agencies, citing federal laws. They demand removal of all late payments from their credit report, claiming inaccuracies, lack of permissible purpose, and violations of the Privacy Act and Truth in Lending.

Sub-issue: High-pressure sales tactics
Consumer complaint narrative: On XX/XX/2024 we attempted to buy a new car at XXXX XXXX Toyota using our financial institution. We were told at near the end of the paperwork that if we did use our bank we could not drive the car off the lot without putting it on our policy first ( California law has a grace period for policy owners of which we are a policy owner and we showed them that fact ). We were told that their policy does not apply if we use Toyota Financing only if we use our own bank. We were pre-approved ofr almost twice the value of the car we were buying. This was a scam to force us to use their financial system.
Narrative Summary: A consumer alleged that XXXX XXXX Toyota misled them about California's insurance law, claiming they couldn't drive off the lot without adding the car to their policy, but only if they used their own bank, not Toyota Financing, in an attempt to force them to use the dealership's financial system.

I spoke to a customer service representative and a manager who refused to provide my payoff letter. They said I will receive my payment history but I haven't received it yet.
